text:
Despite its many oddities, *Between Dog and Wolf* features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC ("How Sokolov's" 205). Elena Kravchenko argues that, in opposition to the visual leanings of the chapters associated with Yakov, Ilya's chapters "may become less impenetrable if received aurally, which will
make its language play come 'alive'. [...] The unmistakable focus in Il'ia's *skaz* on oral culture — through numerous allusions to fairy tales and epics — and language, especially its aural qualities illuminated through paronomasia, is juxtaposed with the literariness and visuality of the prose and verse fragments" (*The Prose* 80).

Despite its many oddities, *Between Dog and Wolf* features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC ("How Sokolov's" 205).

Despite its many oddities, *Between Dog and Wolf* features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC ("How Sokolov's" 205). Sergei Orobii suggests that "in the novel *Between Dog and Wolf*, the principle that will become the cornerstone for determining the root affiliation of Sokolov's texts of the 2000s is mastered: prose is replaced with ease by poetry, or even merges with it. Such a narrative maneuver, of course, originates not in the plot, but in the field of language: considering that the Russian literary language has 'worn out' from constant use and has lost all expressiveness, the writer tries to get away from the usual linguistic norms and constructs a unique style, which becomes the driving force of the narrative. Here, the boundaries between replicas, between direct and indirect speech, between chatter and quotation are fundamentally blurred" (299).

Elena Kravchenko argues that, in opposition to the visual leanings of the chapters associated with Yakov, Ilya's chapters "may become less impenetrable if received aurally, which will make its language play come 'alive'. […] The unmistakable focus in Il'ia's skaz on oral culture — through numerous allusions to fairy tales and epics — and language, especially its aural qualities illuminated through paronomasia, is juxtaposed with the literariness and visuality of the prose and verse fragments" (*The Prose* 80). She describes the structure of the novel as follows: "The structure of the novel, excluding chapter eighteen [...], forms a set of convex mirrors. The first and last chapters are *skaz*, the second and penultimate are prose, the third and the fifteenth chapters are poems, then again two mirroring Il'ia's narratives (4 and 14), the prose narratives (5 and 13), Il'ia's (6 and 12), verse (7 and 11), and Il'ia's (8 and 10). The structure 'folds' in the middle, at chapter nine — a prose entry, thus making it a 'centrefold', which holds the book together" (*The Prose* 53–54).

highlighted: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки
text: The end of chapter 2 and chapter 5 were some of the earliest pieces of *Between Dog and Wolf* written. D. Barton Johnson reports: "This initial focus on Iakov, rather than Illia, emerges from the fragment of *Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom* that Sokolov sent to Carl Professor for the first number of Ardis' new serial miscellany *Glagol* (1977). [...] Much of this material, deleted in the final version, sets forth the book's central theme of indeterminacy much more explicitly than anything in the final variant. The *Glagol* excerpt was abstruse and Proffer's response was 'almost complete incomprehension' (letter to Sokolov of August 26, 1976). [...] In his reply of August 15, 1976, Sokolov suggested that Carl Proffer's doubts echoed his own. The material had been written under difficult psychological circumstances. He had wanted to parody various styles, but felt he had not succeeded. He now proposed that the fragment be published in *Glagol* but with the idea that it would remain suspended [...] The excerpt's opening and closing passages with their descriptions of Iakov and the excursus on his name/identity were deleted" ("Background Notes" 337–338).
chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

text: A reference to Ivan Turgenev's 1852 cycle of short stories *Notes of a Hunter* (also translated as *A Sportman's Notebook*, *The Hunting Sketches*, and *Sketches from a Hunter's Album*). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life. The "Notes" (Записки) trope is common in Russian literature: *Notes of a Rifle Hunter* (Aksakov), Notes of a Shallow Grass (Dryansky), "Notes of a Madman" (Gogol), *Notes from the Underground* (Dostoevsky), *Notes from a Dead House* (Dostoevsky), "Notes of a Madman" (Tolstoy), "Notes of a Christian" (Tolstoy), *Notes of a Doctor* (Veresaev), *Notes of a Young Doctor* (Bulgakov), *Notes of a Psychotic* (Ven. Erofeev), and *Notes of a Nonhunter* (Vantalov). Gerald Smith suggests that the Drunken Huntsman may also be a literary descendent of Alexander Pushkin's hero in *The Gypsies* ("The Verse" 329).
ru_trans: Отсылка к написанному в 1852 году циклу рассказов Тургенева "Записки охотника". Произведение получило признание за отражение крестьянской жизни. Образ "Записок" нередко встречается в русской литературе: *Записки ружейного охотника* (Аксаков), "Записки мелкотравчатого" (Дриянский), "Записки сумасшедшего" (Гоголь), *Записки из подполья* (Достоевский), *Записки из Мертвого дома* (Достоевский), "Записки сумасшедшего" (Толстой), "Записки христианина" (Толстой), *Записки врача* (Вересаев), *Записки юного врача* (Булгаков), *Записки психопата* (Вен. Ерофеев), *Записки неохотника* (Ванталов). Дж. Смит предполагает, что Запойный охотник может быть литературным потомком пушкинского героя из поэмы "Цыгане" (CASS 1987, Smith, "The Verse", 329).

text: Disagreement or disharmony between people, things, or music. In his chapters, Ilya tells the story of his troubles with the hunters. More generally, this translation of the original title (Zaitil'shchina, The Epic Tale Beyond the Itil') might also refer to the confluence and disharmony between the various narrative voices in the novel: Ilya's letter, the chapters concerning Yakov's life and thoughts, and Yakov's poetry.

Another variation on Ilya's unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker's essay, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). Since the beginning portion of the chapter is told by Orina, this could also be a plural form of Ilya's last name: "the Dzynzyrelas." However, as Korovashko suggests, "Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella 'squared': if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence" (277).
ru_trans: Необычная фамилия Ильи встречается и в других графических-орфографических вариантов дальше в тексте. Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). Поскольку начало главы рассказывает Орина, это также может быть формой множественного числа фамилии Ильи: "Дзынзырелы". Однако, Коровашко замечает, что "Илья Петрикеич становится как бы Золушкой «в квадрате»: если последняя потеряла всего лишь свой башмачок, то он утратил и ногу, и компенсирующие ее отсутствие костыли" (277).
suffix: Мол, все время я в бараках

text: The title of Ilya's chapters derives from the Tatar name of the Volga river (Itil'), and recalls the [Zadonshchina](http://www.drevne.ru/lib/zadon_s.htm), an epic literary text (dated late 14th century) about the Battle of Kulikovo of 1380 (its title derives from the river Don). As "the Zadonshchina shows the humanity of the Tatar troops and expresses genuine sympathy for a grief the Russian and Tatar alike could understand” (Halperin, *The Golden Horde *109), the Zaitil'shchina describes the diverse human universe by the Volga (Zavol'zhe), or Wolf river (Zavol'che) as it is called by paronomastic association between the terms Volga and "volk" (wolf). Andrei Zorin describes the setting of the novel in these terms: "in the second novel, the directly named Zaitil'shchina, or Zavolzh'e, serves only as a symbol for a lost corner of the earth. The specific topographical realities here are deliberately scarce, and the historical ones are so thoroughly mixed up that it is absolutely impossible to reconcile the events described with any particular part of our century. And this desire of the writer for the ultimate universalization of time and space in his novel finds its most vivid expression in the role played in his artistic world by the painting of Pieter Bruegel the Elder" ("Nasylaiushchii veter" 252); "The theme of physical damage in the novel becomes another embodiment of the Zaitil'shchina, a land where nothing is being built, produced, and only occasionally repaired, and more often it decays, becomes unusable, breaks and steals" ("Nasylaiushchii veter" 253). Vadim Kreid, titling his article "Zaitil'shchina," describes the "bezvremen'e" (the absence of time) as the "неизлечимая болезнь Заитильского бытия" (incurable illness of life in Zavol'zhe), while he also points out a specific "agnosticism" typical of this fictional world, based on "carelessness, inevitability of desolation, and nothingness (non-existence) as redemption" (беспечность, неизбежность опустошения и небытие как избавление) (216-217).

And this desire of the writer for the ultimate universalization of time and space in his novel finds its most vivid expression in the role played in his artistic world by the painting of Pieter Bruegel the Elder" ("Nasylaiushchii veter" 252); "The theme of physical damage in the novel becomes another embodiment of the Zaitil'shchina, a land where nothing is being built, produced, and only occasionally repaired, and more often it decays, becomes unusable, breaks and steals" ("Nasylaiushchii veter" 253). Vadim Kreid, titling his article "Zaitil'shchina," describes the "bezvremen'e" (the absence of time) as the "неизлечимая болезнь Заитильского бытия" (incurable illness of life in Zavol'zhe), while he also points out a specific "agnosticism" typical of this fictional world, based on "carelessness, inevitability of desolation, and nothingness (non-existence) as redemption" (беспечность, неизбежность опустошения и небытие как избавление) (216-217).

These verse segments are allegedly written by Yakov during his year on the Volga; they come divided in sections according to the time of the year, which is however never a specific season but a period between seasons. In this third section of Notes, the setting is spring.

chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

text: Unlike other chapters concerning Yakov, this final one is relatively straightforward. The parodies and stylistic flourishes are diminished, at least until its concluding section. It is also markedly shorter.

That is, Yakov. These verse segments are allegedly written by Yakov during his year on the Volga; they come divided in sections according to the time of the year, which is however never a specific season but a period between seasons. In this second collection of Notes, the setting is winter. Gerald Smith suggests that the "idea of going to the country for the winter rather than the summer is a calculated reversal of the accepted routine of polite society, and a fundamental aspect of the novel's anti-'civilized' stance" ("The Verse" 325). In opposition to most critics, he also proposes that the Notes are composed by a "controlling intelligence" beyond the novel's main characters ("The Verse" 326).
ru_trans: То есть, Яков. Можно предположить, что эти стихотворные фрагменты написаны Яковом во время его годового пребывания на Волге; они разделены на части согласно временам года, однако, не конкретным сезонам, а межсезоньям. Во вторых Записках время действия — зима. Дж. Смит предполагает, что "идея ехать в деревню зимой, а не летом, умышленно противопоставляется общепринятому обычаю приличного общества и является фундаментальным аспектом анти-цивилизованной позиции романа" (CASS, "The Verse", 325). Вопреки мнению большинства критиков, он также считает, что Записки созданы неким "управляющим разумом" за пределами круга главных героев романа (CASS, "The Verse", 326).

text: These verse segments are allegedly written by Yakov during his year on the Volga; they come divided in sections according to the time of the year, which is however never a specific season but a period between seasons. In this third section of Notes, the setting is late spring to late summer. The title of this chapter alludes to the portion of Mikhail Lermontov's 1839 novel *A Hero of Our Time* titled "Pechorin's Journal." Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/12/p.4/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/913/pg913-images.html).
One more chapter written "as if" by Ilya in the book. Ilya's chapters are the 1st, 4th, 6th, 8th, 10th, 12th, 14th, 17th.

Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky's famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky's work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O31KPk5xnBg).

Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky's famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky's work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O31KPk5xnBg).

The title that Ilya gives to his missive to Pozhilykh. Its name echoes that of the *Zadonschina*, a Russian manuscript of late 14th century, about the Battle of Kulikovo (1380) between Russians and Mongols. The contents of Ilya's letters concern the events related to his life and death that occur "beyond the Itil River." In this way, the story Ilya tells Pozhilykh becomes a real epic poem.

A reference to Ivan Turgenev's 1852 cycle of short stories *Notes of a Hunter* (also translated as *A Sportsman's Notebook*, *The Hunting Sketches*, and *Sketches from a Hunter's Album*). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life. The "Notes" (Записки) trope is common in Russian literature: *Notes of a Rifle Hunter* (Aksakov), Notes of a Shallow Grass (Dryansky), "Notes of a Madman" (Gogol), *Notes from the Underground* (Dostoevsky), *Notes from a Dead House* (Dostoevsky), "Notes of a Madman" (Tolstoy), "Notes of a Christian" (Tolstoy), *Notes of a Doctor* (Veresaev), *Notes of a Young Doctor* (Bulgakov), *Notes of a Psychotic* (Ven. Erofeev), and *Notes of a Nonhunter* (Vantalov). Gerald Smith suggests that the Drunken Huntsman may also be a literary descendent of Alexander Pushkin's hero in *The Gypsies* ("The Verse" 329). Furthermore, on a technical level, Smith writes: "The metrical-typology of the poems in *DW*, crudely stated, is as follows. The texts fall into the conventional four groups as follows: Iambic, 8; Trochaic, 6; Ternary, 17; Other, 4; one poem is polymetric (XXXI). Compared with the norms for contemporary Russian poetry, this distribution represents much higher proportions than usual in the trochaic and ternary groups, and a reduced proportion in the iambic; that is, Sokolov is modelling a repertoire that deviates from literary verse and leans towards folkloric models. However, the two poets who made the most important contribution to the domestication and exploitation of ternary metres in Russian poetry were Nikolai Nekrasov in the mid-nineteenth century and then Boris Pasternak in his work before the mid-1920s, and Sokolov's verse evokes a strong echo of their work" ("The Verse" 329–330). As for the number of poems in the novel, Alexander Boguslawski writes: "one can construct an even more tempting hypothesis that the number of chapters — 18 and the number of poems — 37 are a concealed intertextual reference to the date of Pushkin's death (1837) and to his age at death" ("How Sokolov's" 207).
ru_trans: Отсылка к написанному в 1852 году циклу рассказов Тургенева "Записки охотника". Произведение получило признание за отражение крестьянской жизни. Образ "Записок" нередко встречается в русской литературе: *Записки ружейного охотника* (Аксаков), "Записки мелкотравчатого" (Дриянский), "Записки сумасшедшего" (Гоголь), *Записки из подполья* (Достоевский), *Записки из Мертвого дома* (Достоевский), "Записки сумасшедшего" (Толстой), "Записки христианина" (Толстой), *Записки врача* (Вересаев), *Записки юного врача* (Булгаков), *Записки психопата* (Вен. Ерофеев), *Записки неохотника* (Ванталов). Дж. Смит предполагает, что Запойный охотник может быть литературным потомком пушкинского героя из поэмы "Цыгане" (CASS 1987, Smith, "The Verse", 329). Более того, с технической точки зрения, Смит пишет: "Метрическая классификация стихов в *Между собакой и волком*, грубо говоря, следующая. Cтихи разделяются на четыре традиционные группы: Ямб, 8; Хорей, 6; Трехдольное, 17;  Другое, 4; один из стихов полиметрический (XXXI). Согласно нормам современной руской поэзии, такое распределение показывает намного большую долю хореических и трехдольных стихов, и меньшую долю ямбических; то есть, Соколов создает репертуар, отклоняющийся от литературного слога и больше напоинающий фольклорические модели. Однако, если двумя поэтами, которые внесли значимый вклад во внедрение и адаптацию трехдольного метра в русской поэзии, были Н. Некрасов в середине XIX века и Б. Пастернак в его работах до середины 1920-х, то в слоге Соколова прослеживается сходство с их работами (CASS 1987, Smith, "The Verse" 329–330). Что касается количества стихов в романе, А. Богуславский пишет: "можно предложить еще более заманчивую гипотезу о том, что число глав – 18 – и число стихов – 37 – являются скрытой отсылкой к году смерти Пушкина (1837) и возрастом его смерти" (Boguslawski, "How Sokolov's" 207).

text: A reference to Ivan Turgenev's 1852 cycle of short stories *Notes of a Hunter* (also translated as *A Sportman's Notebook*, *The Hunting Sketches*, and *Sketches from a Hunter's Album*). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life. The "Notes" (Записки) trope is common in Russian literature: *Notes of a Rifle Hunter* (Aksakov), Notes of a Shallow Grass (Dryansky), "Notes of a Madman" (Gogol), *Notes from the Underground* (Dostoevsky), *Notes from a Dead House* (Dostoevsky), "Notes of a Madman" (Tolstoy), "Notes of a Christian" (Tolstoy), *Notes of a Doctor* (Veresaev), *Notes of a Young Doctor* (Bulgakov), *Notes of a Psychotic* (Ven. Erofeev), and *Notes of a Nonhunter* (Vantalov). Gerald Smith suggests that the Drunken Huntsman may also be a literary descendent of Alexander Pushkin's hero in *The Gypsies* ("The Verse" 329).

That is, Yakov. These verse segments are allegedly written by Yakov during his year on the Volga; they come divided in sections according to the time of the year, which is however never a specific season but a period between seasons. In these first Notes, the setting is fall-winter. Gerald Smith suggests that the "idea of going to the country for the winter rather than the summer is a calculated reversal of the accepted routine of polite society, and a fundamental aspect of the novel's anti-'civilized' stance" ("The Verse" 325). In opposition to most critics, he also proposes that the Notes are composed by a "controlling intelligence" beyond the novel's main characters ("The Verse" 326). Alcohol theme.A different interpretation is advanced by Leiderman and Lipovetsky, who interpret the novel as a tripartite narration, unfolded progressively by Ilya, Yakov, and a third “impersonal author” (Russkaia literatura xx veka, 407). However, as Napolitano underlines, "In such a drunk atmosphere, not only the narrative staggers, due to the blurred vision of its narrators, but the reader, too, wavers in following the flows of the voices weaving together the narrative texture. These voices are not simply Ilya’s and Yakov’s (and his alternative personalities, including the Binging Hunter’s), but Maria-Orina also shows up, accompanied for instance by a nineteenth-century porter, or even a certain Carus Sterne with his natural history book *Werden und Vergehen*. Thus, we are presented with Maria’s notebook, containing “sufferings in the Russian language.” Orina will take the floor and open chapter 10 describing her life “in the barracks,” being “known as a walker and turned into a typical strumpet.” Elsewhere, “God only knows how long their confusion would have lasted if the porter Avdey, a sleepy peasant with a pitch-black beard reaching up to his dull and birdlike tiny eyes and with a similarly dull metal badge, did not come to say to the master that they should not be angry – the samovar completely broke” (and, of course, instead of a tea then, he suggests that they sip some “fresh beer”) (CASS, "Studyin this Volapuke", 291).

I'd also add this to your annotation, after you write "are allegedly written by Yakov": "to the extent we can assume he is the author of the Notes – and such a first name, so close to the Russian word iakoby, makes him literally only ‘allegedly’ a hunter, a wannabe poet/artist, or, more generally speaking, a round and authentic character" (Napolitano, CASS, "Studyin this Volapuke", 292). 
[of course, it is not necessary to quote myself, we can also re-write these ideas; it was just easier to copy-paste them :) ]
ru_trans: То есть, Яков. Можно предположить, что эти стихотворные фрагменты написаны Яковом во время его годового пребывания на Волге; они разделены на части согласно временам года, однако, не конкретным сезонам, а межсезоньям. В первых Записках время действия — осень-зима. Дж. Смит предполагает, что "идея ехать в деревню зимой, а не летом, умышленно противопоставляется общепринятому обычаю приличного общества и является фундаментальным аспектом анти-цивилизованной позиции романа" (CASS, "The Verse", 325). Вопреки мнению большинства критиков, он также считает, что Записки созданы неким "управляющим разумом" за пределами круга главных героев романа (CASS, "The Verse", 326). Тема алкоголя.

text: In Note XXXVI, Yakov claims to send his other 36 poems in a bottle down the river (R273/E216).

Again, Ilya's unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker's essay, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). However, as Korovashko suggests, "Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella 'squared': if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence" (277).
ru_trans: Вновь, необычная фамилия Илья (которая встречается более 10 раз и в других графических-орфографических вариантах дальше в тексте). Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356).

text: Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative "tovarishch," opting for a rather general, but still evocative word (cf. Nikolai Nekrasov's "Poet i grazhdanin," "Poet and Citizen," 1856).

Colloquial: she says. This is a continuation of the very end of chapter 8 where Orina takes over the narrative (R212/E108). For an extended analysis of this part of the chapter, see Barbara Heldt's "Female Skaz in Sasha Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf*."
suffix: , все время я в бараках тут прож

text: This expression hides a double meaning, as the word "mesiats" may mean both "moon" and "month". The author is at once suggesting that "the month is clear" (a rather indeterminate time setting) and that "the moon shines". The formulation recalls also Nikolai Gogol's *Diary of a Madman* (1834): "I don't remember the date. There was also no month" (Ostanin 10). Finally, this opening sets up the novel's fixation on seasonal time markers, as opposed to those created by humans.
ru_trans: Данное выражение скрывает в себя по крайней мере два значения: подразумевается либо месяц календаря, либо фаза луны. В первом случае это довольно неопределенное указание на время года, а во втором случае описывается, как луна сияет на небе. Формулировка напоминает "Записки сумасшедшего" Н. Гоголя: "Числа не помню. Месяца тоже не было" (Останин 10). К тому же, такое начало книги подсказывает, что в романе время движется согласно природным знакам времен года, оно не измеряется человеческими инструментами, приборами.
suffix: , за числами не уследишь, год ны

text: Dated: same as сдвинуться (to gather together). Colloquial: to go crazy.
A continuation of the end of chapter 10.

highlighted: Месяц ясен, за числами не уследишь, год нынешний
text: Elena Kravchenko writes: "Sokolov differs from both the avant-garde aestheticization of the real and the conceptualist disclosure of the hyper-real. Firstly, reality is a priori presented in a reflected form through a series of artistic representations. Secondly, in his engagement with these signs, Sokolov does not simply abstract them from their 'original' function or context, but grounds them in their original medium: language. [...]. A pun, produced through a play on the homonym 'mesiats', throws off the reader, forcing him to reflect on the plurality of signifieds covered by a single name. By using the adjective 'iasnyi' (clear), with its indication of both clarity as colour and a level of intelligibility, the narrator provokes a double entendre, thus revealing the basis of the notion of time: the abstract category of time is grounded in a spatial (alberit heavenly) body" (*The Prose* 71).

highlighted:
Месяц ясен, за числами не уследишь, год нынешний. Гражданину 
Сидор Фомичу Пожилых с уважением Зынзырэлы Ильи Петрикеича — Заитильщина
text: Alexey Salomatin and Artem Skvortsov identify this opening line as a reference to the apocryphal "Correspondence between the Turkish Sultan and the Cossacks" (248). Read the original letter [here](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BC%D0%BE_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D1%82%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%83_%D1%81%D1%83%D0%BB%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%83). They note that the novel's opening begins with a reference to the letter's *ending*.

A Turkic (Khazar) name for the Volga River, specifically the lower course of the Volga from the mouth to the confluence with the Kama, the section of the Kama to the confluence with the White, and the entire course of the White.

предложения построенные схожим образом: инфинитив + доп.
Жить [...] быть [...] жить, быть и видеть [...] жить-быть [...] жить-быть [...] It is also resonant with the list of verbs that comes as an epigraph in *A School for Fools*: 
Гнать, держать, бежать, обидеть, слышать, видеть, и вертеть, и дышать, и ненавидеть, и зависеть, и терпеть.
Группа глаголов русского языка, составляющих известное исключение из правил; ритмически организована для удобства запоминания.

The narration in the chapters concerning Yakov are characterized by their more poetic style. This narrator, for instance, frequently uses infinitives, which evoke the eternal quality and endless time of the novel's setting.
ru_trans: Для глав, касающихся Якова, характерен более поэтический стиль повествования. Например, этот автор часто использует инфинитивы, подчеркивающие эффект вечности и нескончаемости времени действия романа.

text: Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky's famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky's work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O31KPk5xnBg).
ru_trans: Такое экфрастическое название заимствовано у знаменитой фортепианной сюиты М. Мусоргского, написанной в 1874 году и состоящей из 10 пьес. Послушать запись можно [здесь](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O31KPk5xnBg). Если произведение Мусоргского сочетает в себе музыку и изобразительное искусство, в этих главах мы видим, как изобразительное искусство проникает в среду литературы.
chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

text: Bellbottoms, a style of pants popular in the 1960s. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/71/Redhead_Beach_Bell_Bottoms.jpg) Clothing motif.

An unusual surname, which does not permit standard declination. It literally means "elderly." Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak's novel *Doctor Zhivago* by means of the root "zhiv" (to live) (10). Read the original [here](http://www.vehi.net/pasternak/). Likewise, he notes, too, that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled "Notes of an Elderly Person" in his cycle of short stories, *The Tales of Belkin*. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/89/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/55219/pg55219-images.html).
Rime ice. Frozen water droplets. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/Rime_ice.jpg)
Usually "zal ozhidaniya" (waiting room, waiting hall). Here the author mixes up the station and its waiting hall (literally, "waiting station").
ru_trans: Обычно "зал ожидания". Здесь, автор путает вокзал и зал ожидания.
suffix: шибает бестактно в нос? Не сочт

text: For a detailed analysis of this chapter's opening scene and its connections to the novel's meta levels, see Mariya Donak's "Poisk bukv."

Typical sample of Sokolov's non-linear conception of time (see, for instance, R.C. Borden, Time, backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev, in CASS 21 (3-4) 1987, 247-263; School for fools, Palisandriya)
ru_trans: Классический пример нелинеарного восприятия времени (см., например, с критической точки зрения, R.C. Borden, Time, backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev, in CASS 21 (3-4) 1987, 247-263, и Школа для дураков / Палисандрия)

text: The peaked hat of a sailor. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/84/US_Navy_091007-N-8273J-012_Hats_from_representatives_of_more_than_100_nations_attending_the_19th_Biennial_International_Sea_Power_Symposium_in_Newport%2C_R.I._are_on_a_table_near_the_auditorium.jpg) Clothing motif.

Sokolov once described the process of writing *Between Dog and Wolf* as follows: "because I had little time, I wrote, primarily, poems. I couldn't write prose. It requires a long 'entrance.' It simply requires continues life, somehow constant. But you can write poets in a train, anywhere you want ... And therefore I also wrote a lot of poems for this book in Switzerland. And in Austria. In Austria I could write every evening but poems. Because when you return home from the forest at nine with axe, with a pitchfork or a saw in your hands, there's simply no talk about prose. Therefore, that's probably *Sobaka's* form is so unusual, why poems and prose are interspersed" (Polovets 8).

In the Gospels, Peter (and his brother Andrew) was invited by Jesus to become a "fisher of men." See for instance [Matthew 4:19](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%204%3A19&version=NIV).
ru_trans: В Евангелиях Петр (и его брат Андрей) призваны Иисусом быть "ловцами человеков". Например, в [Послании от Матфея 4:19](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%9E%D1%82+%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%84%D0%B5%D1%8F+4%3A19&version=RUSV).

text: Set expression: upon expiration, at the end of.

A combination of "moon" and "month." This expression hides a double meaning, as the word "mesiats" may mean both "moon" and "month" in Russian. The author is at once suggesting that "the month is clear" (a rather indeterminate time setting) and that "the moon shines".
suffix: , no catchin up with the dates,

text: That is, after death.

This word, derived from the term "porokh" (an archaic synonym for dust, powder, ashes, now more generally defined through the diminutive "poroshok"), seems to interestingly have no equivalent in other languages. See [Wikipedia](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Пороша), for instance. It indicates snow fallen during the night until morning on which fresh traces of animals are imprinted.
ru_trans: Любопытно, но у данного слова, образованного от "порох" (устаревший синоним к словам "пыль", "пепел", в настоящее время сохранивший значение в уменьшительной форме "порошок"), по всей видимости, нет эквивалента в других языках. См. [Википедию](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B0), например. Означает выпавший ночью и переставший идти к утру снег, на котором отпечатываются свежие следы животных.

text: The use of infinitives is typical of Yakov's chapters. They grant the chapters in which he features a timeless quality. On a related note, Richard Borden claims that "*Between Dog and Wolf* takes place in a circumambient projection of its author's linguistic consciousness and imagination and that claims for the existence of any more conventional setting would be misleading" ("Toward" 321).

Sparrow. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9b/House_sparrow_male_in_Prospect_Park_%2853532%29.jpg) Various traditions have depicted the sparrow as a symbol for lechery, prudence, solitude, or humankind (Rowland 157–159). Animal motif.

Sparrow Night — a short summer night with thunderstorms and lightning that frighten sparrows. The flashes of light on the dark sky are also said to resemble the birds themselves. Associated in folklore with evil spirits. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f9/Lightning_in_Volgograd_002.jpg) The first mention of Sparrow Night appears in the Primary Chronicle's account of the battle between the brothers Yaroslav the Wise and Mstislav in 1024. Read the original [here](http://www.spsl.nsc.ru/history/descr/PWL/povest3.htm) and an English translation [here](https://www.mgh-bibliothek.de/dokumente/a/a011458.pdf). Animal motif. The poem is structured as a long list of tools and animals, as if they appeared one after the other as lightning illuminated them during the night.

Cheap, poor-quality vodka. Moonshine, rotgut, raw vodka. From the Polish *siwy* (grey). Interestingly enough (but the reader is already acquainted with Ilya's style and points of reference), the metaphor is created starting from an alcoholic beverage. Alcohol theme.
ru_trans: Дешевая водка плохого качества. Тема алкоголя. Плохоочищенная, некрепкая хлебная водка. От польского *siwy* (серый). Любовытно заметить (хотя читатель уже знаком со стилем Ильи и его излюбленными объектами метафор), что метафора построена на алкогольном напитке.

text: Colloquial: smart aleck.
ru_trans: Разговорное: умник, всезнайка.

text: error: extra space here

A possible allusion to Blok's "Neznakomka" (Unknown lady) or to Ivan Kramskoi's famous painting "Neizvetstnaia" (sometimes referred to as Neznakomka; Portrait of an Unknown Woman). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Kramskoy_Portrait_of_a_Woman.jpg)
Oleg Dark calls the poems of *Between Dog and Wolf* "autocommentaries that connect a stylistically disintegrating narrative" (228).
Colloquial: to wallop, hit, hurl. Set expression: шибать в нос (to make a strong impression, to draw attention).
ru_trans: Разговорное: бить, ударять. Устойчивое выражение ("шибать в нос"): производить сильное впечатление, обращать на себя внимание.
suffix: бестактно в нос? Не сочтите за

text: Chickens. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Des_Poulets_Goliath_de_couleur_beige_dans_un_poulailler_au_B%C3%A9nin.jpg) Animal motif.

We have already encountered Yakov Il'ich in the previous chapter; his last name there however was the biblical Alfeev. Yakov's changing last names may also be "justified" by the implied semantic link between his first name and the word "yakoby", literally maybe, perhaps. This polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is him who kills Ilya in revenge.
ru_trans: Мы уже встречались с Яковом Ильичем в предыдущей главе; тот, однако, обладал библейской фамилией Алфеев. Изменяющиеся фамилии Якова можно "объяснить" семантической связью между его именем и словом "якобы", то есть, будто. Этот полиморфный герой играет центральную роль в романе, являюсь одновременно собачником, охотником, поэтом, художником и, возможно, единственным вымышленным автором целой книги. Яков играет центральную роль в структуре сюжета, ведь это он убивает Илью в порыве мести.
chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

highlighted:
Курам — ходить по песку, удивленно печатая своими курьими ножками. Не любить этих птиц, но любить наблюдать, как печатают на мокром песке, не подозревая об этом; и ни 
о чем
text:
As José Vergara writes, these chickens " resemble the novel’s heroes themselves, who write and write without ever really stopping to consider their 'prints' on the sand, surprised at
times by what comes of their reflections on the page" ("Flap" 362).
Galoshes. Shoe motif.
ru_trans: Резиновая обувь. Мотив обуви.
suffix:
в пору разлива глубоких 
и мелк

highlighted: no catchin up with the dates
text: Typical sample of Sokolov's non-linear conception of time (see, for instance, R.C. Borden, "Time, backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev," in *CASS* 21 (3-4) 1987, 247-263, *A School for Fools*, and Palisandriia. Классический пример нелинеарного восприятия времени (см., например, с критической точки зрения, R.C. Borden, Time, backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev, in CASS 21 (3-4) 1987, 247-263, и Школа для дураков / Палисандрия).
A pea jacket or sailor jacket. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/22/US_Navy_p_coat_wiki.jpg) Worn by the sailor who visits Orina in chapter 10 (R220/E123).
Boguslawski suggested that the book cointains 37 Notes as an allusion to the year of Pushkin's death, 1837 ("How Sokolov's" 207).
Translator Alexander Boguslawski has rendered the voice of Ilya in this colloquial manner to approximate the original Russian narration's style.
suffix:
up with the dates, the 
year’s

text: In ancient Russia, a *sloboda* referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, *sloboda* refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a [Sloboda](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sloboda,+Tver+Oblast,+Russia,+171265/@56.6543229,36.4671174,12.92z/data=!4m6!3m5!1s0x46b4337b61338bc3:0xfd78ee1285635920!8m2!3d56.6502347!4d36.4718922!16s%2Fg%2F12xpjjzgs?entry=ttu) can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова "свобода". Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, "слобода" в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

text: The blue time — twilight. Between dog and wolf.
suffix: , прохлаждаемся кое с кем на пор

text: This expression introduces the reader into a blurred atmosphere of uncertainty, where exact coordinates in space and time are deliberately foggy.
ru_trans: Данное выражение вводит читателя в мутную атмосферу неопределенности: пространственно-временные представления являются нарочито туманными.
prefix: ц ясен, за числами не уследишь,

text: A word (verb, adjective) used repeatedly with connection to Yakov. See R163/E25, R189/70, R197/E86, R274/E219, and R277/E223.
A French port city and major producer of wine. Alcohol theme.
ru_trans: Французский портовый город и крупный производитель вина. Тема алкоголя.
suffix:
цыганок,
  Что давят шато и де-

text: Ostanin (43) suggests to interpret his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). He also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality. Останин предлагает интерпретировать эту фамилию как вариацию "Паломахеров" (от глагола "палить"), что характеризует разжигающего (или тушащего) огонь человека. На этой ноте, стоит вспомнить завершающие строки романа: "Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки" (R280/E230). Останин также замечает, что фамилия, возможно, берет начало от Григория Паламы, греческого православного богослова XIV века, известного обоснованием духовной практики исихаизма (Ostanin 43).

Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f9/Lightning_in_Volgograd_002.jpg) The first mention of Sparrow Night appears in the Primary Chronicle's account of the battle between the brothers Yaroslav the Wise and Mstislav in 1024. suffix: Увы нам, наш климат для нас

text:
Allusion to the author bio and to the situation many authors were facing in the '80. It is also relevant that Sokolov uses the word 'priyateli' (echoed also in the adj. druzheskij in the reference from the Evgeny Onegin): in dispersion people who belongs to the other (non official / 'second') culture can re-build the links among them.
отсылка к третьей волны русской эмиграции. Важно также что Соколов использует слово "приятели", как будьто именно в рассеянии заново создаются связи, основанные на то, что все эти люди принадлежают к другой ("второй") культуре
A continuation of the temporal setting: spring.

Coming out of chapter 5's Gogolian parody, it is no surprise that chapter 6 begins with a nose. Read Gogol's "The Nose" [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/76/p.1/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gla.ac.uk/0t4/crcees/files/summerschool/readings/Gogol_TheNose.pdf).
ru_trans: После гоголевской пародии в главе 5, начало шестой главы с разговора о носе не становится сюрпризом. Прочитать "Нос" Гоголя в оригинале можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/76/p.1/index.html), а в английском переводе — [здесь](https://www.gla.ac.uk/0t4/crcees/files/summerschool/readings/Gogol_TheNose.pdf).

text: error: extra space here
prefix: манка с  крабом, бушлат в  якоря

text:
Interestingly enough, Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative "Tovarishch" opting for a rather general, but still evocative word (think of Nikolay Nekrasov's "Poet i grazhdanin," Poet and Citizen, 1856). I can be wrong, but I think this is also related to the epistolary genre Ilya is here trying to reproduce and to the fact that his world is rather the 'old' one than the soviet one
Наверное это тоже зависит оттого, что Илья хочет "правильно" писать заявление и думает выражениями, типичными для "старого" (несоветского или, лучше, досоветского) времени
ru_trans: Интересно заметить, что Соколов избегает употреблять советское слово "товарищ", предпочитая ему более общий, зато значимый термин "гражданин" (ср. "Поэт и гражданин" Николая Некрасова, 1856).

text: Set expression: "please, don't take this as..."
ru_trans: Устойчивое выражение: не поймите неправильно.

text: An island region of Italy. The largest Mediterranean island. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a0/Sicily_Map.png)

The adjectival form of this word (рассеянный) can mean absend-minded or forgetful. In many ways, *Between Dog and Wolf* is an attempt by Ilya, one of the protagonists, to remember his life, despite the fact that multiple variants are presented in the narrative.
A music-playing machine that reproduces an orchestra or band. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e1/1918_Seeburg_Orchestrion.jpg)
Colloquial: rotten stuff.
ru_trans: Разговорное: что-то гнилое, испорченное.

text: Sidor (shortened form of Isidor), son of Foma. Here the declension of the name is incorrect (should be in the dative case, Sidoru). In colloquial language, the names are sometimes declined incorrectly for easier pronunciation: Сан Санычу (San Sanychu), Михал Валерьичу (Mikhal Valer'ichu), etc. The name Isidor (or Sidor) originally means "son or gift of Isis," the major goddess in ancient Egyptian religion, an ideal of femininity and motherhood who was also believed to help the dead enter the afterlife.
ru_trans: Сидор (сокращенная форма имени Исидор), сын Фомы. Здесь ошибка в склонении имени: правильная форма — Сидору (дательный падеж). В разговорной речи, имена иногда склоняются не совсем верно для более удобного произношения: Сан Санычу, Михал Валерьичу, и т. п. Имя Исидор (или Сидор) означает "сын или дар Исиды", одной из главных богинь в древнеегипетской мифологии, идеала женственности и материнства, которая покровительствовала мертвым в загробной жизни.

text: These gypsy women press grapes while dancing in order to make wine.
ru_trans: Цыганские женщины, танцуя, давят виноград для производства вина.
suffix:
шато и де-кот
  Под вальсы волш

text: Dated: merchant, tradesman, negotiator. It could also be an "italianism" (as *negozianti* in Italian means shopkeepers, sellers, vendors).
That is, Orina and her multiple hypostases.

, и отрава едва не придушила

text: French: chateau (castle or house). A high-quality wine produced at a chateau. May refer to the label of such a bottle. Alcohol theme.
ru_trans: Французское: chateau (замок, усадьба, дом). Высококачественное вино, произведенное в шато. Может относиться к марке такого вина. Тема алкоголя.

text: A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.

The chapter continues the stroll through the exhibition started in chapter 2. This may be Karl Bryullov's "Self-portrait" (1813), a painting first mentioned on R163/E24 and pictured here: ![](https://i5.walmartimages.com/asr/d8bbc347-c80f-4ffa-bda2-243140f2372c_1.9b8b7b88c27ade69b75f55104b2261e6.jpeg?odnHeight=612&odnWidth=612&odnBg=FFFFFF)

Эта глава продолжает экскурсию по выставке, начатую в главе 2. Здесь, возможно, указывается на "Автопортрет" К. Брюллова (1813), изображено ниже: ![](https://i5.walmartimages.com/asr/d8bbc347-c80f-4ffa-bda2-243140f2372c_1.9b8b7b88c27ade69b75f55104b2261e6.jpeg?odnHeight=612&odnWidth=612&odnBg=FFFFFF)

text: Patronymic: son of Ilya. Yakov may, indeed, be Ilya's son.

An unusual surname, which does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak's novel *Doctor Zhivago *by means of the root "zhiv" (to live) (10). Read the original [here](http://www.vehi.net/pasternak/). Likewise, he notes, too, that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled "Notes of an Elderly Person" in his cycle of short stories, *The Tales of Belkin*. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/89/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/55219/pg55219-images.html).

text: Ostanin (43) suggests interpretинг his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are, "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). Ostanin also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

prefix:
а глубоких 
и мелких рек. Быть;

text: Sokolov comments: "You may have noticed that cats, while strolling in the garden or in the woods, find some nice-tasting grasses and chew them. Specialists say that cats do this instinctively: those grasses are healing. Humans, though perhaps not all, have the same instinct. In our childhood and adolescence, it is evident. Once in nature, a child strives to pick up a leaf of grass or a tree and chew it, this action is involuntary. In adolescence and later we do it less often, but we cannot completely get rid of the habit of chewing something. If there is no plant at hand, we chew a pencil, a paintbrush, a pen. This helps creativity, becomes an integral part of it. Chewing or munching something, we involuntarily masticate, i.e. salivate this object. Alas, it is not quite aesthetic, but we cannot change this state of affairs. The phrase 'to soil the dark-green leaf' contains no hint of something more complicated; it is merely a glimpse, a small aspect of a specific past" (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: Соколов комментирует: "Возможно, вы замечали, что кошки, гуляя в саду или в лесу, находят какие-то приятные на вкус травинки и жуют их. Специалисты говорят, что кошки поступают так инстинктивно: те травинки целебны. Людям, пусть, может быть, и не всем, присущ тот же инстинкт. В нашем детстве и отрочестве он проявляется со всей очевидностью. Оказавшись на природе, ребенок норовит сорвать лист травы или дерева и пожевать его, это действие безотчетно. В юности и позже мы делаем это реже, но полностью изжить в себе привычку что-нибудь пожевать не удается. Если под рукой нет растения, грызем карандаш, кисть, перо. Это помогает творчеству,  становится его неотъемлемой частью. Грызя или жуя что-либо, мы невольно мусолим, то есть слюнявим данный предмет. Увы, это не вполне эстетично, но изменить такое вот положение дел мы не в силах. Фраза 'мусолить жирно-зеленый лист' не содержит намека на нечто более сложное, это просто промельк, малый аспект конкретного прошлого" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).
prefix:
а глубоких 
и мелких рек. Быть;
suffix: . Жить, быть и видеть, как по ка

text: E. Iablokov suggests that the connection to Cinderella in Ilya's surname, as well as his social status, mark his as a typical "little person" (маленький человек) of Russian literature (205). In particular, he mentions the hero of Fyodor Dostoevsky's epistolary novel *Poor Folk*, Makar Devushkin.

Instead of "lapki" (the usual word defining chicken feet), the author antropomorphizes chickens. Animal motif. Moreover, chicken's feet are related to the traditional fairy tale of Baba-Yaga and her chicken-legged hut.
suffix: . Не любить этих птиц, но любить

text: Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative "comrade" opting for a rather general, but still evocative word: "citizen" (grazhdanin). This word evokes the poem "Poet and Citizen" by the 19th-c Nikolai Nekrasov.
A ballroom dance in 3/4 time. From the German *Walzer* (to roll or revolve). Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Phenakistoscope_3g07690d.gif)

text: The word "besprizornyj/besprizornik" appeared in the Soviet era, and according to the [National corpus of the Russian language](https://processing.ruscorpora.ru/graphic.xml?graphic_from_result=1&lang=ru&mode=main&nodia=1&req=беспризорный&smoothing=3&sort=i_grstd&text=lexform#toggle), it was typical in print in particular between 1920s-1940s. Literally meaning "unsupervised", it was usually used to refer to homeless children, orphans. Boris Zhitkov, author of children's books (1882-1938), wrote a short story titled "Besprizornaya koshka" (Unsupervised cat), published in his volume *Rasskazy o zhivotnykh* (Short Stories about Animals), 1935.
ru_trans: Слово "беспризорный/беспризорник" появилось в советскую эпоху, и, согласно [Национальному корпусу русского языка](https://processing.ruscorpora.ru/graphic.xml?graphic_from_result=1&lang=ru&mode=main&nodia=1&req=%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9&smoothing=3&sort=i_grstd&text=lexform#toggle), было особенно распространено в печати между 1920-ми и 1940-ми годами. Буквально означая "без присмотра", слово обычно использовалось для описания бездомных детей, сирот. Борис Житков, автор детских книг (1882-1938), написал рассказ "Беспризорная кошка", который был опубликован в его сборнике "Рассказы о животных" (1935).

text: Such a name is resonant with two famous poetic "albatrosses": Baudelaire's (read it [here](https://fleursdumal.org/poem/200)) and Coleridge's from *The Rime of the Ancient Mariner* (read it [here](https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/43997/the-rime-of-the-ancient-mariner-text-of-1834)). The opening of this chapter draws a direct continuation with the ending of ch. 12 (also by using the same words: "матрос Альбатросов, и списан вчистую").

Again an unusual last name (which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book). It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker's essay, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). However, as Korovashko suggests, "Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella 'squared': if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence" (277).
ru_trans: Еще одна необычная фамилия (которая встречается и в других графических-орфографических вариантов дальше в тексте). Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). Однако, Коровашко замечает, что "Илья Петрикеич становится как бы Золушкой «в квадрате»: если последняя потеряла всего лишь свой башмачок, то он утратил и ногу, и компенсирующие ее отсутствие костыли" (277).

text: Here, the accordion, but, generally, a barrel organ, roller organ, or crank organ. Originally from France, it's name is derived from "Charmante Catherine," one of the first songs played on the instrument. Unlike an organ (or an accordion), it is played by turning a crank. Thus, the musician is known as an organ grinder. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/Austrian_BarrelOrgan.jpg)
ru_trans: Здесь имеется в виду, гармонь, но в общем смысле слова относится к переносному механическому органу. Созданный во Франции, инструмент получил свое название от "Charmante Catherine", одной из первых песен, исполненных на этом инструменте. В отличие от органа или гармони, звук создается путем вращения ручки. Музыкант, играющий на этом инструменте, называется шарманщик. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/Austrian_BarrelOrgan.jpg)

text: Set expression: с корабля на бал (to dash from one place to another, a sudden shift in conditions). Beside the specific use of this set expression in this sea scene, it is also worth noting that this character dashes from his sailor world (sukhogruz) to mainland life (sukhoputnaia uchast') through linguistic play.

text: A Russian carriage with a long frame and no spring. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/47/Tarantass.jpg) Curiously, the word is spelled in Latin letters. Since the origin of the word "tarantas" is unknown, the author could be again playing on a fake "italianism" and/or recall the Italian city of Taranto (which is located in the south of Italy, yet not in Sicily). Ostanin suggests a connection to Vladimir Sollogub's 1840 novella *[Tarantas](http://az.lib.ru/s/sollogub_w_a/text_0040.shtml)*.

The contents of Ilya's letters concern the events related to his life and death that occur "beyond the Itil River." In this way, the story Ilya tells Pozhilykh becomes a real epic poem.

highlighted: проступают через туманы, из-за реки, пресловутые присной памяти
text: The dead rise out of the river (of death, of oblivion). Writing about Sokolov's essay "On Secret Tablets," D. Barton Johnson describes how "Sokolov recounts a strange conversation a with drunken, illiterate old hunter on the Volga, the prototype for Krylobyl [...] The old man counsels Sasha — 'Don't go to America, San'ka.' The idea had never been mentioned, nor had Sokolov even remotely considered it. The novel, finished in America, details, in passing, the bizarre deaths of most of its characters. Shortly before its publication, Sokolov received a letter from the Volga village where he had lived. Many of the novel's prototypes had died their fictional deaths. They had predicted his fate (America); he had predicted theirs" ("Sasha Sokolov's Major Essays" 234). Read the essay [here](https://philologist.livejournal.com/10961052.html).

Having clubfoot. We should here remember Sophocle's *Oedipus*, who had a swollen foot. Several authors have underlined the parallels existing between Sokolov's novel(s) and the story of Oedipus. Olga Matich, for example, writes: "Written in a language that is self-consciously apolitical and un-Soviet, it is a surreal tale of violence and death based on the reenactment of the Oedipus myth" ("Sasha Sokolov's Palisandriia" 416). D.B. Johnson also notes: "Sokolov's three novels are linked by an evolving Oedipal theme. The Oedipal image is latent in *School for Fools*. The boy, who hates his prosecutor father, apparently does not understand why his 'kindly, patient' mother disappears upstairs with the accordion teacher during his lessons. That he is unconsciously jealous of his mother's infidelity is suggested by the skirly-squeaking of the stair- case and the squealing of his accordion. Oedipal incest is somewhat more overt in *Dog and Wolf* thanks to a complex set of superimposed figures from different time dimensions: the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the iden- tity of either. The incest theme comes to the fore in Palisandr. The hero's memory is haunted by incestuous sexual violence. In an incarnation centuries before, Palisandr, a motherless orphan, had been brutally corrupted by his maternal aunt, Majorette, his father's mistress. This experience has been stamped into his sexual memory and is relived in variant form in subsequent incarnations. Incest is the Original Sin that colors his sexual behavior in all possible pasts, presents, and futures" ("Sasha Sokolov's Twilight Cosmos" 644). However, Johnson also adds that in a conversation with Sokolov, the author admitted that "although he did not initially have the Oedipus parallel in mind, it struck him during and after the writing" ("The Galoshes" 165).

Again, between dog and wolf. In the world of the novel, twilight/dusk is ever-present (extends, continues), leading to all sorts of confusion. Normally, the word сумерки (twilight) is never used in the singular.
ru_trans: Вновь, между собакой и волком. В мире романа, сумерки вездесущи и приводят к разного рода путаницам. Обычно слово "сумерки" не употребляется в единственном числе.

The frequent use of the verb gulyat' is linked to the fact that here in chapter 10 Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person," and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

Dwelling, but also the term used to describe a place where hunting animals are fed. Animal-human motif. Sokolov adds that it's a "document according to which payment for an apartment and amenities was made" ("Bol'shoe" 134).
prefix: уляй не хочу. Прежде эта бабуля

text: The title that Ilya gives to his missive to Pozhilykh. Its name echoes that of the Zadonschina, a Russian manuscript of late 14th century, about the Battle of Kulikovo (1380) between Russians and Mongols. The contents of Ilya's letters concern the events related to his life and death that occur "beyond the Itil River." In this way, the story Ilya tells Pozhilykh becomes a real epic poem.

A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.

highlighted: по мере змеенья зимы меняться оттенкам ее слюдяных чешуйчатых крыльев
text: Sokolov comments: "Winter, with its snowstorms and blizzards, surprised me with its snaky habits from an early age. And not only me. See for example the beginning of a [famous poem](https://www.culture.ru/poems/12399/kakaya-grust-konec-allei) by Fet. If winter snakes and has wings, then it is nothing else but a flying kite, and those wings only appear to be made of mica, in fact they are made of ice" (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: Соколов комментирует: "Зима с ее поземками и вьюгами сызмала удивляла меня своими змеиными повадками. И не только меня. Вот начало знаменитого стихотворения Фета: "Какая грусть! Конец аллеи / Опять с утра исчез в пыли, / Опять серебряные змеи / Через сугробы поползли". Если зима змеится и у нее есть крылья, значит она не что иное, как летучий змей, причем эти крылья лишь кажутся слюдяными, на самом деле они ледяные" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

А.С. Пушкин, Евгений Онегин, гл. 4, XLVII
A.S. Pushkin, Evgeny Onegin, chapter 4, XLVII

Sokolov on Pushkin: "Pushkin is dear to me above all as a person. And in that quality he's close. And, I would guess, not only to me. Thanks to that, his entire epoch is entirely an accessible, open book. It seems to me that, despite all the tragedies that have befallen Russian culture, the divide between Pushkin's time and ours is practically nonexistent. At the very least in the creative sense" (Matich, "Nuzhno zabyt'" 12).

text:
Sokolov himself spent the period between May 1972 and November 1973 at the hunting estate located near Bezborodovo in the Kalinin oblast (today Tver') by the Volga river. These months constitute one of the most significant periods in the writer’s life. In Bezborodovo, Sokolov not only wrote his first novel, but collected material that would become fundamental for his later work. Bezborodovo and the adjacent villages along the Volga river constitute a highly mythopoeic place in Sokolov’s mental map. These landscapes did not disappear from the writer’s memories even after emigrating: when later on, in Vienna, at the Kunsthistorisches Museum Sokolov found himself admiring some paintings by Bruegel the Elder, he was surprised to find such strong similarities with the hunting estate where he had lived two years earlier.
In 1982, Sokolov devoted a section of his essay "Na sokrovennykh skryzhaliakh" (On Secret Tablets) to Bezborodovo: "Strange, mysterious, and tragic events occurred in that indigent place, where, besides me, Chaikovskii, Prishvin, and Rilke with his Russian translator Drozhzhin used to find peace and freedom, but where a man’s soul is not worth much more than a pair of boots. There the Volga, otherwise known as the Lethe, flows until it runs into the Turkish sea of oblivion. Enjoying tea made with its water and learning what is going on around its banks, you become forever privy to the inexplicable and unfamiliar—in the river itself and in the fates of those doomed to be with her."
In Bezborodovo Sasha Sokolov had time to observe, listen, create, and write. *Between Dog and Wolf*, which recovers many images and voices ‘recorded’ by Sokolov during his period spent on the Volga and left to settle over time, would appear only later on. See also Napolitano's monograph (2022), in particular chapter 1.

Emery, or corundite, is a dark granular rock used to make abrasive powder. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Corundite_%28emery_rock%29_slabbed_Naxos_Emery_Deposits.jpg)

Colloquial: fatigue, tiredness, weariness (same as усталость). Ostanin suggests this is a reference to Vladimir Vysotsky's 1971 song "Police Protocol": "Я пил из горлышка, с устатку и не евши" ("You bet: I drank from the bottle, hadn’t eaten, was too tired") (49). Прочитать оригинал и английский перевод слов можно [здесь](https://wysotsky.com/1033.htm?1968). Послушать песню можно [здесь](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bupKLAFfAOA).

text:
Double meaning, very relevant from a thematic point of view for the plot: ochota = 1. hunting / 2. desire
двойное значение, тематически очень важно: 1. охота на зверей, 2. охота как желаниеElena Kravchenko also writes, "The unsettling feeling, triggered by the man's intense gaze, overly articulate speech, and lapses into occasional withdrawals, is explained next day. He is deaf, and in order to hear and therefore speak, he needs to see and read the lips of his collocutor. By virtue of his link with Pasternak's hunter, Iakov can be associated with the visual aspect of language. It is also reflected in his artistic aspirations,
manifested in the 'picture gallery' of the prose section" (*Reflections* 81).It is also interesting to notice that in Pasternak's novel 
this “young man” is the interlocutor with whom Zhivago converses while on the train: "Once in the dark of the night, the interlocutor turns out to be deaf and, therefore, capable of sustaining a conversation solely by lip reading. This pivotal sequence in Pasternak’s novel unravels the theme of incommunicability, a topic that is of great interest to Sokolov too. By evoking the idea of the power of language and of its sound, which not everyone is capable of hearing, Sokolov once again stresses the redeeming sacredness of the word. After all, this seemingly epistolary second novel by Sokolov presents itself as a letter addressed to detective Pozhilykh by Ilya Zynzyrela (later discovered to be dead), in which the sender seeks justice for a wrongdoing. Thus, the writing offers a refuge and a redemption from (linear) time and death." (Napolitano 2022: 88).
Yakov.

text: Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov's art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).  Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

The expression "kazyonnaia izba" (the 'treasury' izba) is attested since 1578. It indicates a place where local inhabitants went to pay taxes under the Tsars' rule. The adjective "kazyonny" however could be here intended as both meaning "governmental, belonging to the State," or as "ordinary, commonplace."
Colloquial: accidentally, by chance, in passing, accidentally.

A Tatar — a person from Tatarstan (now the Republic of Tatarstan), a speaker of a Tatar language. The Tatar Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic was forcibly established in 1920 and lasted throughout the Soviet period.
Boguslawski notes that this expression is derived from Tacitus's *Annals*. It gained popularity in Russia thanks to Marie-Joseph de Chénier's *Tibre* (Tiber) (1819) ("Annotations" 246).

text: An allusion to Alexander Radishchev's *Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow* (1790), in particular its epigraph, which was taken from Vasilii Trediakovsky's "Telemakhida" (1766): "чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй" ("a beast who is enormous, disgusting, a-hundred-maws and barking"). Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1850/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://archive.org/details/journeyfromstpet0000radi). Similar wording is used on the following page: "преогромна волчица" ("huge she-wolf"). In chapter 4, Ilya describes his homeland in these terms (cunning, deceptive, rich yet poor at first sight): "Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. Вроде — мать, но хитра поразительно, охмуряет. Поначалу все кажется — земля как земля, только бедная, нету в ней ничего. Но обживешься, присмотришься — все в ней есть, кроме валенок" (R179/E52-53). Animal motif.
ru_trans: Отсылка к "Путешествию из Петербурга в Москву" А. Радищева (1790), в частности, к эпиграфу, взятому из "Техемахиды" В. Тредияковского (1766): "чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй". Прочитать произведение можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/1850/index.html), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://archive.org/details/journeyfromstpet0000radi). Похожая формулировка употреблена на следующей странице: "преогромна волчица". В главе 4, Илья описывает родину так: "Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. Вроде — мать, но хитра поразительно, охмуряет. Поначалу все кажется — земля как земля, только бедная, нету в ней ничего. Но обживешься, присмотришься — все в ней есть, кроме валенок" (R179/E52-53). Мотив животных.

text: A variation on Krylobyl's name. Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. According to Mario Caramitti, the character of Krylobyl is but an "hypostasis" of Drozhzhin, as he is here described dwelling by the Volga ("Strategie" 131). Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: So, it must be in the early morning, before dawn, walking on fresh snow fallen during the night.

highlighted: Что есть счастье и что есть несчастие
text: An echo from chapter 4: "Ведь что такое несчастье и что такое счастие, когда задаться на миг? Несчастие — это если нет счастия, а счастие, Оря, это если несчастия нет". The answer in this case is semantically the same, yet syntactically put in a different way: "happiness is when there is happiness".
ru_trans: Отголосок главы 4: "Ведь что такое несчастье и что такое счастие, когда задаться на миг? Несчастие — это если нет счастия, а счастие, Оря, это если несчастия нет". В этом случае, ответ семантически остается прежним, но сформулирован по-другому: "счастье — это когда есть счастье".
suffix: , милый Вы мой? Не пасуйте, отве

text: Another name given to Orina, the central female figure in the novel. In the chapters devoted to Yakov, she becomes his mother, thus the characters enact a variation on the Oedipal myth. Hanna Kolb writes: "She is a *Rossiia-mater'* (little mother Russia) (65) in eighteenth-century language [...] She is the Volga, the wolf-river which gives them crayfish to eat and water to drink, a stone under their heads, but also a stone around their necks. In each of the only two women's names that occur in the text, Orina and Mariia, may be heard "*rodina*" (native land), as well as "*mat'* (mother). Mariia is Iyakov's mother and the mother of God, about whom Il'a [sic] speaks in his Christmas sermon [...], both a mother goddess and the Mother of God. The lover Orina is raised in the figure of the Lady to sainthood, to the role of Blok's simultaneously life-giving [...] and death-giving "*neponiatnaia neznakomka*" (115)" (204).
ru_trans: Еще одно имя, присвоенное Орине, центральной женской фигуре романа. В главах, посвященных Якову, она становится его матерью, участвуя, таким образом, в воспроизведении героями мифа о Эдипе. Х. Кольб пишет: “Она — *Россия-матерь* (65) в языке XVIII века [...] Она — Волга, волчья река, которая дает им речных раков в пищу и воду для утоления жажды, камень под их головой, но также и камень у них на шее. В каждом из единственных двух женских имен в тексте, Орина и Мария могут читаться как “*родина*” или “*мать*”. Мария — мать Якова, а также матерь Божья, о которой Илья говорит в своей воскресной проповеди […], богиня материнства и Божья Матерь. Любовница Орина причисляется в образе Дамы к лику святых, к блоковской роли дарящей жизнь […] и смерть “*непонятной незнакомке*” (115)” (Kolb 204).
suffix: — трубить в пастуший рожок на ж

text: Ostanin (43) suggests interpretинг his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are, "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). Ostanin also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

Прочитать оригинал можно [здесь](http://az.lib.ru/l/leskow_n_s/text_0246.shtml), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://archive.org/details/steelflea00hapggoog/mode/2up).
