text: The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov's poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg) José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. "He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family," Vergara continues, "but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" ("Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.

text: Usually, the word "matata" is used only in the idiom "navodit'/navesti [razvodit'] matatu": talk nonsense, mislead someone. Thanks to the presence of the verb "izvedat'" it is possible to understand that in this word converge both the meaning of the word 'matata', and the one of 'mutota' (slang), that is nonsense, rubbish.
ru_trans: Обычно, слово "матата" находится только в фразеологизме "наводить/Навести [разводить] матату" = говорить ерунду, вводить в заблуждение кого-либо. От того, что здесь есть глаголь "изведать" понимаем что, на семантику "мататы" добавилась семантика жаргонного слова "мутота" = чушь, дрянь.

text: Much in the chapters devoted to Yakov, his life, and his thoughts consists of ekphrasis—the literary device of describing in words a visual work of art—and other combinations of different genres and media. Here, for instance, the reader is asked to imagine the events of the chapter coming to life as if being painted before their eyes.
ru_trans: Значительную часть глав, касающихся Якова, его жизни и мыслей, составляет эксфразис — описание произведения искусства литературном тексте — и другие сочетания жанров и сфер. Здесь, например, читателю предлагается представить события главы как если бы они были нарисованы у него перед глазами.

text: This event is later recounted in chapter 14 by Ilya, but there *he* is the furrier under the stairs (R255/E187). D. Barton Johnson summarizes: "Orina's story has strange echoes in Il'ya's later life. After parting from Orina, Il'ya sets himself up as a fur-dresser/cobbler [...] Living in a room beneath the stairs, he befriends an old woman rag-picker and her mentally retarded ward whom he seduces when she brings him an animal hide. Their assignations take place in his room and under a beached boat, but the relationship ends when the pregnant girl takes up with the local sailors [...] The fox-fur slippers made for Orina by her cobbler-seducer foreshadow the unknown article made by cobbler Il'ya for the slow-witted girl who is Orina's successor" ("The Galoshes Manifesto" 153–164). Olga Matich reads Sokolov's novel as an extended response to Boris Pilnyak's short story "Mother Earth" (1927), as it shares confusion between a wolf and a fox, a character name Arina, and a setting on the Upper Volga, among other similarities ("Sasha Sokolov" 312–313). Read the original [here](http://az.lib.ru/p/pilxnjak_b_a/text_1924_mat_syra_zemlya.shtml).

text: Many of the characters are displaced from their homes, often more than once. They feel out of place in this area despite their community and their work. On one level, this theme speaks to Sokolov's own self-exile when he took up a job as a game warden in the Upper Volga region and subsequently his exile from Soviet Russia. The novel is dedicated to "приятелям по рассеянью" — comrades in exile.
ru_trans: Множество героев вынуждены покинуть дом, зачастую, не один раз. Несмотря на общину и совместную работу, они чувствуют себя в этом месте чужими. С какой-то стороны, тема изгнания героев созвучна с самоизгнанием самого Соколова, когда он принял должность егеря в Верхневолжье, а позже — его изгнанием из Советской России. Роман также посвящен "приятелям по рассеянью".

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
ru_trans: Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов "город" и "нищий". Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: "Если *Школа для дураков* была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, *Между собакой и волком* можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых" (Matich "Sasha Sokolov" 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid "Zaitil'shchina" 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson "Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

text: A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg). Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 9 (R214/E112), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). text: This poem consists of a series of epitaphs, or short statements on the deceased, for a number of characters from the novel. The implication, of course, is that on one level all these characters are and have been dead. This poem recalls Edgar Lee Masters's *Spoon River Anthology* (1915), a collection of poems that tells the stories of a large collection of fictional characters through their epitaphs. Read it [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/1280/pg1280-images.html).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
High-style: poverty of intellect.
prefix: рекает, стыдя: игры ты над моим

text: According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.
ru_trans: Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, "зимарь" — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского "Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры" (1963) ("Аннотации" 233). Образовано сочетанием слов "зима" и "январь", подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.

text: Cuckoo. The cuckoo is said to predict death, hence why below the poet asks, "Who is she calling?" Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4f/Kuckuck_%28Cuculus_canorus%29_by_Tim_Peukert.jpg) Animal motif.
Bird migration. Bird motif.

This phrase refers to Peter the Great's plans and actions to open Russia to a lengthy series of reforms built on western trends. According to Boguslawski's annotation, a paraphrase "of the expression 'to open a window into Europe'" ("Annotations" 244). Ostanin also suggests that this line calls to mind the sun's setting (58). Curiously, according to this interpretation, Russia/Peter I/Petersburg (which opened a window into Europe) are symbolized by the "bakhroma": rags of a worn-out dawn.
ru_trans: Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, перефразировка "фразы 'прорубить окно в Европу'" (Boguslawski, "Annotations" 244). Эта фраза к планам и действиям Петра Первого, направленным на то, чтобы подготовить Россию к продолжительному циклу реформ, основанных на западных тенденциях. Останин также предполагает, что эта фраза напоминает о закате солнца (Ostanin 58).

text: The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov's poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg) José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. "He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family," Vergara continues, "but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" ("Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.
ru_trans:
Удод несколько раз упоминается в романе, в основном, в стихах Якова: (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg)

A Ukrainian stringed folk instrument similar to the zither and lute. Also known as the kobza. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/59/Chernihiv-style_bandura.jpg) As Boguslawski notes, the word can be used to "denote any kind of a musical instrument" (Boguslawski, "Annotations" 242). Here, then, it represents the accordion that Ilya is discussing.

Как отмечает Богуславский, слово может использоваться "для описанию любого музыкального инструмента" (Boguslawski, "Annotations" 242). Здесь относится к гармони, которую описывает Илья.

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter 4 it is Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it is Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

text: A quotation from Lermontov's *A Hero of Our Time*: "Если б у меня был табун в тысячу кобыл, - сказал Азамат, - то отдал бы тебе весь за твоего Карагеза" (**CITATION NEEDED**). In the chapter "Bela", the titular character's brother, Azamat, offers his sister in exchange for Kazbich's famed horse, Karagez, whom he praises in this way. When he declines, Azamat conspires with the novel's protagonist, Grigory Pechorin, to steal the horse, resulting in Bela's eventual murder at the hands of Kazbich. Sokolov said the following of *Hero of Our Time*: "*Geroi nashego vremeni* [A hero of our time] is, arguably, the finest Russian nineteenth-century prose. That's the point from which it all began. It is prose that cares about how it is made. It is self-conscious and self-reflexive. It admires itself; it knows what it does and how. It bewitches any reader ready to appreciate it" (Podshivalov, "A Conversation" 353).
ru_trans: Цитата из "Героя нашего времени" Лермонтова: "Если б у меня был табун в тысячу кобыл, - сказал Азамат, - то отдал бы тебе весь за твоего Карагеза". В главе "Бэла", брат одноименной героини Азамат предлагает Казбичу свою сестру в обмен на пресловутого жеребца Карагеза. Когда тот отказывается, Азамат сговаривается с героем романа, Григорием Печориным, украсть лошадь, что приводит к гибели Бэлы от рук Казбича. Соколов сказал следующее о *Герое нашего времени*: "*Герой нашего времени* является, пожалуй, величайшим произведением русской прозы девятнадцатого века.  Это — отправная точка, с которой все началось. Эта проза, которая заботится о том, как она сотворена. Она самосознательная и самоотражающая. Она восхищается собой; она знает, что делает, и как она это делает. Она завораживает любого, кто готов ценить ее" (Podshivalov, "A Conversation" 353).

text: The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov's poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg) José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. "He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family," Vergara continues, "but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" ("Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.
ru_trans:
Удод несколько раз упоминается в романе, в основном, в стихах Якова: (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg)

text: According to Ptolemy, the Greek-Egyptian astronomer of the Ancient Roman Empire (2th century BC), the universe had the Earth at its center, while the Sun and the Moon, as well as all stars and planets orbited our planet (geocentric model). From the late 16th century onward, this model was gradually superseded by the heliocentric model developed by Copernicus (1473–1543), Galileo (1564–1642), and Kepler (1571–1630).
ru_trans: Согласно Птолемею, греко-египетскому астроному Древнеримской империи (II век до н.э.), Земля была центром Вселенной, а Солнце, Луна и другие звезды и планеты вращались вокруг нее (геоцентрическая модель). С XVI века эта модель была постепенно вытеснена гелиоцентической моделью, разработаной Коперником (1473–1543), Галилеем (1564–1642), и Кеплером (1571–1630).

text: Patronymic, son of Dorofei. Dorofei is a name of Greek origin, literally meaning "gift of God". It isn't much used in the Russian area, except for the monastic, sacred context. The Ptolemaic model (suggested by the name of this character) was adopted by the Christian church, as it suited well its model of world. Any other interpretation was persecuted (Galileo's case is telling in this regard).
ru_trans: Отчество: сын Дорофея. Дорофей — имя греческого происхождения, буквально означающее "Божий дар". Оно почти не употребляется в русскоговорящих регионах, кроме как в священном контексте (в монастырях). Модель Птолемея (на что указывает имя героя) была принята христианской церковью, так как она хорошо соответствовала церковной модели мира. Все остальные интерпретации были преследуемы и наказуемы (показательный пример — случай с Галилеем).

text: As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps?output=search&q=bydgoszcz&entry=mc&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj4_sT8sbb_AhUaGVkFHWvIBHAQ0pQJegQICxAB) (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).

Ilya frequently refers to himself in the third person.
ru_trans: Илья часто обращается к себе в третьем лице.

text: A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.

а воду обычную. А давай. И останови впечатление, тормошит, в заводи она практически не идет, ее ряска душит, трава, а на стрежне —

что кража, которой ты — жертва, случилась пока что лишь в нашем 
любимом городе, и больше нигде, и на той стороне о ней и не слыхивали. Стоит, значит, тебе туда переехать — все ходом и образуется.
text: A central passage in the novel. Krylobyl suggests that time functions differently depending on one's location or perspective. Just as a river flows at different speeds, so does time move differently. In the backwoods, where not much happens, time moves slowly. In the city, where there is action and hustle and bustle, time moves quickly. Thus, if Ilya were to move to the other side of the river, he would be able to recover his crutches, where their theft, allegedly, hasn't yet occurred. This view of time serves as one explanation for the various contradictions in the novel. For a consideration of Sokolov's atypical approach to time in his novels, see Boguslawskii 1989.
prefix: ебе мое слово: ну не настаиваю.

text: A variation of the set expression "vlezt' v shkuru" (get under the skin), meaning "to put oneself into one's shoes". Literally, the word "shkura" refers to animal skin, and it anticipates the role that fox fur will play later on in the novel. Animal motif. As Johnson notes, Ilya Zynzyrella, evoking "Cinderella of vair (or verre) slipper fame" is indeed "a male Cinderella [who] makes fur slippers for his beloved who (posthumously) seeks to be reunited with him." He adds: "If the fur slippers are central to the intergrading of Orina and the mentally defective girls, valenki 'felt boots' strongly hint at the relationship between Il'ya and Yakov. It is here that we find echoes of the Oedipus legend" ("The Galoshes Manifesto" 164). Shoe motif.

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov's art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).  Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).
ru_trans: Танец. Это слово является неотъемлемой частью творчества Соколова. Хорея — двигательное расстройство из группы неврологических заболеваний. Название происходит от древнегреческого "χορεία" и используется для описания движений страдающих этой болезнью. Первый роман Соколова, "Школа для дураков", был посвящен Вите Пляскиной, ссылаясь на пляску Святого Вита. Посмотреть видео можно [здесь](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg). Неоднократно упоминается в романе (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

text: Low: while, at the same time.

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat' is linked to the fact that here in chapter 10 Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person," and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.
ru_trans: Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола "гулять" связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как "гулящей": "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). В данном случае, "гулена" относится к пристрастию Орины к застольям и пиршествам, а "гулящая" указывает на ее беспорядочные романтические отношения.

text: According to Ptolemy, the Greek-Egyptian astronomer of the Ancient Roman Empire (2th century BC), the universe had the Earth at its center, while the Sun and the Moon, as well as all stars and planets orbited our planet (geocentric model). From the late 16th century onward, this model was gradually superseded by the heliocentric model developed by Copernicus (1473–1543), Galileo (1564–1642), and Kepler (1571–1630).

С XVI века эта модель была постепенно вытеснена гелиоцентической моделью, разработаной Коперником (1473–1543), Галилеем (1564–1642), и Кеплером (1571–1630).

text: Low: to seem.

Patronymic, son of Dorofei. Dorofei is a name of Greek origin, literally meaning "gift of God". It isn't much used in the Russian area, except for the monastic, sacred context. The Ptolemaic model (suggested by the name of this character) was adopted by the Christian church, as it suited well its model of world. Any other interpretation was persecuted (Galileo's case is telling in this regard).
ru_trans: Отчество: сын Дорофея. Дорофей — имя греческого происхождения, буквально означающее "Божий дар". Оно почти не употребляется в русскоговорящих регионах, кроме как в священном контексте (в монастырях). Модель Птолемея (на что указывает имя героя) была принята христианской церковью, так как она хорошо соответствовала церковной модели мира. Все остальные интерпретации были преследуемы и наказуемы (показательный пример — случай с Галилеем).

text: An allusion to Anton Chekhov's *Uncle Vanya*. Read the original Russian [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/972/p.1/index.html) and English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1756/1756-h/1756-h.htm). Since the morgue is described as a theater, it is not surprising that the nurse is an "uncle Vanya."

Прочитать пьесу в оригинале на русском можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/972/p.1/index.html), а в английском переводе — [здесь](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1756/1756-h/1756-h.htm). Так как морг описан как театр, медсестра-"дядя Ваня" не становится сюрпризом для читателя.

text: A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg). Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). text: The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya's letter "Zaitil'shchina" is derived from this version of the river's name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil' and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools* (10).
ru_trans: Татарское название Волги. Заглавие письма Ильи "Заитильщина" является производным от этой версии названия реки. Остатин также указывает на фонетическое сходство рек Итиль и Леты, реки забытья, которая также играет важную роль в первом романе Соколова "Школа для дураков" (Ostanin 10).

text: A reference to the the Wandering Jew, whose name is said to be Ahasuerus. There are various versions of his story, but what is most relevant here are his alleged profession (shoemaker) and sin (taunting Jesus on the path to the crucifixion). In a later text devoted to Velimir Khlebnikov (which Sokolov read on the radio, in honor of the centenary of the poet’s birth in 1985), the author defines the Poet as an Agasfer who lives within the language, rather than in society, which regards him with suspicion and disappointment. The figure of the wandering Jew appears also in Sokolov's last work *Triptych* (2011).

text: Dated: wagon train. Railroad theme.

According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.
ru_trans: Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, "зимарь" — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского "Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры" (1963) ("Аннотации" 233). Образовано сочетанием слов "зима" и "январь", подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.

text: A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.
Patronymic: son of Ilya. Yakov may, indeed, be Ilya's son.
The fastest part of a river.

text: Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: фигурация). The term is ironic, it suggests he is not the least important person (figure) in the lodge. Ilya mistakenly uses the word "фигурант" in chapter 4 (R178/E51).
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "фигурация"). Слово употреблено с иронией, указывая на то, что он в ложе не последний по важности человек. Илья ошибочно использует слово "фигурант" в главе 4 (R178/E51).

text: The hunters' dare to Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr to hang himself after his time with the Dame appears in chapter 8 (R207/E100–101) and chapter 10 (R222/E127–128).

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it is Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: Here, the accordion, but, generally, a barrel organ, roller organ, or crank organ. Originally from France, it's name is derived from "Charmante Catherine," one of the first songs played on the instrument. Unlike an organ (or an accordion), it is played by turning a crank. Thus, the musician is known as an organ grinder. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/Austrian_BarrelOrgan.jpg)
ru_trans: Здесь имеется в виду, гармонь, но в общем смысле слова относится к переносному механическому органу. Созданный во Франции, инструмент получил свое название от "Charmante Catherine", одной из первых песен, исполненных на этом инструменте. В отличие от органа или гармони, звук создается путем вращения ручки. Музыкант, играющий на этом инструменте, называется шарманщик. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/Austrian_BarrelOrgan.jpg)

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (*gorod*) and beggar (*nishchii*). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
ru_trans: Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов "город" и "нищий". Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: "Если *Школа для дураков* была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, *Между собакой и волком* можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых" (Matich "Sasha Sokolov" 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid "Zaitil'shchina" 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson "Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

text: Black woodpecker. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/31/Schwarzspecht.jpg) The woodpecker has traditionally played roles "as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who [...] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war" (Rowland 180). The black woodpecker in particular in folklore is often depicted as a "villain" who "acts contrary to the commands of the Almighty" in refusing to help create the world (Armstrong 96). Furthermore, "in a Russian legend, the woodpecker is a man whom God changed into a bird because he worked on Sunday" (97). Animal motif.

Ilya misspells the colloquial expression "shivorot-navyvorot", meaning "inside out". Yakov will do the same in Note XXVI (R237/E151). As Napolitano suggests, this specific Note can be considered as a summary (through letters containing mentioning to specific episodes or expressions encountered elsewhere in the book) of what is going on by the Volga: "among these letters there is everything we encountered in the narrative" (in terms of heroes, words, expressions, entire episodes) ("Studyin this Volapuke" 292). It can also be assumed from this Note, that the Binging Hunter/Yakov is the only author of the entire book, which he sketches on the basis of the episodes he reads in these "stolen" letters. Be that as it may, the repetition of this specific expression comes as no surprise in the structure of the novel. Absolutely makes sense! We/you should add material from your article to the Note XXVI annotation.

So, do you think Yakov potentially misspells it in both places, then? I was thinking it could be a variant spelling or variant of the expression. But you're right -- there's a logic to it on the level you describe.could this be some kind of variant, then?Yakov does the same in Note XXVI (R237/E151).

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps?output=search&q=bydgoszcz&entry=mc&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj4_sT8sbb_AhUaGVkFHWvIBHAQ0pQJegQICxAB) (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).

text:
This phraseologism is generally used to describe a person with an unstable character. However, the syntagm refers to a folding bag (made of fabric or leather) used to transport things on a horse. Pictured here: ![](https://i.ebayimg.com/thumbs/images/g/uIYAAOSwcFtjR92W/s-l300.jpg)
This type of bag is also linked with the tradition of bylina, in particular with the character of Svyatogor-bogatyr'. [Here](https://lukoshko.net/story/svyatogor-bogatyr.htm) the bylina in Russian, and in its [English translation](http://www.artrusse.ca/byliny/ilya_svyatogor.htm). It is mentioned already in ch. 4 and it will be mentioned again in ch. 12.

Этот фразеологизм обычно используется для описания человека непостоянного и непоследовательного. Изображено ниже:  ![](https://i.ebayimg.com/thumbs/images/g/uIYAAOSwcFtjR92W/s-l300.jpg)

text: Yakov suggests that he sees Bruegel's painting outside his window. A central motif in the novel, this phrase alludes to *The Hunters in the Snow*, a 1565 painting by Pieter Bruegel the Elder. The setting and action of this image recurs throughout *Between Dog and Wolf* (e.g., R202–203/E93–95), as they come to life in the text. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d8/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Hunters_in_the_Snow_%28Winter%29_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg) Elena Kravchenko explains: "Besides the 'trope' of the exhibition viewing, the device of ekphrasis, and the 'gallery' structure of *The Pictures*, Sokolov borrows the underlying 'teleology' of Musorgskii’s work. Alongside Borodin, Balakirev, Cui, and Rimskii Korsakov, Musorgskii was one of the 'Mighty Handful' ('Moguchaia kuchka'). Created under the patronage of an art critic Vladimir Stasov, it became the hub of a pioneering national style which espoused folklore and the traditions of the peasantry as the new foundation for Russian music. The group was closely connected with and drew inspiration from the Wanderers, an artistic movement [...] Iakov is set to communicate a similar idea. He comes to the Volga to grasp and represent the lives of its people. Besides his poetic gift, Iakov is an artist, and it is his works that form the textual gallery of the prose chapters. The gallery 'entries' are either demarcated graphically with italics, which signals a title of a painting, or framed by a reference to their pictorial 'origin'" (*The Prose* 61). She continues: "It can be argued that Iakov’s representation of human suffering, which constitutes one of the main themes of the novel, and which has been identified as the major moral message of many Brueghel paintings, is modelled not directly on Brueghel but on W. H. Auden's ekphrasis in his '[Musée des Beaux Arts](http://www.kulichki.com/moshkow/POEZIQ/AUDEN/poems_meerson.txt)'. Running through the images of Brueghel's [*The Census at Bethlehem*](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_The_Census_at_Bethlehem_-_WGA03379.jpg) (1566) and *[The Slaughter of the Innocents](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f6/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Massacre_of_the_Innocents_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)* (ca. 1564), it culminates in the ekphrasis of *[Landscape with the Fall of Icarus](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/Pieter_Bruegel_de_Oude_-_De_val_van_Icarus.jpg)* (ca. 1558)" (*The Prose* 63). On the presence and role of Bruegel’s imagery and subtext, see also [Mario Caramitti’s article “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia.”](https://www.openstarts.units.it/bitstream/10077/2377/1/23.pdf) Beyond these obvious ekphrastic connections between Sokolov’s novel and Bruegel’s painting, these are other points worth noting. For instance, the series from which *Hunters in the Snow* derives, *The Seasons* (1565) is divided into six paintings, five of which remain extant. “If a division of the year into six pictures seems strange initially,” Sabine Pénot and Elke Oberthaler write, “this proves to have been a common way of diving the annual cycle in the Netherlands during the period, as early spring and spring and early summer and midsummer were differentiated. The year’s inherently cyclic character relativizes the discussion around the ‘correct’ order of the pictures – which painting represents the beginning and which the end of the series” (214). Much the same may be said about the structure of *Between Dog and Wolf*, in which the poetic chapters trace the development of seasonal changes, while everything exists in an in-between state (seasons, characters’ identities, etc.). It is also worth noting that, as in Sokolov’s text where strict adherence to geographical reality is not observed, the landscapes depicted in the *Seasons* paintings are not accurate: “These so-called ‘mixed landscapes’ combine memories of the Alps with typically Flemish motifs” (229). There is something to be said about the way Sokolov, like Bruegel develops a “sheer inexhaustible richness of detail” that inevitably leads to “the limits of visual perception and linguistic representation” (215). One particular detail of the painting, apparently not described by Sokolov in the novel, feels relevant: “Thick icicles have claimed the mill wheel at the right edge and brought it to  a halt, as though time itself has frozen” (228). Indeed, time and therefore the characters feel stuck in the world of *Between Dog and Wolf*.
ru_trans:
Скорее всего, относится к картине Брейгеля, встречавшейся в экфрастическом описании Якова "Охотников на снегу", написанную в 1565 году картину Питера Брейгеля Старшего, ведь когда картина впервые встречается в романе, Яков упоминает декабрь. Сцена из картины повторяется на протяжении "Между собакой и волком" например, R202–203/E93–95), будто бы оживая на страницах романа. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d8/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Hunters_in_the_Snow_%28Winter%29_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)

Е. Кравченко объясняет: "Помимо метафоры посещения художественной выставки, приема экфрасиса и "галерейной" структуры Картинок, Соколов заимствует основополагающую телеологию творчества Мусоргского. Наравне с Бородиным, Балакиревым, Кюи и Римским-Корсаковым, Мусоргский относился к "Могучей кучке". Созданная под патронажем художественного критика В. Стасова, группа стала эпицентром развития нового национального стиля русской музыки, в основе которого лежали крестьянские традиции и фольклор. Могучая кучка была тесно связана и черпала вдохновение у художественного движения Передвижников […]. Яков намерен передать ту же идею. Он поселяется на Волге, чтобы запечатлить и отобразить жизнь тамошних людей. Помимо поэтического дара, Яков также наделен художественным талантом, и это его работы формируют словесную галерею прозаических глав. "Экспонаты" галереи или графически выделены курсивом, то есть, относятся к названию картины, или определяются отсылкой к "прототипу" образа" (Kravchenko, "The Prose" 61). Она продолжает: "Можно предположить, что изображение Яковом человеческого страдания, что является одной из главных тем романа и что было определено как одно из центральных моральных посылов картин Брейгеля, строится не напрямую на Брейгеле, а на экфрасисе У. Одена в его "[Музее изящных искусств](http://www.kulichki.com/moshkow/POEZIQ/AUDEN/poems_meerson.txt)". Останавливаясь на "[Переписи в Вифлееме](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_The_Census_at_Bethlehem_-_WGA03379.jpg)" Брейгеля (1566) и "[Избиении младенцев](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f6/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Massacre_of_the_Innocents_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)" (пр. 1564), экфрасис достигает кульминации в описании "[Падения Икара](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/Pieter_Bruegel_de_Oude_-_De_val_van_Icarus.jpg)" (пр. 1558)" (Kravchenko, "The Prose" 63). О присутствии и роли образов и подтекстов Брейгеля можно прочитать в [статье М. Карамитти "Мультифильмы Брейгеля"](https://www.openstarts.units.it/bitstream/10077/2377/1/23.pdf) (Caramitti “Mul’tfilmy Breigelia”).

text: Ostanin (43) suggests interpreting his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are, "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). Ostanin also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it is Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: A polymorphic character who occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dog keeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge.
Archaism: one who lives in an almshouse.
ru_trans: Архаизм: человек, который живет в приюте для престарелых и инвалидов.

text: Colloquial: here you are! here! take it!
Patronymic: son of Ilya. Yakov may, indeed, be Ilya's son.

The expression "znachitel'noe litso" (prominent personage) is generally linked with Nikolai Gogol's povest' *The Overcoat*. This character is an unnamed bureaucrat who holds power as a general supervisor. Akaky (the main character of the povest') seeks help from him to no avail. This entire section of the novel may be read as a parody of Gogol's style. Read *The Overcoat* in the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/980/p.1/index.html) and a translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/13437/13437-8.txt). Sokolov on Gogol: "he always was and still is, for me, the number-one writer. At the age of six or seven, my mother and I spent several months in Ukraine visiting 'Gogol''s Places.' She, too, was in love with Gogol" (Vaiman, "[A Conversation](https://www.svoboda.org/a/24200193.html)" 367).
ru_trans: Выражение "значительное лицо" обычно ассоциируется с повестью Н. Гоголя "Шинель". Этот герой — безымянный бюрократ в позиции власти, начальник над подчиненными. Акакий (главный герой повести) ищет у него помощи, но безрезультатно. Эту часть романа в целом можно рассматривать как пародию на гоголевский стиль. Прочитать "Шинель" в оригинале можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/980/p.1/index.html), а в английском переводе — [здесь](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/13437/13437-8.txt). Соколов о Гоголе: "Он всегда был и остается для меня писателем номер один. Тем более что в шесть или семь лет я с матерью провел несколько месяцев в гоголевских местах на Украине. Она была тоже влюблена в Гоголя" (Vaiman, "A Conversation" 367).

It originates from [Song of Songs 7:4](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Song%20of%20Songs%207%3A4&version=NIV).

text: At this point, Yakov's voice begins to sound very much like that of Ilya. Again, the implication is that Yakov is the author of all parts of the novel and that he has been imitating Ilya. Elena Kravchenko writes, "Attributed to Iakov, who self-consciously adopts the tone and language reminiscent of Il'ia's skaz, the monologue discloses a possible source of the latter's voice: Makar Devushkin, a character of Fedor Dostoevskii's novel-in-letters, *Bednye liudi* (*Poor Folks*). Here, again, Sokolov resorts to a complex intertextual chain by bringing into play Dostoevskii's text, which is an acknowledged 'parody' (imitation) of Gogol''s style" (*The Prose* 70). Yakov has previous been associated with the magpie, which is significant as this bird has traditionally been "considered a symbol for poets thanks to the Roman satirist Martial, who wrote, 'I, a loquacious magpie, greet you with intelligible speech, my lord, and were you not to see me you would refuse to believe that I was a bird" (Martial, quoted in Rowland 105). As José Vergara explains, "This trait and classical link clearly align with Yakov, who is not only the thieving huntsman who takes Ilya’s crutches in response to the latter’s assault on his dog, but also the author of the poems [...] In these poems, as elsewhere, he demonstrates a particular talent for 'imitat[ing] words in a distinct voice like men,' that is, he adopts various identities, voices, registers, and so on, as if chattering away like a magpie who responds to the people around him. Many of his poems consist of parodies and stylizations of nineteenth-century Russian poetry. Yakov incorporates bits and pieces of previous authors’ works in these texts, along with their general styles, rhythms, and so on. The prose chapters that concern him, but which are not narrated by him, also include ekphrastic descriptions of paintings ('Pictures from an Exhibition') and an account of his ancestor, Nikodim Yermolaich Palamakhterov, that reads as if lifted straight from Gogol. Much like Ilya’s hoopoe with its positive *and* negative connotations and Orina’s lapwings, who are closely tied to a sexuality that is both weaponized and treasured, the Yakov-magpie pairing is therefore multivalent, and it contributes to Sokolov’s art of blended identities. On the one hand, Yakov’s personality, his originality, becomes lost in this mirror-like text. On the other, he takes joy in his chameleon-esque nature [...] Although Yakov constructs his poetic 'nest' deep in the Volga backwoods out of borrowed materials, the resulting product, like that of the magpie, is nevertheless highly original. Yakov’s literary theft involves the recontextualization of his stolen materials, which transforms them significantly" ("Flap" 370–371). In a letter addressed to his publisher Carl Proffer in August 1976, Sokolov admitted being dissatisfied with the first parts of the novel he sketched and explained the reason for this unsuccessful result in this way: "I began to sing in a voice that was not mine" (University of California Santa Barbara. Sasha Sokolov collection, Mss 117 Box 1: 5–6). As Martina Napolitano suggests, "Sokolov’s second novel [...] was born out of a reflection on the structuring role of narrating voices" ("Studyin" 281). Animal-human motif.
As Ilya is in a time-space that is relatively "future" to the other side of the river, according to Krylobyl, he uses his "future scow" to travel to the past.
prefix: л я это к сведению и заездил на

text: Gustav Flaubert (1821—1880), French realist novelist. Best known for *Madame Bovary*. Read it [here]((https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2413/2413-h/2413-h.htm). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4f/Gustave_Flaubert.jpg) In an 1989 interview, Sokolov said: "I've never tried to prove anything. I simply make prose. I want to write like Flaubert wrote, only in our century. Flaubert, Proust — what did they teach? You don't need all that. Literature is like playing on a fortepiano. Improvisation. Literature is good modernist jazz. But, of course, when you write a book, you'll say something. How else could it be?" (Adamov, "Sasha Sokolov" 66).
Humpback. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

text: Dated/low: thanks.
Set expression: usually "vniz golovoi" (upside down).

Nikolai is, apparently, blind, deaf, and mute. Caramitti talks about an "infinite gallery of crippled" (бесконечная галерея калек) in Sokolov's oeuvre ("Mul'tfil'm" 363). Two of Sokolov's early stories were about the blind as well: "The Old Helmsman" ("Staryi shturman") and "All the Colors of the Rainbow" ("Vse tsveta radugi"). Elena Kravchenko notes a parallel between this theme in Sokolov's first published stories and the nature of his writing in general: "They were published in Braille, the language by which corporality took the centre stage, outlasting the artefact of reality: not its expression but its embodiment" (*The Prose* 2).
ru_trans: Как выясняется, Николай слеп, глух и нем. Карамитти говорит о "бесконечной галерее калек" в творчестве Соколова (Caramitti, "Mul'tfil'm" 363). Два ранних рассказа Соколова также написаны о слепых: "Старый штурман" и "Все цвета радуги". Е. Кравченко отмечает параллель между данным мотивом в ранних историях Соколова и его стилем письма в целом: "Они были напечатаны шрифтом Брайля — языком, благодаря которому материальность вышла на первый план, опережая артефакт реальности: не ее выражение, а ее воплощение" (Kravchenko, "The Prose" 2).

text: The entire novel presents itself as a tireless manual of metalinguistic labor, rolled forward through series of digressions in a manner somehow metatextually depicted in this Note: a warden, while stitching a rip, “by willows that weep / let[s] his needle drop;” trying to search it out, he finds instead “some kind of ball,” beginning thus to play with it and his companions, and continuing on till a foggy dusk occurs, literally at the hour “between the dog and wolf.” So the novel is construed by the unendingly weaving of words and images used as threads in order to compose ever new textual scenarios.

text:
A [manul](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Manoel.jpg), also known as the Pallas's cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character's name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means "God with us" (16). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Manoel.jpg) Ilya references a "manul's eyes" in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.[Манул](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Manoel.jpg), также палласов кот — дикий кот, впервые замеченный в районе Прибайкалья. Останин также предполагает, что имя героя —сокращенная форма имени Иммануил, которое означает "С нами Бог" (Ostanin 16). Изображён ниже:

text: A reference to False Dmitry I, the first of several pretenders to the Russian throne who claimed to be tsarevich Dmitry Ivanovich, son of Ivan the Terrible. After coming to power through military force and ruling from 1605 to 1606, he was killed, and his body was torn apart and burned. The remains were then shot from a cannon toward Poland. text: The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov's poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg) José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. "He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family," Vergara continues, "but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" ("Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.
ru_trans:

text: Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative "tovarishch" opting for a rather general, but still evocative word (think of Nikolay Nekrasov's "Poet i grazhdanin," Poet and Citizen, 1856). This choice is also related to the epistolary genre Ilya is trying to reproduce and to the fact that his world is the "old" one rather than the Soviet one. Richard Borden claims that "*Between Dog and Wolf* violate[s] specifically Soviet and Russian taboos in its language and its portrayal of Homo Sovieticus" ("Toward" 328).

text: Another name given to Orina, the central female figure in the novel.

An unusual surname, which does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak's novel *Doctor Zhivago* by means of the root "zhiv" (to live) (10). Read the original [here](http://www.vehi.net/pasternak/). Likewise, he notes, too, that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled "Notes of an Elderly Person" in his cycle of short stories, *The Tales of Belkin*. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/89/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/55219/pg55219-images.html).

text: Set expression (не лыком шит): not worse than others in any respect, not inferior to others.

A diminutive form of Krylobyl's name. Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: The poem is written from perspective of the poem (zapiska/note) itself. It implies that it will outlive man but will be covered in dust and forgotten on the shelf of an archive. Recalls Yakov's ruminations on death, his legacy in writing, and escaping the difficulties of life.
ru_trans: Это стихотворение написано от лица самой Записки. Она имеет в виду, что переживет человека, но покроется пылью и будет забыта на полке в архиве. Напоминает размышления Якова на тему смерти, его творческого достояния и избегания жизненных трудностей.

text:
Names for the plants *Euonymus europaens* (European spindle) and *Solanum dulcamara* (bittersweet nightshade). A reflection of the characters' various, shifting names. Gerald Smith compares this passage to the verse of Velimir Khlebnikov (1885–1922) and his literary descendants, including the OBERIU poets ("The Verse" 334). Plant motif."Смешиваются слова, найденные и изобретенные автором: в словаре В.И. Даля есть «бересклет», «брусклет», «бересдрень», «бересква», «берендейка» и «будъдерево»; писателем придумано слово «бредовник», а «брусклет»
видоизменен в «бурусклень». в период работы егерем, давший материал для романа, на писателя оказала большое влияние речь местных жителей. Подбор созвучных слов из народных говоров также позволяет передать сказочную, фольклорную картину мира, как и первая группа метафор." см. Зубова 2001
ru_trans: Названия растений *Euonymus europaens* (бересклет европейский) and *Solanum dulcamara* (паслен сладко-горький). Отражение того, как подобным образом меняются имена героев. Дж. Смит сравнивает этот отрывок со стилем В. Хлебникова (185-1922) и его литературных последователей, включая поэтов ОБЭРИУ (Smith, "The Verse" 334). Мотив растений.

text: Reference to the medieval "Battle on the Ice" (5 April 1242), which was fought on the frozen Lake Peipus (today on the border between Estonia and Russia) between the Republic of Novgorod and Vladimir-Suzdal (led by Prince Alexander Nevsky), and the forces of the Livonian Order and Bishopric of Dorpat (today, Tartu). The outcome of battle determined whether Western Catholicism or Eastern Orthodox Christianity would dominate in the region. The latter prevailed. The event was (inaccurately) portrayed in Sergei Eisenstein's movie *Alexander Nevsky* (1938).

text: Volapük — the first constructed language. Invented by Johann Martin Schleyer between 1879 and 1880 as an international language. The term is now sometimes used to refer to nonsense or incomprehensibility. Martina Napolitano writes: "Searching for such voice, the author has constructed a language, defined by one of the heroes as 'Volapuke.' This language apparently looks 'mysterious' and inaccessible, yet given a closer examination, it reveals its complex texture of interwoven threads: as any constructed language, its origins are to be found in a spoken, lively idiom. A basic rule in this particular 'Volapuke' derives from the chance allowed to any trope, word, expression, and even grapheme to transfigure into its direct, objectified meaning. The novel is thus built upon the unending weaving of linguistic threads that meet their realized metaphor" ("'Studyin This Volapuke'" 293).

The Pavel Bure (Paul Buhre) watch company was established in 1874 (although the family had started this activity back in 1815). In 1899 Pavel Bure was given the title of "court supplier to the Emperor" (between 1887 and 1917 the Russian court bought more than 10,000 watches from his factory). Bure watches are mentioned in many literary works, for example by Anton Chekhov, or Il'f and Petrov in their *The Golden Calf*. After the 1917 Revolution the Bure factory stopped its activity in Russia, but continued to work in Switzerland.
ru_trans: Часовая компания Павел Буре (Paul Buhre) была основана в 1874 году (хотя семья Буре занималась часовым делом с 1815 года). В 1899 году Павел Буре был удостоен титула "Поставщика Двора Его Императорского Величества" (между 1887 и 1917 годом царский двор приобрел более 10,000 часов его производства). Часы Буре упоминаются во многих литературных произведениях, например, Чехова или Ильфа и Петрова в "Золотом теленке". После революции 1917 года часовая компания Буре прекратила свою деятельность в России, однако продолжила работу в Швейцарии.

The frequent use of variations on the verb *gulyat'* is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person," and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships. Alcohol theme.

text: Set expression: Наш пострел всюду поспел (Our scamp has a finger in every pie).

A reference to the various men with missing limbs in the region. This detail of the novel is a product of the violence described here by Ilya, but it is also part of the realia of the post-war setting. While Olga Matich argues that *Between Dog and Wolf* "eschews recent history completely," Sokolov in fact encodes these conditions of mid-century Soviet life into the novel ("Sasha Sokolov's" 416). In an interview, Sokolov once said: "I see that belles-lettres become less and less popular, gives way to history. Solzhenitsyn understands this and decided that historical form interests the reader more, and therefore, he switched, he moved away entirely from belles-lettres, from the novel, he moved on to something new. But I don't love history. I don't believe in it. I don't believe any research, any archives. All of that, in my opinion, is conjecture, thought up. But that's not even the point. History simply doesn't interest me. I don't believe that you can pull the future from it" (Voroneli, "Ia khochu" 184).

Read the poem (in Russian) [here](https://slova.org.ru/pasternak/sestramojazhizn/). Read a translation [here](https://internetpoem.com/boris-pasternak/my-sister-life-s-overflowing-today-poem/).

text: Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -oго.Maybe it's too simple an answer, but it could be part of the novel's distorted chronology. There's another chapter... blanking on which one it is, though it's another Yakov chapter... that does something similar.There are several "recent" events mentioned in this section, and I got confused with the dates. Cinematograph was patented in 1895, the train robbery was in 1891, and the bank robbery, apparently, in 1907. There is a 12-year gap between the earliest and the latest event, how come they are all recent?Sounds possible! Fascinating either way. Let me know if/when you update the original annotation, and I'll delete these follow-up comments.Could be this [case](https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/politics/anarchists-in-switzerland-part-6_how-a-montreux-bank-heist-led-to-calls-for-the-death-penalty/45225988) (two Russians robbing a Montreux bank in 1907)? One of the two Russians was a Tolstoy fan, apparently. And Montreux is an iconic city in the Russian literary cosmos because of Nabokov. Can we identify this particular robbery, do you think?
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ого. Возможно, имеется в виду [ограбление](https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/politics/anarchists-in-switzerland-part-6_how-a-montreux-bank-heist-led-to-calls-for-the-death-penalty/45225988) банка Монтре двумя русскими в 1907 году. Один из грабителей был поклонником Толстого, а Монтре стал символическим городом в литературных кругах благодаря Набокову.
suffix: банка и о новом крупном ограбле

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.
ru_trans: Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, "зимарь" — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского "Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры" (1963) ("Аннотации" 233). Образовано сочетанием слов "зима" и "январь", подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.
