text:
Olga Matich writes of the sewing themes: "Yet the verb “weave” and noun “weaving” appear only rarely in the novel
and only with its meaning defamiliarized or rewoven, for example in the wellknown colloquial idiom in which weaving words is a metaphor for speaking nonsense ('Ой, плетете вы сами не знаете что,' 142), perhaps intended as
a parody of word-weaving. Another estranged usage is that of '*pleten'*' (wattle fence) metamorphosed into a thrice removed distant relative ('троюродный плетень,' 112); or '*spletni*' (108), meaning gossip, which comes from the verb 'spletat’' (weave in the sense of intertwine). The altercation between Ilya
and the wolf on the ice inscribes reweaving (*perepletat*) rendered as 'Мудрено индивиду в таких переплетах баланс удерживать' (139) [...] '*Pereplet*' means book binding, with its plural in this passage metaphorized as a situation in which Ilya finds it difficult to keep his balance on the ice. The phrase, I would suggest, may also be a nod to *Between Dog and Wolf*’s readers who sometimes find it very difficult to interpret that which they encounter between its, so to speak, woven, rewoven, or interwoven 'bindings'" (*Between Dog and Wolf* 255–256).

text: Various characters sew in the novel. Maria (a variant of Orina, the bobylka, Lonesome Babe) is associated with sewing (R161/E21). text: Yakov once worked as a courier but is now a whipper-in. There is another linguistic layer here based on the use of motion verbs "raz''ezzhat'" and "doezzhat'": he once used to travel all the time to various places (raz-), but in the end he reached a final destination (do-).

text: In his third novel, *Palisandriia* (translated into English as *Astrophobia* by Michael Henry Heim) Sokolov will recount the life and times of Palinsandr' Dalberg, a Kremlin orphan with a preference for older women. See [Matich "About Palisandriia"](http://russianwriters.berkeley.edu/sasha-sokolov/about-palisandriia/) for a summary of the text. Read the novel [here](https://royallib.com/read/sokolov_sasha/palisandriya.html#0).

The duck is here potentially a reference to Boris Pasternak's novel *Doctor Zhivago*, in which the protagonist is gifted a dead duck by a deaf-mute acquaintance that comes to symbolize the apocalyptic and tragic end of Zhivago and his generation. For more on this subject, see Rowland 50 and Jackson. Animal motif.

Literary: once, at some point.

объясняла, что плотью своею сохну,

text: Ilya cannot forget Orina and this makes the woman suffer. Ilya uses the same verb he used to describe himself getting thinner and thinner ("sokhnu", I dry up), but while in regard to himself this process is linked with his living a hard life, here the woman accuses him to make her flesh "dry up." The verb is repeated one more time in the next sentence, yet with a prefix (pri-), as she observes that Ilya "dried up" sticking himself to Orina, that is to say: he cannot forget Orina.
ru_trans: Илья не может забыть Орину, и это заставляет женщину страдать. Илья использует тот же глагол по отношению к себе ("я сохну"), но если в случае Ильи это указывает на тяжелую жизнь, здесь женщина винит его в том, что он заставляет ее плоть сохнуть. Глагол повторяется снова в следующем предложении, но с приставкой при-, когда Орина замечает, Илья присох к ней, то есть, не может ее забыть.
suffix: . Вы присохли к ней, подруга ска

text: Clover. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Rotklee_Trifolium_pratense.jpg) Plant motif. A continuation of the temporal setting: summer.

Transformations, in general, are common in the novel. More specifically, here, the reference is to the biblical Transfiguration of Jesus, in which Jesus goes to a mountaintop to pray with James, John, and Mark. Once there, he begins to shine with light, and Elijah (one of Ilya's identities in the novel) and Moses appear beside him as the voice of God calls out to him. The event is documented in [Matthew 17:1–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2017%3A1-8&version=NIV), [Mark 9:2–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Mark%209%3A2-8&version=NIV), and [Luke 9:28–36](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%209%3A28-36&version=NIV). Celebrated on August 6. Here the transfiguration is also a metaphor suggesting Nikolai's death, which was previously described in chapter 1 by Ilya (R153/E8). The main character of Mikhail Bulgakov's *Heart of a Dog* (a novel which widely circulated in samizdat in the 60s) is Doctor Preobrazhensky, whose experiment of turning a homeless dog into a man leads to tragic consequences (and to his "transfigurating" back into a dog).
ru_trans: Преображения, в целом, нередко встречаются в романе. Конкретнов этом отрывке прослеживается отсылка к библейскому Преображению Иисуса, когда Иисус поднимается на гору с Иаковом, Иоанном и Марком. Там, на вершине, он начинает сиять, а рядом с ним появляются пророк Илия (одна из личностей Ильи в романе) и Моисей, в то время как к нему взывает Божий голос. Это событие описано в [Матфея 17:1-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+17%3A1-8&version=RUSV), [Марка 9:2-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Mark+9%3A2-8&version=RUSV), [Луки 9:28-36](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke+9%3A28-36&version=RUSV). Празднуется 6 августа. Кроме того, главный герой романа Михаила Булгакова "Сердце собаки" (одно из массовых произведений самиздата 60-ых) — доктор Преображенский, чей эксперимент по превращению бездомного пса в человека ведет к плачевному исходу (и его "преображению" обратно в собаку).

text: Colloquial: one-womber. Meaning coming from the same mother but different fathers.
ru_trans: Разговорное: единоутробный. Родной по матери, но имеющий другого отца.

text: First mentioned in chapter 1 by Ilya (R150/E3). Saint Nicholas of Myra / Nicholas the Wonderworker. A folkloric wanderer who roams the world and tests people for hospitality, piety, generosity, etc. According to many legends, saints come in the guise of poor, poor old men who are denied help, overnight accommodation, etc. (see Tsivyan 58–71). Also brings to mind the image of St. Nicholas, who is quite important in Russian Orthodoxy. In his life, different symbolic and ideological lines are connected (movement as salvation; his Mediterranean-Asian origins).

text: Scorpio — astrological sign and constellation. October 23 to November 21. According to Greek mythology, Orion, the great hunter, sought to kill all animals, so the goddess Gaia ordered Scorpio, a giant scorpion, to kill him. Upon stinging him, Scorpio was raised to the heavens where he spends half the year chasing the hunter. Constellation-heavens motif.
Ilya while sleeping grabs the woman roughly, as if he hadn't hands but paws ("lapy", in Russian). Once again he is associated with animals. Animal-human motif.

text: According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

text: Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin (1799–1837), the father of modern Russian letters and a crucial source of subtexts in *Between Dog and Wolf*. In fact, the phrase "пора меж волка и собаки" (the time between wolf and dog) appears in Pushkin's celebrated novel-in-verse *Eugene Onegin* (ch. 4, stanza 47).
ru_trans: Александр Сергеевич Пушкин (1799–1837), отец современного литературного языка и ключевой источник подтекстуальности в романе "Между собакой и волком". Более того, сама фраза "пора меж волка и собаки" взята из знаменитого *Евгения Онегина* — написанного Пушкиным романа в стихах (гл. 4, строфа 47).
prefix:
И словно бы чего-то ждешь.
  То

text: In ancient Russia, a *sloboda* referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, *sloboda* refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a [Sloboda](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sloboda,+Tver+Oblast,+Russia,+171265/@56.6543229,36.4671174,12.92z/data=!4m6!3m5!1s0x46b4337b61338bc3:0xfd78ee1285635920!8m2!3d56.6502347!4d36.4718922!16s%2Fg%2F12xpjjzgs?entry=ttu) can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова "свобода". Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, "слобода" в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

text: The reference here is to the Red Guards (Hong Weibing), a student-let movement who supported Mao during the first phase of the Cultural revolution (1960s). In USSR they were known as “khunveybiny” in the media. As Ostanin recalls (69), they used to cut “dogs’ heads” to political opposers. Here the allusion could also remind a Russian reader of the typical symbol of the oprichniki (a dog’s head, along with a broom). Animal motif.

на похищенных велоциклетах, и лира, как всегда, ни черта не стоила. Маяки и ревуны Гибралтара бодрили штормующих мареманов,

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

text: The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr's name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels "e/ë" and "o."
ru_trans: Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных "е/ё" и "о".

text: Lines 180–182 from Mikhail Lozinsky's 1933 translation of *Hamlet*, Act I, Scene I. Read the Russian translation [here](https://povto.ru/shakespeare/hamlet/shakespeare-hamlet_1-1.php). Read the original English [here](https://shakespeare.folger.edu/shakespeares-works/hamlet/act-1-scene-1/).

A [city](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Millerovo,+Rostov+Oblast,+Russia/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x411ee3aa865e9805:0x33cce3efc853ac80?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwi86MT57Pz8AhUeEFkFHRJXChsQ8gF6BAhoEAE) in the Rostov Oblast of Russia. Ostanin notes that this town recalls the English term "miller," which once again touches upon the theme of mills/flour (51).

Останин замечает, что название города напоминает английское слово "miller" ("мельник"), опять же, возвращаясь к теме мельницы/муки (Ostanin 51).

text: Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: иллюзии).
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "иллюзии").

text: A noble Albanian family in the 14th and 15th centuries. Gjergj Kastrioti (also known as Skanderbeg) led Albanians against Mehmed the Conqueror and the Ottoman Empire. The family eventually pledged allegience to the Kingdom of Naples. They may also be mentioned because their coat of arms features a two-headed eagle (reminiscent of Russia's own coat of arms) and the eagles on the bridge mentioned a few lines up. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Coat_of_arms_of_the_House_of_Kastrioti.svg) Animal motif.

text: This poem merges different lines of Pushkin's oeuvre and biography (duels, spleen, etc.). In particular, this poem seems to creatively rewrite Pushkin's "Zima. Chto delat' nam v derevne?". Read the original [here](https://www.culture.ru/poems/4915/zima-chto-delat-nam-v-derevne ).
ru_trans: В этой строфе соединены раличные фрагменты жизни и творчества Пушкина (дуэль, тоска, и т. п.). В частности, здесь творчески перефразировано стихотворение "[Зима. Что делать нам в деревне?](https://www.culture.ru/poems/4915/zima-chto-delat-nam-v-derevne)" Пушкина.

text: Black woodpecker. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/31/Schwarzspecht.jpg) The woodpecker has traditionally played roles "as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who [...] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war" (Rowland 180). The black woodpecker in particular in folklore is often depicted as a "villain" who "acts contrary to the commands of the Almighty" in refusing to help create the world (Armstrong 96). Furthermore, "in a Russian legend, the woodpecker is a man whom God changed into a bird because he worked on Sunday" (97). Animal motif.

The commanding officer of the Russian army, General Alexander Suvorov, was awarded the title of the Graf of Rymnik" ("Annotations" 246). Alcohol theme.

text: Bird's eye is a type of figure that occurs within several kinds of wood, most notably in hard maple. Pictured here: ![](https://crlumber.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/wood-type-figured-lumber-Birdseye-Maple-600x488.jpg) However, given the botanical and faunistic discussion entangled here, it may also indicated here the Bird's eye chili (or Thai chili), a Mexican chili pepper. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/32/Thai_peppers.jpg) Plant motif.I would guess (based on the previous discussion of plants/animals) that they might mean the [Bird's eye chili](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chili), what do you think?

text: First mentioned in chapter 1 by Ilya (R150/E3). Saint Nicholas of Myra / Nicholas the Wonderworker, saint николай угодник / Николай Чудотворец - святой, покровитель путешествующих, заключённых и сирот. Сказочный сюжет о чудесном страннике, который ходит по миру и испытывает людей на гостеприимство, благочестие, щедрость и т.д. Согласно многим легендам, святые приходят в обличье убогих, нищих стариков, которым отказывают в помощи, ночлеге и т.д. (см. Т. Цивьян, "Николай Угодник - странник на русской земле" // Семиотические путешествия, СПб 2001, с. 58-71). Еще здесь можно упомянуть образ святого Николая, так важного для русских православных: в его житии соединяются разные символические и идейные линии (движение как спасение; свой хотя чужой, средиземноморского-малоазиатского происхождения)
prefix:

text: Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Plyaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg). Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

Сказочный сюжет о чудесном страннике, который ходит по миру и испытывает людей на гостеприимство, благочестие, щедрость и т.д. Согласно многим легендам, святые приходят в обличье убогих, нищих стариков, которым отказывают в помощи, ночлеге и т.д. (см. Т. Цивьян, "Николай Угодник - странник на русской земле" // Семиотические путешествия, СПб 2001, с. 58-71). Еще здесь можно упомянуть образ святого Николая, так важного для русских православных: в его житии соединяются разные символические и идейные линии (движение как спасение; свой хотя чужой, средиземноморского-малоазиатского происхождения)

text: Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: контрадикцией).
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "контрадикцией").

chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

text: The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya's letter "Zaitil'shchina" is derived from this version of the river's name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil' and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools* (10).

According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

Sokolov plays with the difference between *kalika* (wanderer) and *kaleka* (invalid, cripple). The former is a name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg) Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 9 (R214/E112), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). Shoe motif.
ru_trans:
Название слепых странников, поющих духовные песни. Ранее слово не относилось к просящим милостыню калекам, как сейчас, но означало странников, посещающих святые места и поющих песни. Слово происходит от латинского *caligae*, изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg)

Так странники жили на подаяния, собранные в селениях, через которые они проходили (и иногда оставались жить), в современном языке слово приобрело значение занимающегося подобной деятельностью инвалида. Изображено ниже: 
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg)

([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Также упоминается в главе 8 (R209/E103), главе 9 (R214/E112), главе 10 (R223/E129), и главе 11 (R230/E141). Set expression (zadat' lataty): to run away swiftly, without a backward glance, without remembering oneself. But "latka" is also a synonym for "patch," that is, a piece of cloth stitched on a torn place.
ru_trans: "Задать лататы" - устойчивое выражение: стремительно убегать, без оглядки, не помня себя. Но "латка" это тоже синоним "заплата", то есть кусок ткани, нашиваемый на прорванное место.

text: A spit or sandbank, but also a braid or scythe. See also Blok's *Puppet Show*.

The description of train passengers is a typical subject in Russian literature. See for example Zoshchenko's short story entitled "Priiatnaia vstrecha" (1930): read the original [here](https://zoschenko.ru/cat/207/69.html). Another narrative example very close to Sokolov's is contained in Venedikt Yerofeyev's "From Moscow to Petushki", a novel written in the same years as "Between Dog and Wolf." Read the passage [here](http://kirovsk.narod.ru/culture/ludi/erofeev/proizved/petuski/8.html) (in Russian). Railroad theme.
Low: it is unknown.

text: First mentioned in chapter 1 by Ilya (R150/E3). Saint Nicholas of Myra / Nicholas the Wonderworker, saint николай угодник / Николай Чудотворец - святой, покровитель путешествующих, заключённых и сирот. Сказочный сюжет о чудесном страннике, который ходит по миру и испытывает людей на гостеприимство, благочестие, щедрость и т.д. Согласно многим легендам, святые приходят в обличье убогих, нищих стариков, которым отказывают в помощи, ночлеге и т.д. (см. Т. Цивьян, "Николай Угодник - странник на русской земле" // Семиотические путешествия, СПб 2001, с. 58-71). Еще здесь можно упомянуть образ святого Николая, так важного для русских православных: в его житии соединяются разные символические и идейные линии (движение как спасение; свой хотя чужой, средиземноморского-малоазиатского происхождения)

text: As Elena Kravchenko notes, this "recycling" practice is central to the novel on many levels: "Its eternal cyclical progression is manifest not only on the literary level of Iakov's intertextual recycling, but also on the literal level in a portrayal of the material recycling in Il'ia's skaz. Zaitil'shchina, the main setting of Il'ia's story as indicated by the titles of his narratives, represents its embodiment" (*The Prose* 69).
ru_trans: Как замечает Е. Кравченко, прием "переработки" занимает центральное положение в романе на многих уровнях: "Бесконечное циклическое движение прослеживается не только на литературном уровне в виде повторного использования текста Яковом, но и в буквальном смысле в виде переработки материалов в рассказе Ильи. Заитильщина, главное место действия рассказа Ильи, как на то указывают названия его повествовательных глав, символизирует ее воплощение" (Kravchenko, *The Prose* 69).

text: From the French "*cerceau*." Hoop rolling — a children's game in which hoops are kept rolling with a stick or other device. Depicted in the bottom center of the 1560 painting *Children's Games* by Bruegel: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Children%E2%80%99s_Games_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg) Sabine Pénot and Elke Oberthaler write, “*Children’s Games* is one of the earliest known panel paintings by Bruegel. […] Bruegel’s encyclopaedic approach is not limited to the depiction of the greatest possible variety of games but also embraces the rendering of a whole gamut of personal dispositions, from calm to aggressive. With just a few strokes of the brush the painter manages to give each of the protagonists a clearly legible expression that goes well beyond stock characterization, through the play of facial features and body language. Different types of customs make it clear that Bruegel was intending to depict a miscellany of children's activities from all four seasons” (132). Ostanin also notes that Серко (Serko) is the name given to dogs in the Ukrainian fairy tale "Серко" (33).
ru_trans:
От французского "*cerceau*". Детская игра в обруч, при которой движение обруча поддерживается палкой или другим предметом. Изображено внизу в центре картины Брейгеля 1560 года *Детские игры*: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/Pieter_Bruegel_the_Elder_-_Children%E2%80%99s_Games_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)

Останин также замечает, что Серко — собачье имя из украинской сказки "Серко" (33).

text: According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

text: This mix of events and epochs suggests that time is rendered unstable. Time periods, like characters and locations, blur.

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
ru_trans: Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов "город" и "нищий". Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: "Если *Школа для дураков* была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, *Между собакой и волком* можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых" (Matich "Sasha Sokolov" 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid "Zaitil'shchina" 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson "Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

A long literary serious invective of bitter lamentation on the state of society and its morals. The use of this term clashes with the general low register used by Ilya. The term is named after the prophet Jeremiah who wrote the *Book of Jeremiah *and the *Book of Lamentations*. Jeremiah predicted the downfall of the Kingdom of Judah.
ru_trans: Длинное серьезное литературное произведение-оплакивание состояние общества и морали. Название происходит от имени пророка Иеремии, который написал книгу *Иеремии* и *Плач Иеремии*. Иеремия предсказал падение царства Иудеи. Использование этого термина необычно для просторечного стиля Ильи.

text:
According to Ostanin, this most likely refers to the Contemporary and Taganka Theatres, located in Moscow (95). Sokolov counters: "About all theatres" ("Bol'shoe pis'mo" 137). Sokolov on Moscow: "When I came to Moscow in 1989, I lived for a year,
constantly changing apartments, hotels, mainly
because I was "taken" by some journalists, graphomaniacs... all these people who for some reason were interested in talking to me. My wife and I counted nine addresses that we changed during the year. That is, you live, feeling that you are being torn apart a little. And you don't belong to yourself anymore. The attention of people, of course, is flattering (before that I didn't have such an experience that someone was interested in me), but after a few weeks you can barely walk!.. Moscow sucks, twists, you go through some kind of meat grinder. Moscow gives a lot, but it also takes a lot. There are people who love it. They are recharged by such a life… I remember we lived in a hotel near Khimki. We thought we had run away from everyone, no one knows where we are… And a few days later at midnight there's a knock at the door... The entire Taganka Theater is standing on the threshold. They came to talk. They demand that I tell them something, speak out. They wanted to stage something. These are, of course, all wonderful people. I ran away once again, our communication didn't continue. Perhaps they were offended…" (Slepynin).Angelina, here's the Russia: — Когда в 1989 году я приехал в Москву, то в течение года жил, постоянно меняя квартиры, гостиницы, главным образом
потому, что меня «доставали» какие-то журналисты,
графоманы… все эти люди, которым почему-то было интересно со мной общаться. Мы с женой насчитали девять адресов, которые сменили в течение года. То есть живешь, чувствуя, что тебя немножко рвут на части. И ты уже не принадлежишь себе. Внимание людей, конечно, льстит (до этого у меня не было
такого опыта, чтобы я был кому-то интересен), но через
несколько недель ты уже едва ходишь!.. Москва высасывает, выкручивает, проходишь будто через какую-то мясорубку. Москва многое дает, но многое и берет. Есть люди, которые это любят, их подзаряжает такая жизнь… Вспоминаю, мы жили в гостинице недалеко от Химок. Думали, ото всех убежали, никто
не знает, где мы… А через несколько дней в 12 ночи стук в дверь... На пороге стоит весь Театр на Таганке. Пришли общаться. Требуют, чтобы я что-то рассказал, выступил. Было намерение что-то поставить. Это, конечно, все замечательные люди. Я сбежал в очередной раз, наше общение не продолжилось. Возможно, они обиделись…

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -ий. Moreover, since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: приезжий).
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ий. Более того, так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "приезжий").

text: Boguslawski cites this line as a reference to General Joseph Radetzky von Radetz, who, during the Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878), "kept sending reports from Shipka that everything was calm there," when in fact his troops faced freezing conditions and attacks from multiple sides. Vasily Vereshchagin set these events in [a series of paintings](https://arthive.com/vasilyvasilyevichvereshchagin/works/397513~SHIPKA_all_is_quiet_Triptych_Reconstruction). text: The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov's poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg) José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. "He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family," José Vergara writes, "but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" ("Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.

This whole section is a historical nightmare!

A town located on the Volga in the Yaroslavl oblast. It is famous for the assassination of Ivan the Terrible's son, Dmitry (here recalled also through the grandson's name), who was sent to Uglich in 1584 after his father died. The 10-year-old boy was found dead on May 15, 1591, his throat cut in the palace courtyard. Although suspicion fell on the tsar's chief advisor, Boris Godunov, official investigators concluded that Dmitry's death was an accident. The story is mentioned also in Pushkin's play "Boris Godunov" (1831).
ru_trans: Город, расположенный на Волге в Ярославской области. Известен как место, в котором случилось убийство сына Ивана Грозного, Дмитрия (о чем напоминает имя внука), который был сослан в Углич в 1584 году после смерти отца. Десятилетний мальчик был найден мертвым с перерезанным горлом во дворе дворца 10 мая 1591 года. Несмотря на то, что подозрение пало на царского советника Бориса Годунова, официальное расследование заключило, что смерть Дмитрия была несчастным случаем. Эта история упоминается в пьесе Пушкина "Борис Годунов" (1831).

text: Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -ий. Moreover, since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: птичий).
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ий. Более того, так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "птичий").

text: That is, prostitutes.

Elena Kravchenko suggests that by "the spatial image of the mother/land and the temporal image of Life Everlasting in the figure of Orina, Sokolov erases the line between the categories of time and space, dissolving them into a condition of love (and death, love’s double in Sokolov)" (*The Prose* 79).
ru_trans: Елена Кравченко предпологает, что "пространственный образ Родины-мати и временной образ Вечной Жизни в персонаже Орины стирает границы между категориями времени и пространства, растворяя их в среде любви (и смерти — соколовского двойника любви)" (Kravchenko, *The Prose* 79).

text: Also known as seppuku (from the Japanese 切腹, "cutting [the] belly"), hara-kiri is a ritual suicide by disembowelment performed to preserve one's honor in Japan. Samuri used hara-kiri to avoid being captured in battle, to restore one's honor after a dishonorable act, or as capital punishment. It is performed by plunging a short knife into one's abdomen and cutting from left to right, often in front of others. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5d/Seppuku.jpg)
разг. Некоторое время маячить
prefix: на скорый отход мой покинь, еще

text: A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg) Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 9 (R214/E112), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). Shoe motif.
ru_trans:
Название слепых странников, поющих духовные песни. Ранее слово не относилось к просящим милостыню калекам, как сейчас, но означало странников, посещающих святые места и поющих песни. Слово происходит от латинского *caligae*, изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg)

Так странники жили на подаяния, собранные в селениях, через которые они проходили (и иногда оставались жить), в современном языке слово приобрело значение занимающегося подобной деятельностью инвалида. Изображено ниже: 
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg)

text: Boguslawski identities these lines as a reference to Afanasii Fet's untitled 1842 poem "The pine is so dark, despite the moon." Read the original [here](https://slova.org.ru/fet/sosna-tak-temna-hot-i-mesyac/).

Nightingale. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/Luscinia_svecica_volgae.jpg?uselang=ru) According to Peter Tate: "A small member of the warbler family, which has russet upper parts, a broad tail, and is grey-brown below. Its preferred habitat is deciduous woods with dense undergrowth. It is notable for its beautiful song whose notes rise and fall in succession. Contrary to popular belief, nightingales don't just sing at night, but their song is more difficult to distinguish in daylight hours owing to competition from other birds and everyday ambient noise" (81). José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). The characters of Sokolov's novel play out this plot with Ilya seeking out his missing lover Orina and their son Yakov. Animal-human motif.
Literary/archaism: because, for.

text: A reference to the the Wandering Jew, whose name is said to be Ahasuerus. There are various versions of his story, but what is most relevant here are his alleged profession (shoemaker) and sin (taunting Jesus on the path to the crucifixion). The name may also conceal a reference to the nineteenth-century poet Afanasy Fet. In [Sokolov's essay on Velimir Khlebnikov](https://www.svoboda.org/a/25161164.html), he calls the Futurist poet Agasfer. When Ivan Podshivalov brings up Klebnikov in an interview, Sokolov responds: "But you see, phonetics is the yeast, the fermenting agent of language. I start with a sound; sound is like a grain from which everything else grows. It's impossible to speak about phonetics separately from meaning. [...] It takes several years of preparation to understand Khlebnikov, but it is well worth it. After Khlebnikov, Sokolov will be easy" (Podshivalov, "A Conversation" 357–358).
Feathers, used for writing.

Molotov's June 22, 1941 speech on the occasion of the German invasion: "Our cause is just" (Ostanin 101). Read the original [here](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%92%D1%8B%D1%81%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%92._%D0%9C._%D0%9C%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BE_22_%D0%B8%D1%8E%D0%BD%D1%8F_1941_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0) and an English translation [here](https://www.tracesofwar.com/articles/4627/Radio-speech-by-Molotov-22-06-1941.htm).

text: Set expression: to get heavily drunk. Alcohol theme.Устойчивое выражение: сильно напиться. Тема алкоголя. Тема шитья.

This Note "offers a peculiar key to understanding the entire novel’s structure and the nature of its narrating voice(s): in it the 'Binging Hunter' retells a meeting with the mail carrier Sila Silych, during which (...) they decide to 'read at random some of the messages' (...). It is then curious to find out that among these letters there is everything we encountered in the narrative: 'For instance, Pavel from Gorodnishche writes to Pyotr in Bydogoshch, / begs his uncle to purchase the yeast for hooch-brewing, / he implores him to find without fail some alphabet letter.' But, in particular, the two stumble upon Ilya’s letter to Pozhilykh, in which – as we might expect now – 'he complains – during a snowstorm someone lifted his crutches, / the wardens of Shallow Reach, he claims, absconded with them.' So, what we can assume from Note xxvi is that the entire novel may be but a reconstruction or recollection of different voices and stories sketched down by the 'Binging Hunter' only (or rather by Yakov, to the extent we can assume he is the author of the Notes – and such a first name, so close to the Russian word iakoby, makes him literally only ‘allegedly’ a hunter, a wannabe poet/artist, or, more generally speaking, a round and authentic character)." (Napolitano, "Studyin" 291-292).

text: First mentioned in chapter 1 by Ilya (R150/E3). Saint Nicholas of Myra / Nicholas the Wonderworker, saint николай угодник / Николай Чудотворец - святой, покровитель путешествующих, заключённых и сирот. Сказочный сюжет о чудесном страннике, который ходит по миру и испытывает людей на гостеприимство, благочестие, щедрость и т.д. Согласно многим легендам, святые приходят в обличье убогих, нищих стариков, которым отказывают в помощи, ночлеге и т.д. (см. Т. Цивьян, "Николай Угодник - странник на русской земле" // Семиотические путешествия, СПб 2001, с. 58-71). Еще здесь можно упомянуть образ святого Николая, так важного для русских православных: в его житии соединяются разные символические и идейные линии (движение как спасение; свой хотя чужой, средиземноморского-малоазиатского происхождения).

text: Sokolov explains: "This is an ordinary village well with a windlass. The bucket is lowered and lifted with the aid of a windlass and a rope wrapped around it. From time to time in some village someone falls into the well wanting to draw water. Sometimes a child, sometimes a drunken adult. Sometimes a dog or a cat. If there is water in the well, the victim drowns. But if the well is dry, there is a chance that sooner or later the person or animal will be pulled out. They will if people hear screams or meows for help. It is impossible to get out of the well by yourself. The huntsman Ilya tells us about most likely fell into the well, as they say, because he was drunk, and his wife hastened to take advantage of this circumstance. There is nothing allegorical in the fall of the huntsman into the well" (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: Соколов объясняет: "Имеется в виду обычный деревенский колодец с воротом. С помощью ворота и намотанной на него веревки осуществляют спуск и подъем ведра. Время от времени то в той деревне, то в этой кто-нибудь, желая зачерпнуть воды, падает в колодец. Иногда ребенок, иногда пьяный взрослый. Подчас собака или кошка. Если в колодце есть вода, жертва тонет. А если колодец сухой, то есть шанс, что рано или поздно человека или животное вытащат оттуда. Вытащат, если услышат крики или мяуканья о помощи. Самому выбраться из колодца невозможно. Егерь, о котором рассказывает Илья, скорее всего угодил в колодец, как говорится, по пьяному делу, и жена его этим обстоятельством поспешила воспользоваться. В падении егеря в колодец нет ничего иносказательного" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

text: Falcon. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/39/Brown-Falcon%2C-Vic%2C-3.1.2008.jpg) Falcons have been associated with monks, greed, aristocracy (Rowland 59–62). Allusions to his own surname are not seldom in Sokolov's work. See, for instance, *Palisandriia* where a sentry “rises like a falcon” (*Shkola dlia durakov. Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom. Palisandriia. Esse. Triptykh* 285) and the aptly titled "Philornist" ("bird-lover") where Sokolov playfully invokes his surname (“с околосоколиной, коллега, околосоколиной”) (*Shkola dlia durakov. Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom. Palisandriia. Esse. Triptykh* 709). Animal motif.

text: The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya's letter "Zaitil'shchina" is derived from this version of the river's name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil' and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools* (10).
ru_trans: Татарское название Волги. Заглавие письма Ильи "Заитильщина" является производным от этой версии названия реки. Остатин также указывает на фонетическое сходство рек Итиль и Леты, реки забытья, которая также играет важную роль в первом романе Соколова "Школа для дураков" (Ostanin 10).

text: The entire ending passage of this chapter intertwines a series of allusions to Fyodor Tiutchev's 1833 poem "Silentium": "Молчи, скрывайся и таи" (here "Прячешь, скрываешь, таишь"), the reference to silent stars in the sky, "Любуйся" (here "Радуйся"), "Их оглушит наружный шум" (here "все-то небо оглашаешь ты кликушеским балабала́"), "Внимай их пенью" (here "внемлют сему ответу"). Read the original and an English translation [here](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/silentium.html).

text: According to Ostanin (52), they are talking about the historical Moscow hippodrome, which was definitively destroyed by a fire in 1949 (and then rebuilt). From the Greek ἱππόδρομος (ἵππος, "horse" and δρόμος, "course") — a stadium for horse and chariot racing. Now used to refer to a horse track. Here, as in chapter 5, the narrators refer to the Central Moscow Hippodrome, which was founded in 1834 (see also R185/63). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c6/Moscow_Hippodrome.JPG)
ru_trans:
Согласно Останину, они имеют в виду Московский ипподром, который был разрушен в результате пожара в 1949, затем отстроен (Ostanin 52). С греческого ἱππόδρομος (ἵππος, "лошадь" и δρόμος, "бег, площадь для состязаний в беге") — архитектурное сооружение для конных скачек и гонок колесниц. Сейчас относится к конно-спортивному комплексу. Здесь, как и в главе 5, расказчики имеют в виду Центральный московский ипподром, основанный в 1834 (см. также R185/63). Изображено ниже: 
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c6/Moscow_Hippodrome.JPG)

text: The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original [here](https://xn----7sbb5adknde1cb0dyd.xn--p1ai/%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BA%D0%B0-%D0%B6%D0%B0%D1%80-%D0%BF%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B0/) and an English translation [here](http://www.artrusse.ca/fairytales/firebird.htm). In one version of the story, the Firebird transforms into a crow (as mentioned at the end of this sentence). Margaret Ziolkowski explains: "The bird resumes its fantastic form when Ivan returns safely home. Ivan's father wonders what this transformation signifies, and the answer seems to be that the Firebird's temporary metamorphosis into a dreary-looking crow is a symbolic consequence of Ivan's betrayal by his brothers [...] In Sokolov's novel, many primarily sexual betrayals occur, but also a more wide-ranging metaphysical betrayal. The world portrayed in *Between Dog and Wolf* is marred by spiritual emptiness and pervasive cynicism, and the reference to the Firebird belies the loveliness of the landscape. The Firebird's sad transformation is symbolically akin to the many images of physical and psychological maiming that occur in all three of Sokolov's novels and point to the fractured and fragmented nature of existence" (414). Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8a/Firebird.jpg) Animal motif.
A colloquial emphatic particle.
ru_trans: Разговорная эмфатическая частица.

A hymn sung in Eastern Orthodoxy. Derived from the Greek καταβασία (descent). Colloquial: confusion, row, muddle, mess. Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=efPVfBPrJg4). Sokolov is also playing on the sound similarity between *кат*авасия and кот (tomcat). The same happened to the small boat, which was stolen.
ru_trans: Гимн, поющийся во время восточного православного богослужения. Образовано от греческого καταβασία (схождение). Разговорное: беспорядок, суматоха. Прослушать запись можно [здесь](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=efPVfBPrJg4). Соколов играет на созвучности слов "*кат*авасия" и "кот". То же самое случилось с украденным челноком.

text: Death. The reference is to the biblical Transfiguration of Jesus, in which Jesus goes to a mountaintop to pray with James, John, and Mark. Once there, he begins to shine with light, and Elijah (one of Ilya's identities in the novel) and Moses appear beside him as the voice of God calls out to him. The event is documented in [Matthew 17:1–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2017%3A1-8&version=NIV), [Mark 9:2–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Mark%209%3A2-8&version=NIV), and [Luke 9:28–36](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%209%3A28-36&version=NIV). Celebrated on August 6. The main character of Mikhail Bulgakov's *Heart of a Dog* (a novel which widely circulated in samizdat in the 60s) is Doctor Preobrazhensky, whose experiment of turning a homeless dog into a man leads to tragic consequences (and to his "transfigurating" back into a dog). Locally, this concept and its relationship to death also figures prominently in Note XVIII (R204–205/E95–96).
ru_trans: Смерть. Отсылка к библейскому Преображению Иисуса, когда Иисус поднимается на гору с Иаковом, Иоанном и Марком. Там, на вершине, он начинает сиять, а рядом с ним появляются пророк Илия (одна из личностей Ильи в романе) и Моисей, в то время как к нему взывает Божий голос. Это событие описано в [Матфея 17:1-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+17%3A1-8&version=RUSV), [Марка 9:2-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Mark+9%3A2-8&version=RUSV), [Луки 9:28-36](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke+9%3A28-36&version=RUSV). Празднуется 6 августа. Кроме того, главный герой романа Михаила Булгакова "Сердце собаки" (одно из массовых произведений самиздата 60-ых) — доктор Преображенский, чей эксперимент по превращению бездомного пса в человека ведет к плачевному исходу (и его "преображению" обратно в собаку). Локально, концепция преображения и ее связь со смертью играет значительную роль в Записке XVIII (R204–205/E95–96).

text:
Sour cream typical for Central and Eastern Europe. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Borscht_served.jpg)
According to Ostanin (53), here Sokolov refers to the story of the horse Smetanka, an Arabian stallion that in 1776 was bought from the sultan Abdul Hamid I by count Alexey Orlov for 60,000 rubles, in a time when stallions in Russia sold for approximately 5,000 rubles. Smetanka had 19 ribs on each side, instead of 18. The horse Smetanka is mentioned also in Lev Tolstoy's "Kholstomer".
ru_trans:
Кисломолочный продукт, распространенный в Центральной и Восточной Европе. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Borscht_served.jpg)

Согласно Останину, здесь Соколов ссылается на историю скакуна Сметанки, арабского жеребца, купленного в 1776 году графом Алексеем Орловым у султана Абдула Хамида I за 60 000 рублей, в то время как стандартная цена скаковой лошади в России составляла 5 000 (Ostanin 53). У Сметанки было по 19 ребер с обоих сторон вместо 18. Скакун Сметанка также упоминается в повести Л. Толстого "Холстомер".

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
Dated: often, oftentimes, more than once.
ru_trans: Устаревшее: часто, неоднократно, много раз.

Between dog and wolf. "Blinded" in the sense that it's difficult to make out what is before one's eyes during twilight. The entire Note allegorically plays on one's inability to discern a maple from a tatar maple, similar in their signifier and signified.

text: As in ch. 2, a reference to the saying "Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого" (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme.
Colloquial: an unmarried, lonely (peasant) woman. She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

text: Here, the Finist substitutes for the common pigeon. See the fairy tale "The Feather of Finist the Falcon" (or "Finist the Falcon") collected by Aleksandr Afanas'yev. Read the original [here](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BA%D0%B8_(%D0%90%D1%84%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%B5%D0%B2)/%D0%9F%D1%91%D1%80%D1%8B%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%A4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D1%8F%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0) and an English translation [here](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Russian_Wonder_Tales/The_Feather_of_Finist_the_Falcon). As Margaret Ziolkowski points out, "much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife's lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved's jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find martial bliss, while Il'ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him" (414). Animal motif.

text: As this [blog post](https://anle-mezdu.livejournal.com/23974.html) shows, Sokolov drew many words and combinations from Dal''s dictionary, including those found in this sentence (sensuobsceno). An early review of the novel by Igor Burikhin drew this comparison as well: "[Sokolov's language] can be compared to Dal''s dictionary heard from the gateway, at the historical and metaphysical crossroads of Russia today" (273).

text: An allusion to the story of how Alexander Pushkin, the father of Russian letters, encountered a hare on the road while on his way to support the Decembrist Revolt and took it as a bad omen. text:
Sokolov suggests to interpret it on the basis of the expression "ne velik barin" (not a great gentleman): "this is a way of speaking about a person of modest importance, not important, not noble. For example, the secretary reminds her boss that someone has been waiting in the waiting room for an hour, and the boss replies: 'He is not a great gentleman, he can wait.'
And here Ilya calls the mouse (female in Russian) not a great gentleman, because it is small indeed" (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans:
Соколов предлагает толковать это на основе выражения "не велик барин": "так говорят о человеке скромного значения, не важном, не знатном.
Например, секретарша напоминает своему боссу, что некто ждет в приемной вот уже целый час, а босс отвечает: Не велик барин, подождет. А тут Илья называет мышь невеликой барыней, поскольку она действительно мала" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

text: See the fairy tale "The Feather of Finist the Falcon" (or "Finist the Falcon") collected by Aleksandr Afanas'yev. Read the original [here](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/Народные_русские_сказки_(Афанасьев)/Пёрышко_Финиста_ясна_сокола) and an English translation [here](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Russian_Wonder_Tales/The_Feather_of_Finist_the_Falcon). As Margaret Zhiolkowski points up, "much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife's lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved's jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find marital bliss, while Il'ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him" (414). Animal motif.
ru_trans: См. сказку "Перышко Финиста ясна сокола" ("Финист — ясный сокол"), записанную А. Афанасьевым. Прочитать оригинал сказки можно [здесь](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BA%D0%B8_(%D0%90%D1%84%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%B5%D0%B2)/%D0%9F%D1%91%D1%80%D1%8B%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%A4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D1%8F%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Russian_Wonder_Tales/The_Feather_of_Finist_the_Falcon). Как замечает М. Жиолковски, "подобно тому, как точильщик [Илья] изкалечен под колесами поезда, будучи привязан к рельсам любовниками своей жены, Фенист ранит крылья о ножи и иглы, прикрепленные ревнивыми сестрами к подоконнику его возлюбленной. Тем не менее, Фенист в конце концов познает семейной счастье, тогда как Илья теряет свою жену, когда она тщетно пытается его спасти" (CASS 1987, 414). Мотив животных.

text: A twisted yet evident reference to the Russian writer and thinker Aleksandr Herzen (1812-1870). "Kolokol" (Bell) was the first Russian censorship-free weekly newspaper in Russian (and French) languages; it was launched by Herzen and Nikolai Ogaryov in London (1857–1865) and later Geneva (1865–1867). "Byloe i dumy" (My Past and Thoughts) is Herzen's famous extensive autobiography, a classic of Russian literature.
ru_trans: Скрытая, однако очевидная отсылка к русскому писателю и мыслителю А. Герцену (1812-1870). Газета "Колокол" стала первой вольной еженедельной газетой на русском и французском языках; издавалась Герценом и Н. Огаревым в Лондоне (1857-1865), позже в Женеве (1865-1867). "Былое и думы" — знаменитая развернутая автобиография Герцена, классика русской литературы.

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr's name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels "e/ë" and "o."
ru_trans: Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных "е/ё" и "о".
prefix: ось потом, в теченье поминок по

text: The pre-revolutionary term for the Mari peoples. The Mari live along the Volga and Kama Rivers and in the Mari El, Bashkortostan, and Tatarstan Republics. Martina Napolitano writes, "In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (*zaochnoe obuchenie*) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled *Poznat' prirodu tetivy* (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art" (*Sasha Sokolov*). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: "“I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — "a man from the capital" — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn't bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn't read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar" ("V 'Russkoi mysli'" 11).
ru_trans: Дореволюционное название марийцев. Марийцы живут вдоль рек Волги и Камы, в Респубиках Башкорстан, Татарстан и Марий Эл.

Baknina writes: "The introduction of Bruegel's images into the artistic world of the novel is an extensions of the boundaries of the key images of Zaitilshchina. [...] This wonderful phrase [...] speaks to how the world Beyond the Volga is limitless" (183).

Эта замечательная фраза (а в романе Саши Соколова все выверено до буковки!) говорит о том, что мир Заволчья безграничен" (Baknina 183).

He refused to have his leg amputated: he considered it unacceptable for the dignity of a king; on the territory of the Versailles palace he moved thanks to a special wheeled chair” (70).

text: Ostanin (43) suggests to interpret his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). He also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.
ru_trans: Останин предлагает интерпретировать эту фамилию как вариацию "Паломахеров" (от глагола "палить"), что характеризует разжигающего (или тушащего) огонь человека. На этой ноте, стоит вспомнить завершающие строки романа: "Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки" (R280/E230). Останин также замечает, что фамилия, возможно, берет начало от Григория Паламы, греческого православного богослова XIV века, известного обоснованием духовной практики исихаизма (Ostanin 43).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
ru_trans: Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов "город" и "нищий". Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: "Если *Школа для дураков* была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, *Между собакой и волком* можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых" (Matich "Sasha Sokolov" 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid "Zaitil'shchina" 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson "Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

text: Colloquial: the departed. That is, Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr. On a different level, one may read this as a reference to Sokolov's mother and aunt who used to tell him stories about their native Siberia: "My aunt, my mother's sister, mostly raised me. She was a woman of the old regime, strict. She graduated from a classical gymnasium in Novonikolaevsky and knew exactly how good gentlemen should behave. She read out loud beautifully, told miraculous stories, and sang Siberian songs" (Vrubel'-Golubkina, "Sasha Sokolov").

Dated: February. бок (side) + греть (to warm). As Boguslawski translates it, "side-warmer," meaning a shift in weather that will warm your sides. A reference to St. Sidor Bokogrei, whose day is celebrated on May 14/27. He was given this name, because it was said that bitterly cold northern winds would stop blowing on this date. Likewise, swifts and swallows would fly to Sidor with the approach of warm weather. However, people caution against taking the appearance of the first bird as a sure sign of the cold's departure, similar to the following clause. Read his saint's life [here](https://religion.wikireading.ru/100944). The addressee of Ilya's letter is, of course, Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Animal motif.

text: Set expression: March will leave you without pants. The meaning is that March, as a transitional month between winter and spring, brings with it some challenges: occasional unexpected shifts in weather, low resources before the harvest.

Another variation on Ilya's unusual last name (which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book). It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker's essay, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). add to the English: However, as Korovashko suggests, "Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella 'squared': if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence" (277).

Toker, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). text: See the fairy tale "The Feather of Finist the Falcon" (or "Finist the Falcon") collected by Aleksandr Afanas'yev. Read the original [here](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BA%D0%B8_(%D0%90%D1%84%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%B5%D0%B2)/%D0%9F%D1%91%D1%80%D1%8B%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%A4%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0_%D1%8F%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0) and an English translation [here](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Russian_Wonder_Tales/The_Feather_of_Finist_the_Falcon). As Margaret Ziolkowski points out, "much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife's lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved's jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find martial bliss, while Il'ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him" (414). Animal motif.

text: Mari: no, there is not. Martina Napolitano writes, "In 1968 Sokolov eventually chose to register as a non-attending student (*zaochnoe obuchenie*) due to his frustration with city life. He moved to the village of Morki in the Mari Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic with Taisiia Suvorova, a fellow student and his first wife until 1974. He then concluded his studies in 1971, having already started to collaborate with the prestigious “Literaturnaia gazeta” mainly submitting book and art reviews. His last article published on the pages of this weekly magazine, titled *Poznat' prirodu tetivy* (Knowing the nature of the bowstring), was dedicated to Mari poets. In this text, Sokolov expressed his appreciation for the first translations that appeared in Russian, but also included general reflections concerning poetry and art" (*Sasha Sokolov*). In a review with Kira Sapgir, Sokolov stated the following: “I believed that the work of a journalist would lead me faster to real prose. And since you can write more freely not in the central newspaper, but in a peripheral one, I switched to the correspondence department and left for the Mari Republic. I worked in a district newspaper, in a village, a hundred kilometers from Yoshkar-Ola. I was 22 years old. My appearance there — 'a man from the capital' — was somewhat stunning. As a result, I wasn't bothered, and I could write whatever I wanted, I could even afford to experiment. I wrote mainly essays about people: I took the surname, first name, and patronymic of a person, and invented his whole life. These were, in fact, stories, and the hero could be a gamekeeper, forester, innkeeper, anyone. These were short story-essays written in rhythmic prose: if you like, close to the style of Andrei Bely, although at that time I hadn't read anything about him or his work itself. The first time I read Bely was here, abroad, and I was surprised: it looks similar" ("V Russkoi mysli" 11).
ru_trans: Означает "нет" на марийском.

— снасть э-э́,

text: Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb *gulyat'* is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina will be defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person," and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

text: Sokolov writes, "At some point I read 'Mikhei Marafetin' in some text. I can't find any evidence of that now. I found two variants: Morasfitianin and Morasfitin. So, let's change it to Morasfitin" ("Bol'shoe" 133).
ru_trans: Соколов пишет: Некогда в каком-то тексте я прочел: Михей Марафетин. Сейчас нигде подтверждения этому не нашел. Нашел два других варианта: Морасфитянин и Морасфитин. Исправим на Морасфитин, короче" (Sokolov "Bol'shoe" 133).

text: Dated/literary: to heed, listen, hark. A possible allusion to the end of Alexander Pushkin's famous 1826 poem "The Prophet," in which a seraph commands the poet to "arise [...] watch and hark." Read the original and a translation [here](https://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm).

A [city](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Millerovo,+Rostov+Oblast,+Russia/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x411ee3aa865e9805:0x33cce3efc853ac80?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwi86MT57Pz8AhUeEFkFHRJXChsQ8gF6BAhoEAE) in the Rostov Oblast of Russia. Ostanin (51) notes that this town recalls the English term "miller," which once again touches upon the theme of mills/flour.
ru_trans: [Город](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Millerovo,+Rostov+Oblast,+Russia/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x411ee3aa865e9805:0x33cce3efc853ac80?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwi86MT57Pz8AhUeEFkFHRJXChsQ8gF6BAhoEAE) в Ростовской области в России. Останин замечает, что название города напоминает английское слово "miller" ("мельник"), опять же, возвращаясь к теме мельницы/муки (Ostanin 51).

text: Now the narration goes back to Yakov Il'ich. His unskilled cunning (his inability to lie and pretend, which was mentioned at the beginning of the chapter) is paired with that of his great-grandfather in pretending he's having luck at play.

text: Russianized Latin: postscript. The novel's final poem is called "Post Scriptum" (R279–280/E229–230). In it, Yakov both questions the purpose of his writings and challenges the reader to describe his "ingenious" lines.
Colloquial: to spend some time lying about.
prefix: ешь с неделю там, порыбалишь да

text: The name Emeli'an (Emil) is derived from the Latin *aemulus* which means rival, literally "emulator." In this context, it's a fitting name given the relationship between Ilya and his brother, as well as the fluid nature of the divisions between characters' identities. Aemilianus was also briefly Roman emperor in 253. Ostanin notes that Emel'yan was also the name of Pugachyov, a Cossack ataman who led a popular insurrection during the reign of Catherine the Great (52). His figure turned literary thanks to Pushkin and his historical novel *The Captain's Daughter* (1836).
ru_trans: Имя Емельян (Эмиль) образовано от латинского *aemilianus*, что означает "соперник", буквально "эмулятор" ("подражатель"). В данном контексте, это отлично подходящее имя, учитывая отношения между Ильей и его братом, а также размытые границы между личностями персонажей. Эмилиан также недолго был римским императором в 253 году. Останин замечает, что Емельяном также звали казацкого атамана, предводителя крупного восстания во время правления Екатерины Великой (Ostanin 52). Его образ стал литературным благодаря Пушкину и его исторической повести Капитанская дочка (1836).
