вто рой 
весь день. Милый брат,

text: Ostanin remarks that this is a "mystery for the annotator" (27). Sokolov responds: "Sometime in the 20th century the pin turned 500 years old, probably English [...] At some point I read about this in some journal [...] Now I can't find this information on the Net" ("Bol'shoe pis'mo" 126).As Caramitti has noted in his dissertation (130), "the pin appeared in England in 1443". 500 years after, Sokolov was born (1943).
ru_trans: Останин замечает, что это "загадка для комментатора" (Ostanin 27). Соколов отвечает: "Где-то в середине 20 века исполнилось 500 лет булавке, вероятно, английской […] Я в свое время об этом прочел в каком-то журнале […] Теперь не могу найти этой информации в Инете" (Ostanin "Bol'shoe pis'mo" 126). Как отмечает в своей диссертации Карамитти, "булавка появилась в Англии в 1443 году" (Caramitti 130). Спустя 500 лет родился Соколов (1943).

That is, Yakov, the hunchbacked whipper-in.

Ilya says старице rather than старости (old age). A female religious elder, a nun. Also a city on the Volga in the Tver Oblast. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/View_of_Staritsa.jpg) Ostanin notes a meaning connection: Staritsa — Pozhilykh — Zhivago — Vetkhii Den'mi (Ancient of Days) (64).
ru_trans:
Илья говорит "старица" вместо "старость". Пожилая религиозная женщина, монахиня. Также город на Волге в Тверской области. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/View_of_Staritsa.jpg)

Останин отмечает важную цепочку: Старица — Пожилых — Живаго — Ветхий Днями (Ostanin 64).

text: Sokolov explains: "Cockroaches often infest houses in Northern villages. Village cockroaches differ from city cockroaches: village cockroaches are bigger, but they are nicer: they are black, not yellow, and not so arrogant. In poor farms there are not many cockroaches or none: there is nothing for them to do in the canteen - food is scarce. But in the terem, as Ilya probably thinks, people live richer, they have more food and, therefore, lots of cockroaches" (personal communication, June 7, 2023). Animal motif.
ru_trans: Соколов объясняет: "В домах северных деревень нередко заводятся тараканы. Деревенские тараканы отличаются от городских: деревенские крупнее, но симпатичнее: хотя бы потому, что они черные, а не желтые, и не такие наглые. В бедных хозяйствах тараканов мало или они отсутствуют: там ведь по буфету особенно не разгуляешься - скудная там снедь. А в теремах, как, вероятно, думает Илья, живут люди побогаче, еды у них, значит, больше и, следовательно, имеется много тараканов" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

text: Colloquial: chaos, disorder. A variation on the expression "кутерьма буревая" used at the very end of chapter 4. According to Ostanin (42), this expression is a quotation from Nadezhda Pavlovich's poem "Beregom, beregom, s razbegu…" Read the original [here](https://slova.org.ru/pavlovich/beregomberegom/).
High: outrage, villainy, atrocity, evil deed.
Colloquial: to steal, pilfer.

text: The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya's letter "Zaitil'shchina" is derived from this version of the river's name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil' and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools* (10).

text: Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -ий.

text: Sokolov explains: "'plesnut' vzdrok' means to pour to the edge of the glass. I have not found this word in the dictionaries, but I heard it more than once on the Volga, so it can be considered a regional, local word. However, the dictionaries have synonyms equal to it in expressiveness: vsklyan', vsklen', vskray, vzrez', vzdroch'. Going to town, Ilya plans to have a nice rest there and rhetorically asks the city to be generous, in particular, to treat him with alcohol, to pour him, Ilya, a full glass, and, of course, not only one. I remember an ironic phraseologism about a heavy drinker: he doesn't drink at all, but he pours a glass full (nalivaet vsklen')" (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: Соколов объясняет: "'плеснуть вздрок' значит - налить до края стакана. В словарях это слово я не нашел, но на Волге не раз слышал, наверное, его можно считать областным, местным. Однако в словарях наличествуют равные ему по выразительности синонимы: всклянь, всклень, вскрай, взрезь, вздрочь. Направляясь в город, Илья планирует славно там отдохнуть и риторически просит его быть щедрым, в частности, как следует угостить спиртным, налить ему, Илье, полный стакан, причем, разумеется, не один. Фразеологизм помню такой, иронический, про сильно пьющего человека: Не пьет совсем, а наливает всклень" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

An instrument similar to the tambourine. The main difference is that some bubens have metal rings, plates, cymbals, or bells attached. Also mentioned in chapter 1 by Ilya ("брюзжи себе под дугою хоть до Валдай-пристани — литье бубенчиков" [R150/E2]) and in chapter 3 in one of Yakov's poems ("Некто с бубном бредет пелесками" [R169/E35]). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5c/Ukr_folk_05.jpg)
ru_trans: Бубен — инструмент, напоминающий тамбурин. Основное отличие от тамбурина заключается в том, что у бубнам обычно подвешены металлические кольца или колокольчики. Упоминается Ильей в главе 1 ("брюзжи себе под дугою хоть до Валдай-пристани — литье бубенчиков" [R150/E2]) и в главе 3, в одном из стихов Якова ("Некто с бубном бредет пелесками" [R169/E35]). Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5c/Ukr_folk_05.jpg)

text: The name Emeli'an (Emil) is derived from the Latin *aemulus* which means rival, literally "emulator." In this context, it's a fitting name given the relationship between Ilya and his brother, as well as the fluid nature of the divisions between characters' identities. Aemilianus was also briefly Roman emperor in 253. Ostanin notes that Emel'yan was also the name of Pugachyov, a Cossack ataman who led a popular insurrection during the reign of Catherine the Great (52). His figure turned literary thanks to Pushkin and his historical novel *The Captain's Daughter* (1836).
ru_trans: Имя Емельян (Эмиль) образовано от латинского *aemilianus*, что означает "соперник", буквально "эмулятор" ("подражатель"). В данном контексте, это отлично подходящее имя, учитывая отношения между Ильей и его братом, а также размытые границы между личностями персонажей. Эмилиан также недолго был римским императором в 253 году. Останин замечает, что Емельяном также звали казацкого атамана, предводителя крупного восстания во время правления Екатерины Великой (Ostanin 52). Его образ стал литературным благодаря Пушкину и его исторической повести Капитанская дочка (1836).

text: Word used in set expressions (зги нет, ни зги, зги не видать, ни зги не видать, ни зги не видно: что бы то ни было, Слепой слепого водит, а оба зги не видят) meaning that nothing is visible. According to Dal''s dictionary, зга means "темь, потемки, темнота" (darkness). This definition presents a complication, as the phrase "ни зги не видать" would come to mean "no darkness is visible" (so dark that even the darkness is obscured). However, Dal' also proposes that the word зга originated from "стьга" (path, road), which would make more logical sense in the various expressions that use зга. According to yet another version, Sokolov's "favorite," a зга is a ring on a yoke, which a driver couldn't see in the dark ("Bol'shoe pis'mo" 126).
ru_trans: Слово, использующееся в выражениях "зги нет, ни зги, зги не видать, ни зги не видать, ни зги не видно: что бы то ни было, Слепой слепого водит, а оба зги не видят", означающих, что ничего не видно. Согласно словарю Даля, "зга" означает "темь, потемки, темнота". Такое определение вызывает некоторые затруднения, ведь тогда фраза "ни зги не видать" должна значить "не видно темноты" (так темно, что даже тьма становится невидимой). Однако, Даль предполагает, что слово "зга" происходит от  "стьга" (путь, дорога), что придает больше смысла значениям со словом "зга". Согласно еще одной, "любимой" версии Соколова, "зга" означает кольцо на упряжке, которое извозчик не видит в темноте (Соколов, "Большое письмо" 126).

text: A paraphrase of the expression "Лучше синица в руках, чем журавль в небе" (literally: It's better to have a tit in your hands than a crane in the sky), meaning it's better to have something feasible and attainable than an unattainable dream that remains out of reach. The English equivalent is "A bird in the hand is better than two in the bush." Animal motif.
ru_trans: Перефразированное выражение "Лучше синица в руках, чем журавль в небе", означающее, что лучше иметь нечто доступное и реальное, чем недостижимую цель или мечту. В английском варианте "A bird in the hand is better than two in the bush" (буквально: Птица в руке лучше двух в кусте). Мотив животных.

text: Lapwings have traditionally been associated with misbehaving women (Rowland 97). José Vergara writes: "Maria/Orina is regularly correlated with deceptions and betrayal, often sexual in nature, so the reference to the lapwings has some internal logic. Her squealing evokes the folklore of the naughty birds" in key scenes throughout the novel, and the "sounds of the bird thus echo throughout the book’s architecture. Even when not physically present, Maria’s presence can be felt here, as the longing the two heroes feel for each other manifests in the creaking sounds" ("Flap" 367–368). Animal-human motif.
Poetic: time, year.

text: The novel's sense of time is likewise brazenly distorted. Death is meaningless as the deceased can still communicate with the living, and time moves at different speeds along the various points of the Volga. Krylobyl explains this conception of time in  chapter 14 (R255/E186–187).
ru_trans: Восприятие времени в романа так же откровенно искажено. Смерть бессмысленна, ведь умершие все равно могут взаимодействовать с живыми, а время течет с неодинаковой скоростью в разных местах Волги. Крылобыл объясняет эту концепцию времени в главе 14 (R255/E186–187).

text: A reference to the saying "Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого" (Hiccups, hiccups, go to Fedot, from Fedot to Yakov, from Yakov to everyone). This proverb derives from the folk belief that hiccups (a disease or demonic invasion) could be passed from one person to another. This hiccup (and the barrel further below) develops also the recurrent drinking theme.
ru_trans: Отсылка к поговорке "Икота, икота, уйди на Федота, с Федота на Якова, с Якова на всякого". Происходит от народного поверья, что икота (болезнь или бесовское вмешательство) может передаваться от одного человека другому. Икота (как и нижеупомянутая бочка) превращается в повторяющуюся тему пьянства.

text: A sign of Ilya's illiteracy: the correct verb should be tsitirovat' (first person singular: *tsitiruiu*).
Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -oго.
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ого.

The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr's name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

text: A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg). Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 8 (R209/E103), and chapter 9 (R214/E112). text: Diminutive form of Yakov.

Another variation on Ilya's unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker's essay, "Gamesman's Sketches (Found in a Bottle)," CASS 21.3-4: 356). It is here spelled even closer to that of Cinderella. However, as Korovashko suggests, "Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella 'squared': if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence" (277).
October 14 (1, old calendar). In this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet.
ru_trans: 14 октября (1 по старому стилю). В этот день, согласно народному поверью, встречаются осень и зима.

text: At this point, the reader understands that Krylobyl (here named through his diminutive) is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river, in Vydogoshch). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it was Krylobyl who advanced the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: The end of chapter 2 and chapter 5 were some of the earliest pieces of *Between Dog and Wolf* written. D. Barton Johnson reports: "This initial focus on Iakov, rather than Illia, emerges from the fragment of *Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom* that Sokolov to Carl Professor for the first number of Ardis' new serial miscellany *Glagol* (1977). [...] Much of this material, deleted in the final version, sets forth the book's central theme of indeterminacy much more explicitly than anything in the final variant. The *Glagol* excerpt was abstruse and Proffer's response was 'almost complete incomprehension' (letter to Sokolov of August 26, 1976). [...] In his reply of August 15, 1976, Sokolov suggested that Carl Proffer's doubts echoed his own. The material had been written under difficult psychological circumstances. He had wanted to parody various styles, but felt he had not succeeded. He now proposed that the fragment be published in *Glagol* but with the idea that it would remain suspended [...] The excerpt's opening and closing passages with their descriptions of Iakov and the excursus on his name/identity were deleted" ("Background Notes" 337–338). Along similar lines, author Tatyana Tolstaya has expressed frustration with the novel's complexities: "Although it is a beautifully and very intricately crafted novel, the average reader cannot make it to the end and cannot recover its meanings. They are too secret. The reader does not feel like solving some of those crossword puzzles. [...] It is ill advised to give readers tasks that are too complicated before they are capable of solving them" (Genis, "Lessons" 346–347).

text: In ancient Russia, a *sloboda* referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, *sloboda* refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a [Sloboda](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sloboda,+Tver+Oblast,+Russia,+171265/@56.6543229,36.4671174,12.92z/data=!4m6!3m5!1s0x46b4337b61338bc3:0xfd78ee1285635920!8m2!3d56.6502347!4d36.4718922!16s%2Fg%2F12xpjjzgs?entry=ttu) can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans: В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова "свобода". Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, "слобода" в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

text: Fish belonging to the Carassius genus and Cyprinidae family. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/CarassiusCarassius8.JPG) Animal motif. This same question, as well as this general scene, first appears in chapter 1 (R157/E15). Alexander Boguslawski notes: "Sokolov increases the artistic impact of these two descriptions by combining images with skillful manipulation of the lexical material. It is easy to see the delicate modulations of the phrase about the carp, achieved by synonymic substitutions *prishchurilsia – prigliadelsia* and *dremali – kemarli* as well as by replacement of *zdes' gde* by *tut u nas* and of *ershi eti samye* by *mne vzbrelo vdrug*" ("How Sokolov's" 215).
ru_trans:
Рыба из семейства Карповых, род Караси. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/CarassiusCarassius8.JPG) 

Мотив животных. Этот же вопрос, как и эта же сцена в целом, повторяется Ильей в главе 1 (R157/E15). А. Богуславский замечает: "Соколов усиляет художественное воздействие этих двух описаний путем соединения визуальных образов с мастерски использованным лексическим материалом. Несложно заметить легкие модуляции фраз, описывающих карасей, выполненные путем синонимичных замещений *прищучился – пригляделся* и *дремали – кемарили*, а также замена *здесь где* на *тут у нас* и *ерши эти самые* на *мне взбрело вдруг*" (Boguslawski, "How Sokolov's" 215).
suffix: -то здесь где, ерши эти самые? П

text: Dated: bush. Typically used in the phrase Неопалимая купина (Burning Bush). According to the [Book of Exodus](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+3&version=NIV), Moses was given his charge to lead the Israelites out of Egypt at the Burning Bush.

text: The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr's name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels "e/ë" and "o."
ru_trans: Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных "е/ё" и "о".

text: One such aforementioned *chastushka*. Listen to a rendition [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fJ40QKaD2Ws).

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
Blue pigment for dying. Colloquial: a state of true drunkenness. Also here, the color of the sky.
ru_trans: Синий пигмент или краситель. Разговорное: стадия глубокого опьянения. Здесь относится к синему цвету неба.

It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: поругание).Typo: пОругание.
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "поругание").

text: Low: payday, paycheck.

The word "besprizornyj/besprizornik" appeared in the Soviet era, and according to the [National corpus of the Russian language](https://processing.ruscorpora.ru/graphic.xml?graphic_from_result=1&lang=ru&mode=main&nodia=1&req=беспризорный&smoothing=3&sort=i_grstd&text=lexform#toggle), it was typical in print in particular between 1920s-1940s. Literally meaning "unsupervised", it was usually used to refer to homeless children, orphans. Boris Zhitkov, author of children's books (1882-1938), wrote a short story titled "Besprizornaya koshka" (Unsupervised cat), published in his volume *Rasskazy o zhivotnykh* (Short Stories about Animals), 1935.

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps?output=search&q=bydgoszcz&entry=mc&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj4_sT8sbb_AhUaGVkFHWvIBHAQ0pQJegQICxAB) (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).
Colloquial: cur, small dog. Animal motif.
ru_trans: Разговорное: дворняга, мелкая собака. Мотив животных.

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

Watch the film [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVpmZnRIMKs). See Smith's "Underground Songs" for more information and context on this style of music in the Soviet Union. Describing publisher Carl Proffer's difficulties understanding Sokolov's drafts of the novel, D. Barton Johnson writes: "Sokolov was surprised at this and later reactions: 'It was my first clash with reality. I hadn't even known [the thing] was complex. No idea. I thought I had written on the level that [Vladimir] Vysotskii writes song lyrics' (DBJ interview June 20, 1983)" ("Background Notes" 339). Railroad theme.

text: The phraseologism (as elsewhere in the book) turns real as they both have only one leg. Furthermore, D.B. Johnson, writes: "The proverbial idea 'two books make a pair' supports the suggestion that the two men are related, although the point is made more forcefully (and grotesquely) by their sharing (and stealing) a single set of footwear. It also hints at the intergrading of personalities so typical of the murky world between dog and wolf. The other function is more speculative. Both father and son are lame. They do not know each other. The son is destined to kill the father. It appears that they have both loved the same woman, i.e. the mentally defective girl who shares much of her past (including the slipper episode) with Orina, the wife and mother. The parallel to the Oedipus legend is striking: father and son are lame (cf. the etymologies of Laios and Oedipus), they do not recognize each other, the son kills the father, and loves (a version of) his mother" ("The Galoshes Manifesto"165). Shoe motif.
ru_trans: Фразеологизм (как и в других местах в романе) воплощается в жизнь, ведь у них обоих есть только по одной ноге.

text: Orina's body arouses Ilya. Beyond being considered a silly or stupid animal, the goose has other resonances. According to Beryl Rowland, the goose has been seen as "an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses" (68). Connections between geese, sexuality, and foolishness appear several times in the novel (R154, 210, 221/E10, 106, 126). A reference to Ivan Krylov's "Geese" (1811). Read the original [here](https://rvb.ru/18vek/krylov/01text/vol3/01fables/096.htm) and a translation [here](https://chekhitout.wordpress.com/2012/04/30/i-may-provoke-the-geese/). Animal-human motif.
ru_trans: Тело Орины возбуждает Илью. Помимо современного восприятия гусей как глупых существ, гуси могут иметь и другие символические значения. Согласно Роуленду, гуси традиционно воспринимались как "эротический символ обоих полов, будь то в форме солнца, олицетворяющего мужских богов, или луны, олицетворяющей богинь-матерей" (Rowland 68). Подобные связи между гусями, сексуальностью и глупостью встречаются далее в романе (R154, 210, 221/E10, 106, 126). Отсылка к басне И. Крылова "Гуси" (1811). Прочитать оригинал можно [здесь](https://rvb.ru/18vek/krylov/01text/vol3/01fables/096.htm), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://chekhitout.wordpress.com/2012/04/30/i-may-provoke-the-geese/). Мотив животных.

An 1829 poem by Alexander Pushkin. As Ostanin underlines, Pushkin dedicated it to the 16-year-old Ekaterina Vel’yasheva, whom he met in the Tver estate of P. Osipova-Vul'f by the river T'ma, tributary to the Volga (71). Read the original [here](https://www.culture.ru/poems/5707/podezzhaya-pod-izhory) and an English translation [here](https://aleksandr-pushkin.su/podezzhaya-pod-izhory/?lang=en).

text: Again a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels "e/ë" and "o". A prime example of what Leona Toker calls Sokolov's "forking characters" ("Gamesman's Sketches" 354).
ru_trans: В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных "е/ё" и "о". Яркий пример того, что Л. Токер называет "расходящимися (разветвляющимися) персонажами" (Toker "Gamesman's Sketches" 354).

text: The highest ranked Christian angel class, the seraphim are best known from the [Book of Isaiah (6:1–8)](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%98%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B8%D1%8F%206%3A1-8&version=RUSV,NIV): "In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying. And they were calling to one another: 'Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory.'" They are also mentioned in Alexander Pushkin's seminal 1826 poem "The Prophet": "Tormented by a spiritual thirst, / I stumbled through a gloomy waste, / And there a six-winged seraph / Appeared before me at the crossroad." Read the original and this English translation [here](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm). Previously mentioned in chapter 4 (R180/E54).
ru_trans: Серафимы —  высший ангельский чин, описаны в книге [Исаии 6:1-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%98%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B8%D1%8F%206%3A1-8&version=RUSV,NIV): "В год смерти царя Озии видел я Господа, сидящего на престоле высоком и превознесенном, и края риз Его наполняли весь храм. Вокруг Него стояли Серафимы; у каждого из них по шести крыл: двумя закрывал каждый лице свое, и двумя закрывал ноги свои, и двумя летал. И взывали они друг ко другу и говорили: Свят, Свят, Свят Господь Саваоф! вся земля полна славы Его!". Также упоминаются в судьбоносном стихотворении А. Пушкина 1826 года "Пророк": "Духовной жаждою томим, / В пустыне мрачной я влачился, - / И шестикрылый серафим / На перепутьи мне явился". Прочитать стихотворение в оригинале и английском переводе можно [здесь](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm). Упоминались ранее в главе 4 (R180/E54).

text: Similar phrasing is used in chapter four: "В эту пору, траченный бытовыми невзгодами и хлесткими обложными ливнями" ("At that moment, worn out by everyday hardships and by lashin incessant downpours") (R174/E44). As Kravchenko notes, the "everyday needs" mentioned here likely mean that Yakov has been using the book for smoking and toilet paper (*The Prose* 67).
ru_trans: Похожая формулировка встречается в главе 4: "В эту пору, траченный бытовыми невзгодами и хлесткими обложными ливнями" (R174/E44). Как замечает Кравченко, под использованием для "повседневных нужд", вероятно, подразумевается использование Яковом книги для курения и в качестве туалетной бумаги (Kravchenko, "The Prose" 67).

Ostanin suggests that Ilya's train ticket number calls to mind both George Orwell's *1984* (1948) and the number of letters in the Jewish alphabet (103). Railroad theme.No idea. text: This description brings to mind Alexander Pushkin (1799-1837), Russia's national poet. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/56/Kiprensky_Pushkin.jpg)

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: the grapheme "i" was left out of the Russian Cyrillic alphabet after the 1918 reform (today this word would be spelled as follows: библиотеки).
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: графема "i" была исключена из русского кирилличекого алфавита после реформы 1918 года (сегодня правильное написание слова было бы "библиотеки").

text: Ostanin (43) suggests to interpret his last name as a variation of "Palamakherov" (from the verb palit', to burn), meaning someone who starts (or stops) fires. On that note, it would be worth recalling that final lines of the novel are "So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell, / My amazing, ingenious lines!" ("Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки") (R280/E230). He also observes that the name may find its origin in Gregory Palamas (in Russian, Palama), a Byzantine Greek theologian lived in the 14th century, known for his defense of hesychast spirituality.
ru_trans: Останин предлагает интерпретировать эту фамилию как вариацию "Паломахеров" (от глагола "палить"), что характеризует разжигающего (или тушащего) огонь человека. На этой ноте, стоит вспомнить завершающие строки романа: "Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка, / Мои гениальные строчки" (R280/E230). Останин также замечает, что фамилия, возможно, берет начало от Григория Паламы, греческого православного богослова XIV века, известного обоснованием духовной практики исихаизма (Ostanin 43).
chapter: 05. Ловчая повесть, или картинки с выставки

text: That is, the hunters scribble their response to Ilya's missive on birch bark. An allusion to the renowned Novgorod birch bark manuscripts.
Birch bark. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/be/Birkenstamm_mit_Ameise.jpg?uselang=ru) Plant motif.
Dated: together, collectively.

Since the narration moves back in time to the 19th century, the orthography is also consequently dated: this adjectival ending today would be -ий. The word was previously used in Zapiska IX and will appear again in further chapters: while used in its literal sense elsewhere (a senior dog handler, who trains hounds for the hunt), here the word occurs in an unusual context, as Yakov is described as "a time handler" or, more precisely, "a handler of his practical and merciless time."
ru_trans: Так как повествование возвращается во времени к XIX веку, орфография соответствует эпохе: сегодня, правильное окончание прилагательного должно было бы быть -ий.

Boguslawski identifies this line as a reference to Nikolai Nekrasov's 1864 poem "The Railway" ("Annotations" 248). Read the original Russian [here](https://www.culture.ru/poems/39557/zheleznaya-doroga). Railroad motif.

text: A reference to Samuil Marshak's children's poem "Master-lomaster." Read the original [here](https://www.culture.ru/poems/42779/master-lomaster) and an English translation [here](https://en.miloliza.com/index.php/marshak-s-poems-for-children/34-marshak/1857-master-lomaster).

highlighted: и воспомнил ваши взоры, ваши синие глаза
text: Another couple lines from Alexander Pushkin's 1829 poem, "As I Drove Up to Izhory." Read the original [here](https://www.culture.ru/poems/5707/podezzhaya-pod-izhory) and an English translation [here](https://aleksandr-pushkin.su/podezzhaya-pod-izhory/?lang=en).

Throughout the novel, geese are associated with sexual arousal. Here, they are linked to the Dama's appearance in the hunters' company. Although today far more commonly considered silly or stupid, geese have a lofty mythology. The goose has been traditional viewed as “an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses" (Rowland 68). Similar connections between geese, sexuality, and foolishness appear elsewhere in the novel (R210, 221/E106, 125). Animal-human motif.
ru_trans: На протяжении романа, гуси ассоциируются с сексуальным возбуждением. Здесь, они связаны с появлением Дамы в компании охотников. Несмотря на современное восприятие гусей как глупых существ, мифологическая история этих птиц весьма благородна. Гуси традиционно воспринимались как "эротический символ обоих полов, будь то в форме солнца, олицетворяющего мужских богов, или луны, олицетворяющей богинь-матерей" (Rowland 68). Подобные связи между гусями, сексуальностью и глупостью встречаются далее в романе (R210, 221/E106, 125).

text: That is, the people of the cemetery (the undertakers). In chapter 1, Ilya mentions the village of Bydogoshch, of which Bygodozhd' could be an ironic variant (-dozhd' meaning "rain") (R158/E16). As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps?output=search&q=bydgoszcz&entry=mc&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj4_sT8sbb_AhUaGVkFHWvIBHAQ0pQJegQICxAB) (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).

text: The mythical Firebird from Slavic folklore. Read the original [here](https://xn----7sbb5adknde1cb0dyd.xn--p1ai/%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BA%D0%B0-%D0%B6%D0%B0%D1%80-%D0%BF%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B0/) and an English translation [here](http://www.artrusse.ca/fairytales/firebird.htm). Margaret Ziolkowski writes: "Here the Firebird has becomes [sic] an explicit metaphor for an evanescent happiness. Moreover, while the folktale Firebird never changes into a person, in Sokolov's novel the Firebird symbolically acquires a human identity. Thus the traveller did not recognize the real Firebird, who might actually have made his dreams come true, in the woman encountered years before" (415). Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8a/Firebird.jpg) Animal motif.

Again, the twilight hour brings confusion and uncertainty to the novel's events. Writing about *A School for Fools*, Dmitry Danilov says that in his art Sokolov captures "a world of uncertainty that is a world of continuous cognition that fails to ossify" ("Shkola neopredelennosti").
ru_trans: Вновь, час сумерек вносит смятение и неопределенность в события романа. Описывая *Школу для дураков*, Д. Данилов замечает, что Соколов в своем творчестве запечатлевает "мир неопределенности — мир непрерывного, не успевающего закостенеть познания" (Danilov, "Shkola neopredelennosti" 4).

text: Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe. In Ovid’s *Metamorphoses* Tereus is transformed into a hoopoe and searches for his missing family, calling out "where, where" in the bird's famous song. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. Most importantly here, "Ilya closes the loop, so to speak, when he calls Orina 'you swallow of mine,' while bemoaning how she took his son from him. He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family, but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" (Vergara, "Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.

An allusion to the story of how Alexander Pushkin, the father of Russian letters, encountered a hare on the road while on his way to support the Decembrist Revolt and took it as a bad omen. "Кучерявый" (curly), a trait Pushkin is well known for, further strengthens this allusion.  Here, the curly-headed quality has shifted from the hare in line 22 of the poem to the lyric persona.

text: As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps?output=search&q=bydgoszcz&entry=mc&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj4_sT8sbb_AhUaGVkFHWvIBHAQ0pQJegQICxAB) (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).

text: Dated: from the valley.

Time flows unnaturally in the novel. One possible implication here is that Ilya has or will experience(d) *other* existences. Ashcheulova, linking Sokolov's writing to that of Valentin Kataev (1897–1986), comments on this theme of "transformations and displacements in time and space" that "create an image of life and death that endlessly repeat" ("Tvorchestvo" 137). For more on Sokolov and Kataev, see Borden's "Time, Backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev" and "Toward a Postmodern 'Bad': Sasha Sokolov."

text: In Greek mythology Helios (god and personification of the Sun) is depicted as driving a horse-drawn chariot through the sky. This myth mixed up with the Roman myth of Apollo, also depicted as driving a chariot carrying the sun through the sky.

text: The reference to Albatrasov the sailor in the next sentence brings to mind Coleridge's *The Rime of the Ancient Mariner* (read it [here](https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/43997/the-rime-of-the-ancient-mariner-text-of-1834)), in which a sailor is compelled to wear an albatross he has killed around his neck in penance. Addressing the latter subtext's image of a bird wrapped around a sailor's neck in penance, José Vergara writes, "Albatrosov is an embodiment of Ilya’s perceived betrayal by Orina, who it is said, sleeps with a number of sailors under the aforementioned overturned boat on the banks of the Volga, as well as guilt over his own actions. Ilya takes on his sorrow when he meets Albatrosov on a train after his separation from Orina. The avian-sailor thus serves to remind Ilya of the past he cannot escape. [...] The anthropomorphized bird imagery, in this way, underscores Ilya’s lingering psychological trauma, both that which he himself caused and that which he received" ("Flap" 372). Animal-human motif.

text: As Ostanin suggests (38), in Botfortovo Ilya mixes up the term "botforty" (Peter the Great's favorite boots), the last name of one of the Emperor's close associates, François Le Fort (or Lefort; 1656-1699), and the Lefortovo district in Moscow, founded in 1699 and named after him. The narrator in chapter 9 does the same (R215/E115). Shoe motif.
ru_trans: Как предполагает Останин, в слове "Ботфортово" Илья путает "ботфорты" (любимые сапоги Петра Великого) с именем одного из приближенных императора, Франца Яковлевича Лефорта (1656-1699), и районом Лефортово в Москве, основанного в 1699 году и названного в его честь. Рассказчик делает то же самое в главе 9 (R215/E115). Мотив обуви.

text: "Moist Mother Earth" is the personified representation of the earth in Slavic mythology. It is also the title of a povest' by Boris Pil'nyak (1925). Olga Matich already pointed out at the similarities between Pil'nyak's text "about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War" and *Between Dog and Wolf*: "It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story's many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina's maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf" ("Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context" 312).
suffix: , куда ему было уйти в скромном

text: The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr's name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels "e/ë" and "o."
ru_trans: Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных "е/ё" и "о".

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
prefix: и по веленью сердец почапали в

text: Low: small shabby house, hovel, shack.

Miller, related to the term мельница (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between "milling" and "pastries." Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

[Kostroma](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kostroma,+Kostroma+Oblast,+Russia/@57.7736658,40.7991705,11z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m6!3m5!1s0x46ad4ff11964c7bb:0xe547e104bd9b4c6e!8m2!3d57.7677078!4d40.9262609!16zL20vMDJjbDBt), the administrative center of the Kostroma Oblast and one of the Golden Ring cities. Located where the Volga and Kostroma Rivers meet. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bc/%D0%9A%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0._%D0%A0%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0._%D0%90%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82_3_-_panoramio.jpg)

This phraseologism is generally used to describe a person with an unstable character. However, the syntagm refers to a folding bag (made of fabric or leather) used to transport things on a horse. [Here](https://lukoshko.net/story/svyatogor-bogatyr.htm) the bylina in Russian, and in its [English translation](http://www.artrusse.ca/byliny/ilya_svyatogor.htm). Mentioned already in ch. 4 and 8.

The frequent use of the verb *gulyat'* is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina will be defined as gulyaschaya: "была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая" (R220/E124). In her case, "гулена" means "party person" and "гулящая" is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

text: An alcoholic drink typically made with red wine and other liquors such as gin, vodka, or rum. Made famous in Russia by Nikolai Iazykov's translation of Christoph Friedrich Wedekind's song "Kraumbambuli." Derived from the Old High German word *Kranawitu* or *chranawita* and the Rotwelsch word *Blamp*. Alcohol theme.

Тема алкоголя.

text: Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or "the minor", "the little", "the lesser", "the younger". In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be "justified" by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word "yakoby", literally maybe, perhaps.
ru_trans: Иаков Алфеев был одним из 12 апостолов. Он также известен как Иаков Младший, или Меньший. В следующей главе, Якову будет присвоено другая фамилия, Паламахтеров: его изменяющиеся фамилии можно "объяснить" семантической связью между его именем и словом "якобы", то есть, будто.

It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).

text: A town located in Novgorod Oblast first mentioned in a chronicle in 1495 and known for the manufacture of bells in eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Mentioned several times throughout the novel (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).
ru_trans: Город в Новгородской области, впервые упоминается в летописи 1495 года. Известен литьём ямщицких колокольчиков в XVIII-XIX вв. Неоднократно упоминается в романе (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).

text: Although appearing only now, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book.  In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article ("The Verse in Sasha Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf"), Sokolov himself stated that: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is him who kills Ilya in revenge.
ru_trans: Несмотря на позднее появление в романе, этот полиморфный герой играет центральную роль в романе, являюсь одновременно собачником, охотником, поэтом, художником и, возможно, единственным вымышленным автором целой книги. В ответе Смиту, опубликованному в статье 1987 года, Соколов отмечает: "Стихотворные главы написаны Яковом. Он никак ко мне не относится, но он должен быть и является человеком высокой культуры, ведь он и есть тот самый художник, описанный в прозаических главах (не написанных Ильей) "Ловчая повесть", где он живет в доме с матерью, юноша, влюбленный в простодушную девушку, которую уводят матросы; автор эскизов и "Автопортрета в мундире", и так далее; (И. конечно, в этой главе он также охотник и поэт, который "несвеж и немолод"); "Ловчая повесть, или Картинки с выставки", где он — Яков Ильич Паламахтеров, "неподкупный свидетель и доезжачiй своего практическаго и безжалостнаго времени", который представляет сцену из этнографии XIX века с участием своего прадеда; "Картинки с выставки" (9), в которой он наблюдает за сценами уличной жизни сквозь окно кадетского училища; см. также похожие места в романе, 13 и 16. Все они написаны с позиции автора, но стилизированного автора, то есть, не от меня непосредственно. Яков — поэт, художник, мечтатель, представитель интеллигенции, который родился и вырос в городе. Он поселяется у Итиля уже в зрелом возрасте" (327). Яков играет центральную роль в структуре сюжета, ведь это он убивает Илью в порыве мести.

text: Yakov Alfeev's patronymic suggests Ilya is his father. Yet, the suggestion is debatable. D.B. Johnson noted: "Yakov is Ilya's son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (...). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) 'marries' a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (1984; 211-212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter's dogs for a wolf and kills it. For a consideration of Sokolov's mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova's "Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov."
ru_trans: Отчество Якова Алфеева указывает на то, что Илья — его отец. Однако, это предположение оспоримо. Д. Б. Джонсон замечает: "Яков — сын Ильи, в той степени, в которой что-то может быть чем-либо в сумереченом мире между собакой и волком. И Яков, и Илья остаются в неведении этого факта, однако позже, когда их жизненные пути как собачника и точильщика фатально пересекаются, они также неосведомлены о их временной дружбе в больнице. (...). [Яков] повторяет роль Эдипа. Он неосознанно убивает своего отца и (пусть и не буквально) "женится" на версии своей матери. Соколов воплотил греческий миф о Эдипе среди вод Волги" (1984; 211-212). На самом деле, Илья будет убит Яковом в отместку за то, что первый (в сумерки, переходя замерзшую реку) принял одну из собак последнего за волка и убил ее. Анализ мифопоэтики Соколова приведен в "Творчестве Саши Соколова в контексте литературного процеса 60-80-х годов" И. Ащеуловой (Ashcheulova).

text:
Acacia trees. Plant motif. A self-reference to Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, in which the character Vetka Acacia appears: "как твое имя меня называют Веткой я Ветка акации я Ветка железной дороги я Вета беременная от ласковой птицы по имени Найтингейл я беременна будущим летом и крушением товарняка" (whats your name I am called Vetka [Branch] I am Vetka of the acacia I am Vetka 
of the railroad I am Veta pregnant by the tender bird named Nightin- gale I am pregnant with the coming summer and the crash of the freight train) (*Shkola* **###**). There is thus a confluence of motifs here: trains, plants, sex.
ru_trans: Дерево акации. Мотив растений. Самоссылка на первый роман Соколова, *Школа для дураков*, где появляется героиня Ветка Акация: "как твое имя меня называют Веткой я Ветка акации я Ветка железной дороги я Вета беременная от ласковой птицы по имени Найтингейл я беременна будущим летом и крушением товарняка" (*Школа* ###). Здесь происходит слияние нескольких мотивов: поезда, растения, секс.

text: Set expression: драть как Сидорову козу (to beat like Sidor's goat, whip someone's ass, beat mercilessly). Of course, the phrase draws a direct link to Sidor Fomich Pozhilykh. Boguslawski adds: "Some scholars derive the origin of this phraseological expression from the Arabic "*sadar kaza* (perhaps brought to Russia by the Mongols), a sentence that often involved punishment by beating with clubs" ("Annotations" 253). Animal motif.

text: A non-existent, tongue-twister toponym. It also appears in other chapters with slight variations: Milokurekemovo and Malokulelemovo (R150/E2). This "муко" sound will be repeated many times in the novel. Such repetition will stress the closeness (paronomasia) of the words *muká* and *múka* (flour and pain).

text: Fox. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/2014-06-20_Vulpes_vulpes_vulpes%2C_B%C3%B6nhamn%2C_V%C3%A4sternorrlands_L%C3%A4n%2C_Sverige_1.jpg) Animal motif. Olga Matich reads Sokolov's novel as an extended response to Boris Pilnyak's short story "Mother Earth" (1927), as it shares confusion between a wolf and a fox, a character name Arina, and a setting on the Upper Volga, among other similarities ("Sasha Sokolov" 312–313). Read the original [here](http://az.lib.ru/p/pilxnjak_b_a/text_1924_mat_syra_zemlya.shtml). D. Barton Johnson adds: "The prose models that served for *Shkola dlia durakov* were obviously unsuitable for the setting and events of *Mezhdu sobakoi i volkom*. Apart from the obvious sections of literary parody in which Gogol' is flagrantly apparent, it is difficult to point to direct stylistic sources. The first that comes to mind is the Andrei Belyi of *Serebrianyi golub'* (The Silver Dove) with its (partial) peasant setting and its elaborate sound instrumentation. Sokolov, however, denies having read Belyi at this point. A more likely literary context is afforded by modernist Boris Pilniak [...] Pilniak had recently been rehabilitated and his work was easily available. Sokolov recalls reading his work in 1975. Something of the same dark violence and fractured language is also to be found in the work of Pilniak's adherent Andrei Platonov whose work was being rediscovered and republished in the late 1960s" ("Background Notes" (336–337).

text: Derived from the colloquial невтерпёж (lacking patience). Here, Ilya suggests that his relations with Orina were going smoothly and patiently (i.e., calmly) for some time. Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the "close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word *nevterpezh*, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression "mne stalo nevterpezh" [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary" ("How Sokolov's" 218).
Dated: to pull, drag.
ru_trans: Устаревшее: манить, тянуть.

text: крест - отсылка к притче плотник в пустыне в школе для дураков + тема художникаThe cross is a crucial symbol in *A School for Fools*, more precisely in the story/parable titled "The Carpenter in the Desert" contained in it. As the story tells, the carpenter wonders: "Fine, I don't have material to build a house, a carousel, or a crate, but I have two boards and one good nail." In the end, he makes a cross out of these poor materials. Later on, some people come and ask him to help them crucify a man; at first, he refuses the idea, but then they persuade him successfully. In the end, as the crucified man is dying he decides to tell the carpenter his story, which echoes the carpenter's. "You fool," he addresses the carpenter, "haven't you understood yet there's absolutely no difference between us, that you and I are one and the same man." In the end, the narrator says, "the carpenter died."
suffix: , и растенья белеющие, ивы что л

text: Dated: scroll, tablet, table, annal. This Biblical word (Moses's *Tablets of Stone*) carries a relevant meaning for Sokolov, who also used it in the title of one of his essays, *On Secret Tablets*(1981). In this text, the writer retraces his literary destiny, wondering about the meaning of being an artist and a writer and suggesting that life often just follows what art has already predicted on "secret tablets."

In the sense of a railway switch. Trains play crucial thematic and narrative roles in all of Sokolov's novels. Here, Orina is moved from one job to another, but more generally, the train switch symbolizes the characters' many possible paths and multiple identities. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/26/SunsetTracksCrop.JPG) Railroad theme.

Здесь, Орина меняет место работы, но, в более широком смысле, железнодорожная стрелка символизирует многочисленные личности героев и разнообразие их возможных жизненных путей. Изображено ниже:

text: Nineteenth-century song "Otrada" ("Joy") with lyrics by Sergei Ryskin and music by Mikhail Shishkin. The song describes the singer's love for a woman who is locked away in a high tower, echoing Orina's displacement from Ilya. Listen [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R0xBLrMFmPg). Ilya references the same song in chapter 6 (R190/E72-73). "Терем" refers to a tower-room, that is, living quarters in the topmost part of a building shaped like a tower. Common in ancient Rus': ![](https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2018/11/14/10/10/terem-3814845_960_720.jpg)
ru_trans:
Написанная в 19 веке песня "Живет моя отрада", слова С. Рыскина, музыка М. Шишкина. В песне поется о любви певца к женщине, запертой в высокой башне, намекая на разлуку Ильи и Орины. text: In Slavic folklore, the bogeyman. Descriptions vary but often he is disabled in some manner: mute, lame, or missing an arm. Used to scare children who misbehave or refuse to sleep. The name is derived from the Tatar for "grandfather" or "old man."

text: Poetic/low: to call, glorify, name.

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov's art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).  Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

text: Dated: washhouse, laundry.

A false etymology of the verb "dopetrit'" (Peter the Great) just encountered in the text could make the use of this adjective acquire a subtle "historical" hint to the smutnoe vremya (Time of Troubles, 1598-1613). The "historical" frame is stressed even further below, through the verb "otboyarivat'sya", etymologically linked with the word "boyarin" (boyar, a member of the ruling nobility in medieval Russia).
ru_trans: Ложная этимология только что встретившегося слова "допетрить" (Петр Великий) может намекать подтекстуальный "исторический" намек на Смутное время (1598-1613). "Историческая" отсылка подтверждается несколькими строками ниже: глагол "отбояриваться" этимологически связан с существительным "боярин" (представитель высшего общества в феодалов в средневековой Руси, член высшего совета при князе).

text: The highest ranked Christian angel class, the seraphim are best known from [Isaiah 6:1–8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%98%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B8%D1%8F%206%3A1-8&version=NIV): "In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying. And they were calling to one another: 'Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory.'" They are also mentioned in Alexander Pushkin's seminal 1826 poem "The Prophet": "Tormented by a spiritual thirst, / I stumbled through a gloomy waste, / And there a six-winged seraph / Appeared before me at the crossroad." Read the original and this English translation [here](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm). Later mentioned in chapter 6 (R195/E80).
ru_trans: Серафимы —  высший ангельский чин, описаны в книге [Исаии 6:1-8](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%98%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B8%D1%8F%206%3A1-8&version=RUSV,NIV): "В год смерти царя Озии видел я Господа, сидящего на престоле высоком и превознесенном, и края риз Его наполняли весь храм. Вокруг Него стояли Серафимы; у каждого из них по шести крыл: двумя закрывал каждый лице свое, и двумя закрывал ноги свои, и двумя летал. И взывали они друг ко другу и говорили: Свят, Свят, Свят Господь Саваоф! вся земля полна славы Его!". Также упоминаются в судьбоносном стихотворении А. Пушкина 1826 года "Пророк": "Духовной жаждою томим, / В пустыне мрачной я влачился, - / И шестикрылый серафим / На перепутьи мне явился". Прочитать стихотворение в оригинале и английском переводе можно [здесь](http://max.mmlc.northwestern.edu/mdenner/Demo/texts/prophet.htm). Позже упоминаются в главе 6 (R195/E80).

text: An anagram of Bydogoshch mentioned before. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).
prefix: роге лунной, как по мосткам, от

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
prefix: по мосткам, от Гыбодощи сюда, к

text: From the expression "Всё перемелется — мука будет" (Everything will get milled over; there will be flour). An expression of the milling theme in the novel. Sokolov will play with this expression and the difference between му́ка (torment) and мукá (flour) several times.
ru_trans: От выражения: "Всё перемелется — мука будет". Выражение темы мельницы в романе. Соколов неоднократно обыгрывает это выражение и созвучность м*у*ки (страдания) и мук*и* (хлебопекарной).

text: Stream.

An apparent allusion to Alexander Blok's "[Unknown Lady](https://ruverses.com/alexander-blok/unknown-woman/926/)" (1906). The poem has certain resonances and overlap with Sokolov's novel: drinking, truth, a mysterious woman.
Colloquial: same as сначала (at first).

According to Ostanin, a reference to Nikolai Alexandrovich von Ritter's romance "Coachman, Don't Drive the Horses" (1914), another tragic love song. Read the lyrics (in Russian) [here](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AF%D0%BC%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BA,_%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%B9), and listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qIbQmmST7zk).
ru_trans: Согласно Останину, отсылка к романсу Николая Александровича фон Риттера "Ямщик, не гони лошадей" (1914), еще одной песне о несчастной любви. Слова можно прочитать [здесь](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AF%D0%BC%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BA,_%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B8_%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%B9), а послушать запись [здесь](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qIbQmmST7zk).

text: Barbara Heldt observes of this scene in chapters 10 and 14: "The words about teeth and tail are repeated with the different that *predlinnyi* becoms *dolgii*, like the long memory of the event" (281). Orina likens her alleged bad behavior and excesses to animal qualities: sharp teeth and a long tail. On memory, D. Barton Johnson writes, "Since all times seem to exist more or less concurrently and variant versions of events exist both in fact and *in potentia*, memory in Sokolov's works merges with imagination. The first person narrators not so much retell *the* past but imagine at different times variant pasts and futures. For Sokolov's characters, memory is imagination, and imagination, the only reality" ("Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos" 643). Animal-human motif.

Once again characters are associated with animals (here, with birds). Porkhalishche defines a place where birds are protected and free to bathe. Here, it is to be intended as the banya mentioned before. Animal-human motif.
A key image in Ilya and Orina's relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.
ru_trans: Ключевой предмет/образ в отношениях Ильи и Орины. Он дарит его ей, а она теряет подаренный гребень на железнодорожных путях. Образ впервые вводится в главе 1 (R156/E12). Мотив гребня.

text: Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov's art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg).  Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). text: A reference to the expression “У сороки боли, у вороны боли, а у (имя) всё заживи” ("The magpie is hurt, the crow is hurt, but (name) will feel all better"), used to comfort children who have hurt themselves. This reference also appears in Note XI (R196-197/E84–86), which begs the question: which came first — Yakov's poem or Ilya's letter? Animal motif.

text:
The accent should be put on the first vowel, but apparently Ilya is not aware of this (or mixes it up with the toponym "TatAriya/TartAriya"). In Greek mythology, Tartarus is the abyss where wicked people are tormented and suffer, and where souls are judged after death. In the Middle Ages, the most remote corners of the earth started to be called Tartarus.
It should be kept in mind that Sokolov himself worked in a morgue for some time in 1961 after completing school.
ru_trans: Ударение должно стоять на первом слоге, но Илья или не знает об этом, или путает с топонимом "Татария / Тартария". В греческой мифологии, Тартаром называлась бездна, в которой страдали и были мучимы злые люди, и где судились души после смерти. В Средневековье Тартаром стали называть наиболее удалённые уголки земли. Стоит приминать во внимание тот факт, что сам Соколов работал в морге после окончания школы в 1961 году.

text: Natalya Fedotova and Daniil Osipov write: "This fragment presents a description in a fundamentally different color scheme (iridescent azure), opposed to the grayness of the narrator's being. The hero is so ingrained in his perception of the everyday world, presented only in colors corresponding to the time of twilight (faded, faded, ash-gray, gray, grayish, ashy, ashy, the colors of unpainted felt, the colors of felt, the colors of crows and magpies), that the unreal, the realm of reveries, dreams are perceived by him as a colored dream, where the colors indistinguishable, but striking" (65–66). original: Данный фрагмент представляет описание в принципиально иной цветовой гамме (переливчатая лазурь), противопоставленной серости бытия рассказчика. Герой настолько укоренился в своем восприятии обыденного мира только в цветах, соответствующих времени сумерек (полинялые, выцветшие, пеплогривая, седой, серый, сероватый, пепельный, пепловатый, цвета некрашеного фетра, цвета войлока, цвета ворон и сорок), что ирреальное, область грез, мечты воспринимается им как цветной сон, где цвета неразличимы, но ярки

text: In ancient Russia, a *sloboda* referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, *sloboda* refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a [Sloboda](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sloboda,+Tver+Oblast,+Russia,+171265/@56.6543229,36.4671174,12.92z/data=!4m6!3m5!1s0x46b4337b61338bc3:0xfd78ee1285635920!8m2!3d56.6502347!4d36.4718922!16s%2Fg%2F12xpjjzgs?entry=ttu) can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

text: Sokolov explains: "Cable reel is shaped like a reel of thread, except that it is much larger, about one and a half to two meters in diameter. An empty reel, without cable, can serve as a round table in the garden. Having used the cable, electricians leave empty reels in the bosom of nature, and the boys play with them, in particular - roll them into the river or pond and float on them, since they are made of wood. Then the reels stay floating in those water reservoirs and get more and more swollen, soaking up in water. Ilya makes a mistake, perhaps deliberately: as in many other water reservoir (singular), while he should say: in many other water reservoirs (plural)" (personal communication, June 7, 2023).
ru_trans:
Соколов объясняет: "Кабельная катушка по форме напоминает катушку для ниток, только размер ее гораздо больше, она примерно полтора-два метра в диаметре. Пустая катушка, без кабеля, может служить круглым столом в саду. Использовав кабель, электрики оставляют пустые катушки на лоне природы, и мальчишки играют с ними, в частности - скатывают их в реку или в пруд и плавают на них, они ведь деревянные
Потом катушки остаются плавать в тех водоемах и все больше набухают, пропитываются водой. Илья делает ошибку, возможно, сознательную: как и во многом другом водоеме, а надо бы сказать: во многих других водоемах" (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

text: A modified line from the famous seafaring song "The Sea Spreads Wide." Read the lyrics [here](http://www.sovmusic.ru/text.php?fname=raskinul). Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_gqYwTyE-K4).

This type of willow is often mentioned in Russian folklore. According to the myth, it grew on the very first rock on Earth, which was thrown out of the sea by a fish. Birds and animals living on this bush boast magic powers and can foresee the future. In literature, we find it in Nekrasov's *Who is Happy in Russia?* (3rd part, ch. 5): the heroine laments her bitter fate while sitting on this bush. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/13/p.15/index.html) and its English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/9619/pg9619.html). Plant motif. This bush will be mentioned again in chapter 14.
ru_trans: Этот вид ивы часто упоминается в русском фольклоре. Согласно мифу, он вырос на самом первом камне на Земле, который выбросила из моря рыба. Птицы и животные, живущие на этом кусте, обладают магической силой и могут предвидеть будущее. В литературе мы находим его в романе Некрасова *Кому на Руси жить хорошо?* (3-я часть, гл. 5): героиня думает о своей горькой судьбе, сидя на этом кусте. Читайте текст [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/13/p.15/index.html). Мотив растений. Этот куст упоминается снова в главе 14.

text: Natalya Fedotova and Daniil Osipov suggest that Sokolov uses "prospection as a form of temporary discountinuum that stops the linear unfolding of the novel's plot" in order to "create an alternative reality, an oneiric space of the heroes' dreams of another version of the unfolding events" (62). This use of time is contrasted with retrospection and cyclical time, two other key temporal modes of the novel (62).

text: The term is derived from the German *Feldscher* from the fifteenth century meaning "field shearer." It was originally used to describe barber surgeons in the German and Swiss armies from the seventeenth until the early 18th century. The term and position was exported by Russian solders serving in Prussia, and the All-Russia Union of Feldshers was established in 1905.  Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/74/Ambulanz_zu_Fr%C3%B6schweiler_August_1870_-_deutscher_Feldscher.jpg)
ru_trans: Термин происходит от немецкого слова *Feldscher*, буквально означающего "полевой цирюльник" в XV веке. Первоначально использовался для описания полевых хирургов в немецкой и швейцарской армиях с XVII века по ранний XVIII век. Сам термин и профессия были привезены русскими солдатами, служившими в Пруссии, и в 1905 году был основан Всероссийский союз фельдшеров. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/74/Ambulanz_zu_Fr%C3%B6schweiler_August_1870_-_deutscher_Feldscher.jpg)

text: An allusion to the prison song "Taganka." The title refers to the Taganka Prison in Moscow, which housed numerous political prisoners in both tsarist and Soviet times. The lights were never turned off in the prison, hence the line "полные огня" ("full of fire"). The prison was demolished in 1960. Read the lyrics [here](https://lyricstranslate.com/en/taganka-taganka-taganka.html). Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ih0WLzvZjuY). Early in this chapter, Ilya mentioned that he has not spent time in prisons despite his wanderings and his experience with large cities.
ru_trans: Отсылка на тюремную песню "Таганка". Название указывает на Таганскую тюрьму в Москве, в которой содержались политические заключенные в царские и советсткие времена. Свет в тюрьме никогда не выключался, отсюда строфа "полные огня". Тюрьма была упразднена в 1960 году. Слова песни можно прочитать [здесь](https://lyricstranslate.com/en/taganka-taganka-taganka.html). Послушать запись можно [здесь](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ih0WLzvZjuY). Ранее в этой главе Илья замечает, что в тюрьмах не бывал, несмотря на его странствия по большим городам.
