text: Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the "close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word *nevterpezh*, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression "mne stalo nevterpezh" [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary" ("How Sokolov's" 218).

text:
Boguslawski writes: "A combined reference to the
famous highway Shosse Entuziastov (Enthusiasts’ Highway) in Moscow and to '*otkuda est’ poshla russkaia zemlia*' (from whence had the Russian land come), a part of the opening sentence of the twelfth-century Russian chronicle *Povest’ vremennykh let* (*The Tale of Bygone Years*)" ("Annotations" 240). Read the original [here](http://lib.ru/HISTORY/RUSSIA/povest.txt) and an English translation [here](https://www.mgh-bibliothek.de/dokumente/a/a011458.pdf).
ru_trans: Богуславский пишет: "Комбинированная отсылка к знаменитому Шоссе Энтузиастов в Москве и к '*откуда есть пошла русская земля*', части первого предложения русской летописи XII века *Повести временных лет*" (Boguslawski "Annotations" 240). Прочитать оригинал можно [здесь](http://lib.ru/HISTORY/RUSSIA/povest.txt), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://www.mgh-bibliothek.de/dokumente/a/a011458.pdf).

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by  the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).
prefix: ни то ни другое пока немыслимо.

text: Archaism/poetic: eyelids. Ilya uses the same word in chapter 6:  "На манер как бы брючины подворачивай вежды себе" ("Roll up your eyelids like a pant leg, bare your stump, too") (R190/E73).
ru_trans: Архаизм/поэтическое: веки. Илья использует то же слово в главе 6: "На манер как бы брючины подворачивай вежды себе" (R190/E73).

text: A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg) Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 9 (R214/E112), and chapter 10 (R223/E129). Shoe motif.
The crutches can't be found.

text: Set expression: to vanish into thin air, the trail went cold.

Fish belonging to the Carassius genus and Cyprinidae family. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/CarassiusCarassius8.JPG) Animal motif. This same question, and this scene in general, is repeated in chapter 8 by Ilya (R210/E106). Alexander Boguslawski notes: "Sokolov increases the artistic impact of these two descriptions by combining images with skillful manipulation of the lexical material. It is easy to see the delicate modulations of the phrase about the carp, achieved by synonymic substitutions *prishchurilsia – prigliadelsia* and *dremali – kemarli* as well as by replacement of *zdes' gde* by *tut u nas* and of *ershi eti samye* by *mne vzbrelo vdrug*" ("How Sokolov's" 215).
ru_trans:
Рыба из семейства Карповых, род Караси. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/CarassiusCarassius8.JPG) 

Мотив животных. Этот же вопрос, как и эта же сцена в целом, повторяется Ильей в главе 8 (R210/E106). А. Богуславский замечает: "Соколов усиляет художественное воздействие этих двух описаний путем соединения визуальных образов с мастерски использованным лексическим материалом. Несложно заметить легкие модуляции фраз, описывающих карасей, выполненные путем синонимичных замещений *прищучился – пригляделся* и *дремали – кемарили*, а также замена *здесь где* на *тут у нас* и *ерши эти самые* на *мне взбрело вдруг*" (Boguslawski, "How Sokolov's" 215).

text: This type of willow is often mentioned in Russian folklore. According to the myth, it grew on the very first rock on Earth, which was thrown out of the sea by a fish. Birds and animals living on this bush boast magic powers and can foresee the future. In literature, we find it in Nekrasov's *Who is Happy in Russia?* (3rd part, ch. 5): the heroine laments her bitter fate while sitting on this bush. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/13/p.15/index.html) and its English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/9619/pg9619.html). Plant motif. This bush was already mentioned in chapter 1.
ru_trans: Этот вид ивы часто упоминается в русском фольклоре. Согласно мифу, он вырос на самом первом камне на Земле, который выбросила из моря рыба. Птицы и животные, живущие на этом кусте, обладают магической силой и могут предвидеть будущее. В литературе мы находим его в романе Некрасова *Кому на Руси жить хорошо?* (3-я часть, гл. 5): героиня думает о своей горькой судьбе, сидя на этом кусте. Читайте текст [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/13/p.15/index.html). Мотив растений. Этот куст упоминается снова в главе 14.

text: In ancient Russia, a *sloboda* referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, *sloboda* refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a [Sloboda](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sloboda,+Tver+Oblast,+Russia,+171265/@56.6543229,36.4671174,12.92z/data=!4m6!3m5!1s0x46b4337b61338bc3:0xfd78ee1285635920!8m2!3d56.6502347!4d36.4718922!16s%2Fg%2F12xpjjzgs?entry=ttu) can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).

text: An allusion to [2 Peter 2:22](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2%20Peter%202%3A22&version=NIV) or [Proverbs 26:11](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Proverbs%2026%3A11&version=NIV). The meaning is that the unfaithful will return to their sinful life. Animal motif.

text: Elena Kravchenko writes: "[W. H.] Auden's ekphrasis, especially his references to *The Census* and *The Slaughter*, is scattered throughout Sokolov's text. Shimmering through its portrayal of the desolate state of humanity, its images of frozen river and skating, the ekphrasis re-emerges in Il'ia's 'allegory' of existence: in what appears to be an elaboration of Auden’s dogs that ‘go on with their doggy life'" (*The Prose* 63).
Colloquial: beloved, beautiful.
ru_trans: Разговорное: дорогой, любимый.

Historical term: people who performed various domestic duties at the royal court in the 16th-18th centuries. Later on, in the 18th-19th centuries, judicial officers were called stryapchie. Here the term is related to cooking, suggesting the "challenges" regarding the process of cooking the egg.
ru_trans: Исторический термин: придворные служащие в XVI-XVIII веках. Позже, в XVII-XIX вв. судебных чиновников также стали называть стряпчими. Здесь, употребленно в значении "кухонный", намекая на "трудности" процесса приготовления яйца.

text: Archaism for объедение: gluttony, a delight to eat, something incredibly delicious. This form encodes the word for poison (яд), creating a link between Ilya's lusting after Orina, his tastes, and death. Along with the various drinking allusions in this section, a reference to [Luke 21:34](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke+21%3A34&version=NIV): "Be careful, or your hearts will be weighed down with carousing, drunkenness and the anxieties of life, and that day will close on you suddenly like a trap."
ru_trans: Архаическая форма слова "объедение": обжорство, лакомство. Такая форма включает в себя слово "яд", намекая на страсть Ильи к Орине, его вкусы и смерть. Наряду с различными аллюзиями к пьянству в данном отрывке, ссылка на [Луки 21:34](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=%D0%9E%D1%82+%D0%9B%D1%83%D0%BA%D0%B8+21%3A34&version=RUSV): "Смотрите же за собою, чтобы сердца ваши не отягчались объядением и пьянством и заботами житейскими, и чтобы день тот не постиг вас внезапно".

text: Ilya wishes (possibly ironically) to understand what is the sense, the meaning of such a fairy tale, whether it is a parable carrying any meaning at all, or not. In a sense, this is what the reader may wonder reading Sokolov's novel and failing to grasp its plot, structure, and levels of interpretation. Possibly, this is a (Nabokovian) provocation for readers who search for meaning in any literary work. Before agreeing to appear in [Maxim Gureev's documentary film](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8RoUlCN2yxk) about him, Sokolov asked the director whether he had a script prepared. When Gureev replied in the negative, Sokolov responded positively: "Plot... That side of literature never appealed to me. Plot is a contrived thing. Plot is used to sell something. For me it's important how language works, the linguistic dance of its own kind. If I was born in a different time, in a different place, in a different family, I would have become a composer, because is one of the forms of music" (Gureev 165–166).

text: As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of [Bydgoszcz](https://www.google.com/maps?output=search&q=bydgoszcz&entry=mc&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj4_sT8sbb_AhUaGVkFHWvIBHAQ0pQJegQICxAB) (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver'. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209).
ru_trans: Возможная отсылка к польскому городу Быдогощ, но также ошибочное написание деревни Видогощь на реке Волге, недалеко от Твери. Быдогощ (Быдгощ) располощен на реке Брда. Согласно легенде, город был основан братьями Быдом и Гостом на месте, показавшемся им идеальным, в том числе благодаря реке. Д. Б. Джонсон замечает, что, в то время как живые обитают в Городище, Быдогощи — дом мертвецов (Johnson, "Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209).

text: Tëshin yazyk, literally "mother-in-law's tongue", is a flowering plant (sansevieria) native to Africa and southern Asia, but also popular as a houseplant. The plant, as the name suggests, is linked with superstitions according to which it would badly affect the future of couples and families. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/91/Snake_plant.jpg) Plant motif.
ru_trans: Тещин язык (сансеверия) — род растений, встречающих в регионах Африки и Южной Азии. Широко распространено как домашнее растение. Растение, как следует из имени, тесно связано с суеверием, согласно которому оно негативно влияет на будущее пар и семей.

text: Sokolov has written about his desire to avoid the "what" in literature," opting for the "how": “In the milieu from which I come […] the traditions of so-called art-for-art’s sake are still alive. I am using here the expression so-called because by definition art is always for its own sake […] Forgive me for being so insistent, but art should be beautiful. And prose – should be refined and superior like poetry. […] Show me your how – a pass to truth, and take away what; I will find what myself.” (Sokolov, “The Key Word of Belles-Lettres,” In the House of the Hanged, 28-29)
ru_trans:
Соколов упоминает о своем желании избегать слово "что", заменяя его словом "как":
"В той среде, откуда я родом, в той школе живы традиции так называемого чистого искусства. Я говорю — так называемого, потому что искусство чисто по определению […] Простите, что я так настойчив, но искусство должно быть прекрасным. И проза — да будет изящна и максимальна, подобно поэзии. […] Предъявите мне ваше как — пропуск в истинное, а что — уберите, что — я придумаю сам. " (Соколов, "Ключевое слово словесности, В доме повешенного").

text: Woodpecker. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/42/Yellow-bellied_sapsucker_in_CP_%2840422%29.jpg) The woodpecker has traditionally played roles "as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who [...] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war" (Rowland 180). It is also said that the woodpecker can knock out anything blocking its nest in a tree. While there doesn't seem to be any such obstruction here, Ilya implies that the bird has knocked down the snow that falls on his head. Animal motif.

text: The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov's poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/06/Upupa_epops_Madrid_01.jpg) José Vergara writes: "the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s *Metamorphoses*. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family" ("Flap" 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. "He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family," Vergara continues, "but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him" ("Flap" 366). Animal-human motif.
The Wolf River is alternatively called Itil' and Volga in the novel.
ru_trans: Волчья река в романе также называется Итиль или Волга.

text: The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya's letter "Zaitil'shchina" is derived from this version of the river's name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil' and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools* (10).

text: Dated: February. It will be mentioned again in chapter 14 (another chapter by Ilya). The word derives from the terms "бок" (side) and "греть" (to warm). As Boguslawski translates it, "side-warmer," meaning a shift in weather that will warm your sides. A reference to St. Sidor Bokogrei, whose day is celebrated on May 14/27. He was given this name, because it was said that bitterly cold northern winds would stop blowing on this date. Likewise, swifts and swallows would fly to Sidor with the approach of warm weather. However, people caution against taking the appearance of the first bird as a sure sign of the cold's departure, similar to the following clause. Read his saint's life [here](https://religion.wikireading.ru/100944). The addressee of Ilya's letter is, of course, Sidor (Fomich Pozhilykh).

text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (*gorod*) and beggar (*nishchii*). It is the "town of beggars." Olga Matich writes: "If *School for Fools* was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov's next novel *Between Dog and Wolf* may be read as the author's response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies" ("Sasha Sokolov" 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an "Anti-Kitezh" (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves ("Zaitil'shchina" 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch ("Sokolov's *Between Dog and Wolf* and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: "Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his *Journey from Petersburg to Moscow* and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel" (217).
ru_trans: Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов "город" и "нищий". Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: "Если *Школа для дураков* была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, *Между собакой и волком* можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых" (Matich "Sasha Sokolov" 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid "Zaitil'shchina" 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson "Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition" 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

highlighted: хочешь — на шею дам, отдыхай тогда на здоровье хоть до Страшнеющего Суда
text: Ilya's conversation with the river here is continued in chapter 4 (R176/E47-48). There, the "Страшнеющего Суда" becomes "последнем случае." The threat of death and the pull of suicide looms over Ilya and many of the men living on the banks of the Volga. However, as Martina Napolitano explains, "As if to exorcise it, as if to disavow it as incompatible with the characters' very personal idea of a-chronological, nonlinear, circular and modifiable time, death is always spoken of in a metaphorical key" ("'Studyin This Volapuke'" 287). Death is one of Sokolov's central themes. As he put it in an interview with Olga Matich, "In that sense, I'm apparently traditional. I write on eternal themes: love, life, death. Death is inseparable from life. It's constantly near, around us, in the objects that surround us. It becomes clearer in certain of its forms. For example, in old photographs. Since I was a child I've had a thought: everyone in photos from the previous century, at the very least those born in its first half, died. This fact particularly stands out when you look at group photos, at snapshots of massive street scenes. Or when you're simply walking down the street at rush hour and suddenly see a freeze frame. All movement, the entire crowd momentarily stops, and you suddenly remember: in 60-70 years all of them will no longer be. Yourself included" ("Nuzhno zabyt'" 12). This fascination with death dates back to his childhood: "Visiting cemeteries [...] was for me something like a home education. I was also interested in the theme of death. It's, after all, the most interesting thing in life" (Kochetkova).
ru_trans: Разговор Ильи с рекой продолжается в главе 4 (R176/E47-48). Здесь, выражение "до Страшнеющего Суда" становится синонимичным "в последнем случае". Угроза смерти и тяга к самоубийству давлеет над Ильей и другими обитателями берегов Волги. Однако, как объясняет М. Наполитано: "Будто бы бы для того, чтобы освободиться, отречься от нее как от идеи, несовместимой с весьма личным ахронологическим, нелинейным, спиралевидным, легкоизменяемым понятием времени героев, о смерти всегда говорится в метафорическом ключе" (Napolitano, "'Studyin This Volapuke'" 287). Смерть является одной из центральных тем в творчестве Соколова. Как он замечает в интервью с Ольгой Матич: "В этом смысле я, видимо, традиционен. Пишу на вечные темы: любовь, жизнь, смерть. Смерть неотлучима от жизни. Она постоянно рядом, вокруг нас, в окружающих нас предметах. В некоторых из них ее облик проступает ясней. Например, в старых фотографиях. Меня с детства занимала мысль: все люди на снимках прошлого века, во всяком случае — родившиеся в первой половине его, умерли. Особенно этот факт поражает при взгляде на групповые фото, на снимки массовых уличных сцен. Или просто идешь по улице в часы пик и вдруг видишь как бы стоп-кадр: все движение, вся толпа мгновенно останавливается и вспоминаешь вдруг: через 60-70 лет их всех тоже не будет. И тебя в том числе" (Solokov, "Nuzhno zabyt'" 12). Увлечение темой смерти зародилось еще в детстве: "Посещение кладбищ — не только Ваганьковского, но и Симоновского и Новодевичьего — было для меня чем-то вроде домашнего образования. Меня тоже интересовала тема смерти — это ведь самое интересное, что есть в жизни" (Kochetkova).

text: Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil' river). It is not surprising given his "speaking name" formed by the words "krylo" (wing) and "byl" (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the "zhe" letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a "know-it-all" who "instructs," the one "whom I trust, whom I praise." In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya's Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as "Fedot Fyodorov" (R279/E227).

text: Dated/low: thanks.

text: An allusion to Chekhov's "Uncle Vanya". Read the original Russian [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/972/p.1/index.html) and English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1756/1756-h/1756-h.htm). Since the morgue is described as a theater, it is not surprising that the nurse is an "uncle Vanya."
ru_trans: Отсылка к пьесе Чехова "Дядя Ваня". Прочитать русский оригинал можно [здесь](https://ilibrary.ru/text/972/p.1/index.html), а английский перевод — [здесь](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1756/1756-h/1756-h.htm). Так как морг описан как театр, медсестра-"дядя Ваня" не становится сюрпризом для читателя.

text: Dated (and misspelled, "torovatost'"): generosity.
ru_trans: Устаревшее (и неправильно написанное: "тороватость"): щедрость.

text: Usually the word is written as "vtoropiakh" (hastily), but here Sokolov splits the prefix.

text: On one level, Ilya here suggests that he "picked up" his surname in the sense that it's not really his name. It's an adopted identity, a mask. Indeed, he just admitted loving collecting things: "I’m a fan, I possess a pas- sion for collectin" (R262/E196).
suffix: ? Что ли, я цыганский барон, то

text: An opera hat. A portmanteau from шляпа (hat) and шлепок (slap, smack). The term is in turn derived from the French "chapeau claque," which combines "hat" and "click," as the hat closes with a clicking sound. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3e/Chapeauclaque.png). The same style of hat is mentioned in Note VIII (R172/E39). Clothing motif.
ru_trans:
Шляпа-цилиндр. Слово-гибрид, образованное слиянием слов "шляпа" и шлепок". Сам термин происходит от французского "chapeau claque", в котором объединены слова "шляпа" и "щелчок", ведь цилиндр имеет свойство складываться со щелчком. Изображено ниже: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3e/Chapeauclaque.png)

Такой же вид шляпы упоминается в Записке VIII (R172/E39). Мотив одежды.
prefix: ое, выбрал в тот раз чиновничий

text: Made of cheviot sheep fur. Clothing motif.
ru_trans: Сделано из шерсти овец породы шевиот.

text: A long coat, typical for Polish and Galician Jews. Pictured here: ![](https://helperia.ru/public/images/comments/3/37/591074.jpg) Clothing motif.
ru_trans: Длинное пальто, типичное для польских и галисийских евреев. Изображено ниже: ![](https://helperia.ru/public/images/comments/3/37/591074.jpg)

text: Dated: the словое́рс (*slovojers*). An obsolete honorific suffix derived from сударь (*súdarʹ*, sir) previously used to emphasize one's politeness or lower social position.
ru_trans: Устаревшее: словое́рс. Вышедший из употребления суффикс для выражения почтения с собеседнику, исходно образованный от слова "сударь" и использовавшийся для подчеркивания вежливости или низшей социальной позиции говорящего.

text: Colloquial: to make a mistake, miss the mark.
ru_trans: Разговорное: ошибиться, промазать.

text: Colloquial: of clothes that for long were not worn. Here, it is used meaning "durable" in order to explain why the clothing choice was good and practical. Clothing motif.
ru_trans: Разговорное: об одежде, которую долго не носили. Здесь, употреблено в значении "прочный, долго не изнашивающийся", чтобы объяснить, почему выбор материала был удачный.

text: Mispelling: semaphores. An "appratus for signalling." From the Greek *sema* (sign, signal) and *phoros* (bearer). Used to transmit signals over a distance as for railway traffic. Orina works at a railway station. The railway is a key motif in Sokolov's art.

text: According to Ostanin (42), a quotation from Nadezhda Pavlovich's poem "Beregom, beregom, s razbegu...". Read the original [here](https://slova.org.ru/pavlovich/beregomberegom/).
ru_trans: Согласно Останину (42), цитата из стихотворения Н. Павлович "Берегом, берегом, с разбегу...". Прочитать оригинал можно [здесь](https://slova.org.ru/pavlovich/beregomberegom/).

ru_trans: Устойчивое выражение: дать прикурить — доступно объяснить что к чему, выбить всю дурь.

highlighted: What and what—such an annoyin whatter
text: Sokolov has written about his desire to avoid the "what" in literature," opting for the "how": “In the milieu from which I come […] the traditions of so-called art-for-art’s sake are still alive. I am using here the expression so-called because by definition art is always for its own sake […] Forgive me for being so insistent, but art should be beautiful. And prose – should be refined and superior like poetry. […] Show me your how – a pass to truth, and take away what; I will find what myself.” (Sokolov, “The Key Word of Belles-Lettres, In the House of the Hanged, 28-29)
Diminutive form of Ilya
Another spelling of Gorodnishche.
suffix: , I don’t begrudge you nothin; f
